HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Securities Industry Pushes To Limit State Enforcement
Some members of the securities industry have started lobbying Capitol Hill to stop states from bringing enforcement actions against brokerage firms. A proposed amendment would shut down state investigations into conflicts among analysts and restrict states' enforcement of securities laws.
 State regulators say they have a duty to protect investors. The question, they say, is whether to stand with millions of investors or a handful of Wall Street firms. Page A1. 

Nestle Merges Ice Cream Business
Nestle has agreed to merge its United States ice cream business, which includes Haagen-Dazs, with Dreyer's Grand Ice Cream in a $2.4 billion deal that will give Nestle control of the new company. The proposed merger will help Nestle to compete with Unilever, which makes Ben & Jerry's and Breyers ice cream. C13.

Licensing deals by food companies have led to products like Jack Daniel's Grilling Sauces and Creamsicle Candy Twists. More such products are on the way. Advertising. C14.

Cruise Ship Project Fails
Two years after the government announced an ambitious program to build two passenger cruise ships, the project has failed, costing the government $187 million. A1.

Irish Paper Company Is Acquired
Madison Dearborn Partners, a private equity firm in Chicago, has agreed to acquire the Jefferson Smurfit Group, a global paper and packaging conglomerate based in Ireland. World Business, Section W.

Disney Unit Shifts to Linux
Disney's animation division plans to use data-serving computers running Linux for digital animation work. The Disney move is the latest commitment by major studios and special-effects houses to Linux software. C15.

Tough Microsoft Sanctions Urged
In the closing days of the Microsoft antitrust trial, six economists filed a brief urging tough sanctions against the software maker. C15.

Markets Have a Strong Day
The Dow Jones industrials closed up 213.21 points, at 9,687.42. The Standard & Poor's 500 index rose 28.90 points, to 1,036.17, and the Nasdaq jumped 48.55 points, to 1,553.29. C15.

More Questions for Martha Stewart
Congressional investigators say there are inconsistencies between what lawyers for Martha Stewart have told them about the timing of her sale of ImClone shares and what her stockbroker is reported to have said. Investigators also want to interview the stockbroker, Peter Bacanovic, who handled the ImClone sale for Ms. Stewart. C4.

Opposing a Return to Downtown
Many reporters and editors at The Wall Street Journal are opposed to a return to offices across from the World Trade Center. C14.

EgyptAir Removes Its Chairman
Battered by tensions in the Middle East, a drop in tourism and a poor safety record, EgyptAir has removed its chairman, Muhammad Fahim Rayan. World Business, Section W.

Have 8-Iron, Will Buy Shares in Jet
For golfing celebrities like Tiger Woods, a private plane is just another business deal. But for many other golfers, it is a major expense that can also buy them time and peace of mind. Joe Sharkey: On the Road. C8.

HEADLINE: Energy Call to Action 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Missing from David Gergen's laudable call to action for Americans after Sept. 11 is an appeal to urgently address our country's energy challenge ("A Nation in Search of Its Mission," Op-Ed, June 17). 
 Sept. 11 was as much of an alarm as the 1973 oil embargo. 
It is imperative that we respond this time by making sure that America will not be held hostage by unfriendly oil suppliers who finance terrorism and teach hatred of the West.
In 1973, America imported 28 percent of its crude oil. Today, the figure is 59 percent, and 30 percent of it comes from the Persian Gulf, principally Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and yes, Iraq.
Increasingly popular S.U.V.'s are subject to laxer mileage standards than cars. Even for cars, fuel economy standards have not been raised since the 1980's.
There are no simple formulas for developing a national energy policy, but the high stakes should jolt us all into action.

DAVID A. HARRIS
Executive Director
American Jewish Committee
New York, June 17, 2002

HEADLINE: Notes From Tysons Corner; 
A Suburb All Grown Up and Paved Over

BYLINE:  By David Plotz; David Plotz is the Washington bureau chief of Slate.

DATELINE: TYSONS CORNER, Va. 

 BODY:
The first commandment of the suburbs used to be Not in My Back Yard. Apparently now it is Not in Your Front Yard -- at least here in Fairfax County, Va., just over the Potomac from Washington.
 Earlier this month the county council passed a law forbidding homeowners from paving over their front yards to create extra parking spaces. This legislation is directed not at the mansion-owners of Reston, who have ample room for their fleets of Beemers, but at the immigrants sardined into houses in the county's less tony neighborhoods, like Groveton. There has apparently been a rash of yard-paving: the owners of these houses have asphalted the lawn so they have a place to put the three, four or six cars that their sisters and husbands and cousins need to get to work. 
 Fairfax isn't the only jurisdiction that is fighting yard-paving; Boston and San Francisco are, too. But there is something absurd in the idea of Fairfax trying to limit car ownership. Like most suburbs, Fairfax County owes not just its existence but its prosperity to the automobile. Its major landmarks are intersections (Bailey's Crossroads, Tysons Corner, Seven Corners and so on). And there's something equally silly in the notion that stopping pave-overs somehow preserves Fairfax's natural beauty -- as if any remained. One councilwoman said she supported the bill because pave-overs had "nibbled away" at Fairfax's green space.
Nibbled is right: When you add up the malls and highways and condos and office parks and malls and malls, what's left is enough greenery for a side salad. Every neighborhood in Fairfax is named after the nature that was destroyed to build it: Rose Hill, Blueberry Farm, Sycamore Lakes -- every place but Money's Corner.
The paving regulation stems partly, of course, from the usual paranoia about property values. Grass sells better than asphalt. But the regulation may succeed only in moving cars from the front lawn to the front curb. As soon as the pave-over law passed, at least one resident griped that it would encourage people to park on the street. No doubt the council will be weighing street parking bans next. 
The true cause of the pave-over law, however, is not parking. It's Fairfax's midlife crisis. Fairfax County, which strutted and preened through the 1990's, is having some bad years. America Online, which was born and raised here, married Time Warner and moved its headquarters to New York City. Michael Saylor, Fairfax County's very own Internet billionaire, has become a pariah, his crippled company, Microstrategy, a symbol of all that was wrong with the tech bubble. The richest county in America according to the 1990 census, Fairfax discovered a few weeks ago that it has now dropped to No. 2.
Yet the roots of the crisis here go even deeper. Since the 1970's, Fairfax has morphed from a bucolic exurb into its own metropolis, a hotbed of industry and commerce. The typical lazy comforts of the distant suburb have vanished; the danger and disorder of the city always seem to be encroaching. The county's population will top a million any day now -- nearly twice that of Washington itself.
Growth is not new to the county, but immigrants are. The number of immigrants in Fairfax jumped 86 percent in the 90's, to nearly a quarter of the population. (Essentially all the population growth came from immigrants and their children.) A third of county residents now speak a language other than English at home, more than twice the national average.
Fairfax is the very model of the benefits of immigration. Southeast Asians, Indians, Arabs, Pakistanis, West Africans, East Africans and Latin Americans have all settled here in huge numbers, but the county remains wonderfully mixed up. It lacks ethnic enclaves. Immigration has accomplished the impossible in Fairfax: it has made the county interesting, with the area's best and oddest ethnic restaurants and stores.
Fairfax's high-tech industry has relied heavily on highly educated foreign workers. At the same time, though without the same eagerness, Fairfax has accepted tens of thousands of low-skill immigrants. They are the backbone of the county's service sector. Working-class immigrants move to Fairfax because that is where the jobs are. They pack houses because rents and home prices are so high they can't afford to live in less cramped conditions. They buy cars because that's the only way they can get to the jobs that everyone wants them to do. And so they pave driveways.
Poverty rates have climbed with the arrival of these immigrants, and middle-class neighbors feel squeezed. The pave-over bill is only the most recent manifestation of their worry. Last year a state senator from Fairfax introduced a bill to the Virginia Legislature that would forbid Virginians from sleeping in living rooms, dining rooms, kitchens and closets. The measure was withdrawn immediately after loud complaints from civil libertarians and immigrant groups.
Fairfax is growing up faster than its residents can adjust. Like many sprawled suburbs, it has consumed its youthful vim and isn't quite sure what to do now. In the space of a generation, Fairfax lost its rural character and its middle-class white identity. In exchange it has won jobs, businesses and bustling, hustling immigrants.
The pave-over battle is a small rearguard action to preserve some vision of a Fairfax past, and in a way it's oddly encouraging. It signals the success of the American melting pot: Fairfax County has undergone great change, causing enormous upheaval, and all anyone can find to fight about is parking.

HEADLINE: Retirement Rules Gone, the Ivory Tower Goes Gray 

BYLINE:  By SAMUEL WEISS

 BODY:
At 78, Robert G. Shulman remains an active and distinguished member of the academic community at Yale.
 Holding the title of Sterling professor, Yale's most prestigious rank, in the department of molecular biophysics and biochemistry, Dr. Shulman still goes to his laboratory every day, where he conducts research on brain metabolism while teaching advanced biochemistry to M.D.-Ph.D. candidates at Yale Medical School. 
 Until the end of the spring semester, when he finally decided to give it up, Dr. Shulman was also a team teacher of an undergraduate seminar on science and literature. 
"There are things I've wanted to do and I can do them here," he said, explaining why he continues to work full time when other colleagues have long since retired.
Eight years after Congress put an end to college regulations that forced faculty members to retire by 70, a growing number of professors have begun working past that age.
This is particularly true at some premier Northeastern institutions like Yale, Columbia and New York University, but at other leading research universities, like the University of Chicago and Johns Hopkins, faculty members also remain highly motivated and working conditions are close to ideal.
Some college administrators continue to argue, as many did before the retirement rules were changed in 1994, that the new workplace environment encourages professors protected by tenure to stay well beyond their prime. This, they say, prevents promising younger scholars, particularly women and members of racial minorities, from gaining permanent positions.
Other administrators say they are losing the energy and ideas that younger professors bring to their fields. 
"The problem is double-edged," said Jonathan R. Cole, provost of Columbia. "Chronological age is not always a good indicator of research and teaching ability, and some of the most cherished members of our faculty" are older than 70.
But, he said, a major research university "always needs to revitalize itself with new ideas and new perspectives and those more often than not come from younger faculty members."
Still, the evidence suggests that although many faculty members may indeed be putting off retirement, a great majority of them are still retiring by their mid-60's, and the trend of working longer has not been a major factor in the overall decline of employment opportunities at most colleges.
Ronald G. Ehrenberg, the Irving M. Ives professor of industrial and labor relations and economics at Cornell, noted, for example, that while the number of full-time faculty jobs shrunk significantly over the last decade, the primary reason has been fiscal. Teaching jobs have been eliminated or converted to part-time positions to save money. "The vast majority of American faculty are going to retire before age 70, so lifting the age cap is not going to be that important at most institutions," he said.
The exception, he and others say, appears to be at the nation's elite private research universities, where professors tend to work longer than their colleagues at other institutions, and where there is more pressure to remain productive and stay in the forefront of scholarship.
"These are people that are just so tied to their jobs they cannot conceive of doing something else and they want to keep working," said Dr. Ehrenberg, who is chairman of the committee on retirement for the American Association of University Professors.
Exactly how many faculty members are now working past 70 is not known. David Card, an economist at the University of California at Berkeley and a co-author of a major study last year on changing retirement patterns in academia, estimates that perhaps as much as 1.8 percent of the faculty members at the nation's four-year colleges and universities are now 70 or older, whereas eight years ago, virtually none were. But he noted that data in his study, done with Orley Ashenfelter of Princeton, showed there was much variation among institutions and that the percentage of older faculty members appeared to be significantly higher at some of the nation's best-known institutions.
Calls to several universities seemed to confirm that. At Yale, almost 9 percent of the 370 tenured faculty members in core arts and sciences faculty are 70 or older. At Princeton, 4.9 percent are; Columbia, 7 percent; Harvard, 7 percent; New York University, 7 to 10 percent; and Johns Hopkins, about 10 percent.
For the last few years, Columbia has offered a $30,000 financial incentive to professors who retire before the age of 70. But the steady rise in the ranks of older professors -- and complaints by department chairmen that they were losing flexibility to hire new teachers -- prompted the university this year to offer members of the arts and sciences faculty who were 70 or older a one-time offer of a full year's paid leave if they retired by June 30. To date, 14 faculty members have accepted the offer, according to David H. Cohen, vice president for arts and sciences.
A trend seems to be growing among colleges and universities to offer retirement incentives. It began building in the early 1990's when it became clear that Congress would eliminate the exemption universities had under the Age Discrimination in Employment Act.
"Before the early 90's, most universities could rely on mandatory retirement rules to eliminate any uncertainty they faced about planning," said P. Brett Hammond, co-editor of a book about retirement policy and practice in higher education. "A faculty member turned 70 and that was it. 
Or, if a professor was felt not to be pulling his weight, "a dean might put his arm around a guy and ask what it would take to get him to leave," Mr. Hammond said."
But taking their cue from the University of California, several big public universities began offering buyouts, in which faculty members received cash payments or pension enhancements for agreeing to retire in a certain time period.
Another popular plan is a phased-in program under which professors have a chance to acclimate themselves to the idea of leaving by allowing them to teach reduced course loads for a fixed period of time at lower pay.
Yale has a phased-in program with two options. Under one, a faculty member between 59 and 67 with at least 15 years of service can reduce his administrative responsibilities, including supervision of doctoral dissertations, while keeping his full-time responsibilities for teaching and research for up to three years, and still receive his full salary. 
Under the second option, the faculty member can reduce his teaching and research load by half for up to three years, but he would receive half his salary. Under both options, Yale permits the faculty member to begin receiving his pension.
Although experts say that the problems created by the lifting of mandatory retirement rules are limited in scope thus far, they also say it is difficult to say if they will stay that way. 
Most of today's professors were hired during the heyday of university expansion during the 1960's and 1970's. Statistics show that almost half of the tenured professors in the country are 55 or older, and it is hard to tell whether retirements will continue at the current rate.
Other variables are economic conditions. Mr. Hammond, who is director of portfolio studies for TIAA-CREF, the giant fund that manages the pensions of more than half the nation's faculty members, said that under the bull market conditions of the 1990's, the average retiring faculty member had a good chance of receiving at least 70 percent of his final year's salary from his pension account combined with Social Security.
But if the recent downturn in the market continues, he said, that could change a lot of minds about retirement.
"If market conditions are not as robust as they have been, one option is to keep working longer, and professors have that option," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Dr. Robert G. Shulman, at 78, is still going strong at Yale, as Sterling professor in biophysics and molecular biochemistry. He works every day, doing research and teaching advanced courses at Yale's medical school. (Thomas McDonald for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Gauges Are Mixed in an Up-and-Down Day on Wall St.

BYLINE:  By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Stocks closed narrowly mixed, fluctuating throughout the session as investors cashed in some profits from a rally on Monday. A revenue downgrade for I.B.M. reminded investors that an economic recovery was not assured.
 The news on I.B.M. was offset somewhat by an upbeat housing report. Analysts said investors who felt more optimistic on Monday about a business recovery seemed less willing to commit to stocks until the rebound in earnings and the economy was more of a sure thing. 
 "Most of our customers are waiting for a time when they feel more confident about doing something," said Philip S. Dow, managing director of equity strategy at Dain Rauscher Wessels in Minneapolis.
After shifting between gains and losses through the day, the Dow Jones industrial average closed up 18.70 points, or 0.2 percent, to 9,706.12. The advance was slight compared with the 213-point surge on Monday when the Dow claimed its biggest daily point gain since May 8, when it rose 305.28 points.
Broader indicators were mixed. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index inched up 0.97 point, or 0.1 percent, to 1,037.14, having climbed nearly 29 points on Monday, its best daily advance since May 8, when it rose 39.36. The Nasdaq composite index declined 10.33 points, or 0.7 percent, to 1,542.96, after rising 48.55 points on Monday to achieve its best one-day gain since rising 66.51 points on May 14.
Analysts said the fluctuations also had to do with its efforts to find a normal trading range after more erratic sessions, the rally on Monday and big losses last week, when the Dow had two triple-digit declines.
Investors seemed encouraged by a report from the Commerce Department that said housing construction rose 11.6 percent in May, the largest increase since July 1995. Home builders advanced on the housing news; Lennar rose $1.80, to $57.30.
But I.B.M. was the weak spot, and its shares fell $1.20, to $75.94, after Morgan Stanley lowered its revenue outlook for the second quarter as well as 2002 and 2003.
Over all, technology stocks were mixed. Shares in Intel fell 54 cents, to $22.02, while shares in Microsoft rose 31 cents, to $55.99.
Investors punished companies that said profits continued to languish. Shares in the electronics retailer Best Buy sank $2.51, to $39.75.
The market was uninspired by the Labor Department's report that consumer prices were flat in May. That was the best showing in inflation in five months and an improvement over the 0.5 percent increase in April.
Still, analysts said the market's lackluster performance was not surprising given the strides the market made Monday after four weeks of selling on concerns about earnings, the economy and conflicts overseas. --------------------

Treasury Prices Rise
By Reuters
Treasuries rebounded from early losses to stand mostly firmer yesterday, encouraged that equities lacked the strength to support a second day of hefty gains.
The price of the benchmark 10-year Treasury note increased 3/32, to 100 10/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, dropped to 4.83 percent from 4.85 percent on Monday. The 30-year bond increased 2/32, to 98 25/32. Its yield was unchanged at 5.46 percent.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 
Making Waves on Air: Big Radio's Bad Boy

BYLINE:  By LYNNLEY BROWNING 

 BODY:
Wall Street admires the nation's largest radio broadcasting conglomerate, Clear Channel Communications, as a fast-growing, profitable multimedia empire. It includes the largest chain of radio stations -- five times the number of its nearest rival -- and the biggest collection of billboards, as well as growing collections of television stations and concert halls.
 Among its competitors and some cultural critics, however, Clear Channel is referred to as "the evil empire" -- or worse. They complain that the company, based in San Antonio, has made its money by filling its broadcasts with prefabricated nonlocal programming or with tasteless fare that hit bottom last year when one of its disc jockeys in Tampa, Fla., had a wild boar castrated and killed in the parking lot of his station while he described the scene and added recorded pig squeals on the air. 
 But in some ways, many rivals of Clear Channel -- including Cumulus Media, the Infinity Radio unit of Viacom and Citadel Communications -- are increasingly copying it. They are courting advertisers and listeners with moves that come directly from Clear Channel's playbook -- even if they do not involve livestock. They are also scrambling to acquire more stations, to come closer to matching Clear Channel's huge audience. 
The reason is simple. Clear Channel, in the last two years, has acquired enough stations of its own -- it now has 1,200, about one-tenth of all radio stations -- to dominate the industry. It ranks No. 1 in 5 of the top 10 markets and No. 2 in four others, sometimes commanding more than a third of all listeners. In some top-25 markets, like Denver and Cleveland, about half of all listeners tune in to Clear Channel stations. Inside Radio, an independent industry newsletter, estimates that Clear Channel has a larger national audience than the four next-largest broadcasters combined.
"Being up against those guys is forcing us to become more resourceful," said Lewis Dickey, chairman and chief executive of Cumulus, the No. 2 radio broadcaster as measured by number of stations -- it owns 248. "They are very aggressive, so now we're more aggressive. They've set the standard that we're responding to."
Clear Channel's aggressive approach includes cost-cutting -- it has replaced many local radio hosts, for example, with recorded music programs spiked with local color for individual stations, or with syndicated talk-show hosts like Rush Limbaugh and Dr. Laura Schlesinger. But with 770,000 billboards, 135 concert halls and 19 television stations -- and 18 more being acquired -- Clear Channel also has the resources to undercut competitors on price while wooing advertisers with cross-promotion over many different media. Few rivals, for example, can promote a music group on their stations, book the act in their clubs and amphitheaters, then advertise the tour on their billboards.
"There is a very strong sentiment that they have done a disservice to broadcasting, by using their clout in a way that makes it difficult for smaller companies to compete," said Reed Bunzel, chief editor of Radio Ink, a trade publication. "A lot of people in the business really hate Clear Channel."
None of this has stopped other broadcasters from adopting many strategies pioneered by Clear Channel, including million-dollar contests for listeners and attractive package deals for advertisers that cover many stations. Some competitors have started working together to ask advertisers to place ads with them as a group, to counter Clear Channel's new push to entice advertisers to sign exclusive deals to pitch products across its empire.
Competitors are also bulking up, aiming to meet Clear Channel head-on. Mr. Dickey said Cumulus, which is based in Atlanta, would try to double or triple in size over the next three to five years through acquisitions. "The one thing we've learned from Clear Channel is the advantages of size and scale," he said.
Beyond the big companies, thousands of one- and two-station broadcasters are hunkering down in their markets. Lacking the capital to grow but mindful that radio is a local medium, these smaller companies are working to counter Clear Channel's national reach by appealing more to local advertisers -- sending D.J.'s to car dealership promotions and high school football games, for example.
Clear Channel itself started small -- with a single FM radio station in San Antonio in 1972, when L. Lowry Mays, a former investment banker, was stuck with the station after a partner backed out of a deal to buy it. The company grew slowly, to 36 stations by the time the landmark federal Telecommunications Act of 1996 loosened station ownership restrictions. That set off a wave of consolidation and reshaped the industry.
Led by Mr. Mays as chief executive -- he has installed two sons, Randall and Mark, in senior management positions, and family members own or control more than 33 million shares of Clear Channel, or about 5.5 percent of the company -- Clear Channel gobbled up broadcasters from coast to coast, growing into a behemoth in the late 1990's. It vaulted into the No. 1 position two years ago, when it bought what was then the largest radio broadcaster, AMFM Inc. of Dallas, for $23.8 billion.
Competitors like Cumulus, Infinity and Citadel, which is based in Las Vegas and owned by Forstmann Little, went on smaller buying sprees. Still, they created a tiered industry with a few large conglomerates and scores of smaller players.
With its size and muscle, Clear Channel has prompted complaints from rivals that it resembles a monopoly. The Federal Communications Commission has said that it is investigating the company and other broadcasters to see whether consolidation has resulted in less diversity in programming. Senator Russell Feingold, Democrat of Wisconsin, said last week that he was preparing a bill that would impose restrictions on the radio and concert industries, in part because of Clear Channel's tactics. An Illinois woman filed a class-action lawsuit in United States District Court in Manhattan last week, accusing Clear Channel of using its market power to inflate the price of concert tickets.
On its Web site, the company says its share of all radio advertising dollars is around 20 percent. For 2001, Clear Channel's radio business had revenue of approximately $3.4 billion, or 43 percent of the company's total. The company reported a first-quarter loss of $17 billion, to reflect changes in how it accounts for good will and other intangible assets. Without those one-time changes, it showed a profit of $73 million, about what Wall Street analysts had forecast.
Many brokerage firms, like Merrill Lynch, are bullish about the company's prospects as the economy picks up. Its stock has fallen about 11 percent this year, hurt recently by a competitor's challenge to Clear Channel's attempt to buy the Hispanic Broadcasting Corporation, while shares of competitors like Cumulus and Radio One Inc. have risen 10 to 20 percent or more.
Clear Channel already uses its size to promote "cluster" sales of ads. Some are across geographic areas, while others may include all its stations with a particular music format, like hip-hop. Others are "cross-platform" sales that give advertisers access to different types of media, from radio to billboards. "We try to adapt our assets to whatever trading area you, Mr. Customer, might have," said Mark P. Mays, the president and chief operating officer and the older son of Lowry Mays. The younger son, Randall T. Mays, is the chief financial officer.
Now that advertising rates are firming as the economy emerges from recession, Clear Channel is flexing even more muscle in the scramble for ad revenue.
It recently persuaded Arbitron Inc., the listener ratings agency, to lump Clear Channel's eight stations in Florida into one customized "trading zone," with a single rating for the entire group. (Stations have traditionally been rated according to set geographic areas, usually broken down by county.)
The new system, which will take effect later this year and supplement the traditional system, may give Clear Channel a competitive advantage by making it look as though it has strong listener ratings across Florida, not just in particular counties. Advertisers use Arbitron ratings when deciding where to buy ads and how much to pay.
The move will put smaller broadcasters with fewer stations at a disadvantage before advertisers, said Warren S. Lada, the senior vice president for operations at Saga Communications, a broadcaster based in Grosse Pointe Farms, Mich. Saga owns 61 stations, none in Florida.
Even some much smaller broadcasters are trying to use some Clear Channel tactics.
Last month, Clear Channel sought to scoop up all the dollars that a major advertiser was planning to spend on radio in Philadelphia, said Chuck Fleming, who oversees the national media business at the McGavern Guild, a company in New York that represents radio stations to national advertisers.
Fighting back, three smaller broadcasters with a total of five stations in Philadelphia -- Greater Media, based in New Brunswick, N.J.; the Beasley Broadcast Group in Naples, Fla.; and WEAZ FM Radio of Bala Cynwyd, Pa. -- matched Clear Channel's bid.
Broadcasters are finding other ways to fight for revenue. The Susquehanna Media Group, which owns 29 stations in eight markets, plans to start selling access to its database, with profiles of 1.6 million listeners gleaned from contests and other promotions, for advertisers' direct-mail campaigns, said Peter Brubaker, Susquehanna's chief executive and president.
On another front, smaller competitors that once offered only modest contest prizes like restaurant gift certificates are increasingly staging million-dollar cash giveaways. 
The contests, which Clear Channel pioneered on the national level, have been criticized in the past as not making clear that the same contest runs on many stations simultaneously and that listeners are competing with audiences from stations around the country. In 2000, the Florida attorney general fined Clear Channel $80,000 for misleading listeners about one such contest and ordered it to clearly promote its future contests as national, not local.
For its part, Clear Channel appears to regard its rivals' me-too moves with a characteristic brash confidence.
"When you're a pioneer, you get a lot of arrows in your back," said Pam Taylor, a spokeswoman for the company. "But then people pick them out and say, 'Oh, that's not so bad.' "

HEADLINE: Home Building Is Up Sharply; Price Index Flat 

BYLINE:  Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 18 

 BODY:
Home construction grew sharply in May, increasing at the fastest rate in nearly seven years, the Commerce Department reported today.
 The number of projects started last month rose by an unexpectedly high 11.6 percent in May, after two months of declines, the report said. 
 "The housing market suggests the economic recovery is on track and not as weak as the market perceives it to be," said Peter Cardillo, chief strategist for Global Partners Securities. 
In a separate report, the Labor Department said that consumer prices, a measure of inflation, were unchanged in May, leaving Federal Reserve interest rate setters with few worries of mounting price pressures. 
"Inflation is not a threat at this point," said Gary Thayer, chief economist at A. G. Edwards in St. Louis. "Policy makers are going to want to make sure the economic recovery is sustainable before they raise rates." 
The housing market, aided by the lowest mortgage rates in decades, continued to turn in a strong performance last month. 
"Housing starts confirm that low mortgage rates continue to keep the housing market strong," said Edgar Peters of PanAgora Asset Management in Boston. "Rising housing prices are offsetting the negative wealth effect from the stock market so that consumers continue to feel as if their financial situation is stable." 
Groundbreaking for new houses jumped to a seasonally adjusted annual pace of 1.733 million from a downward revised 1.553 million pace in April, the biggest rise since July 1995, the Commerce Department said. Starts of single-family homes, the largest category of activity, jumped 9.6 percent, an increase also unmatched since July 1995. 
Many economists had thought that last year's torrid pace of housing construction was ready to slow, but the sector has proved resilient with mortgage rates below 7 percent. 
Consumer prices in May were flat. Held down in part by declining energy and food prices, the Consumer Price Index, the most widely used inflation barometer, was flat in May after a seasonally adjusted 0.5 percent rise in April. Excluding food and energy prices, the so-called core price index rose 0.2 percent, after gaining 0.3 percent in April. 
"It's still too early to make firm predictions, but we may be heading for one of the better-case recovery scenarios -- an economy growing moderately and creating new jobs but not strong enough to generate worrisome inflationary pressures," said Oscar Gonzalez, an economist at John Hancock Financial Services.

HEADLINE: Albany's Work Is Not Done 

 BODY:
In a State Legislature as addicted to behind-the-scenes dealmaking as New York's, it's possible to accomplish a great deal very quickly. As the lawmakers in Albany move into the final days of their official session, there is plenty of work still on the table. Some important proposals, such as reorganization of the jumbled judicial system, can't be jump-started at this late date. But others are close to resolution. If officials don't get them done, they should be ashamed to face the voters this November. 
 Reform of the state's arcane Rockefeller drug laws, which impose cruelly long prison terms even for nonviolent offenders, is one priority that appears to be in danger of falling through the cracks. Prosecutors prefer the current system of mandatory terms because it gives them most of the real sentencing power. This is an area where Gov. George Pataki should show his leadership and negotiate a decent compromise between his own narrower bill and the Assembly's already modified offering. 
 For wage earners, the Legislature should raise the state's minimum wage, now only $5.15 an hour, and pass an extension of unemployment insurance for as many as 100,000 New Yorkers who are about to run through their benefits.
Resolving three environmental issues should also be within the Legislature's reach. Superfund, aimed at cleaning up highly toxic industrial sites, ran out of money long ago and needs to be reactivated. A brownfields program, which deals with less dangerous sites that can more easily be reclaimed, can be started at little cost since much of the money would come from developers. The law on siting of power plants expires this year, providing a golden opportunity to preserve the best features of the present law while closing loopholes that allow utilities to build small but dirty plants as long as they fall below a certain generating threshold. 
Once again the Legislature threatens to adjourn without approving basic civil rights legislation barring discrimination against gay people in employment, housing and public accommodations. The opposition lies in the Republican-majority State Senate, and Governor Pataki should persuade fellow party members to take action. Senate Republicans are also blocking a reasonable proposal by the Nassau County executive, Thomas Suozzi, to create a new sewer and storm water authority to help close a budget deficit that was built up under Mr. Suozzi's irresponsible G.O.P. predecessor.
A promising statewide ban on smoking in restaurants has stalled, under lobbying pressure from the small-restaurant owners who can now permit smoking in many parts of the state. Surveys show that bar and food revenues are not affected by smoking bans, and that they are popular with most customers. This is an election year, and if there's any time that Albany should be listening to majority sentiment rather than special interests, this is it.
There are other issues that the Legislature could still tackle if it really had the will. Despite much hand-wringing, nothing has been done yet about auto insurance rates. There is also time to pass a law giving customers more protection against predatory lending practices. This "sub-prime" or high-interest lending has ballooned in recent years, too often trapping borrowers who lose their homes.
Despite the long list of undone work, the Senate majority leader, Joseph Bruno, has vowed to close the session tomorrow. The Assembly speaker, Sheldon Silver, has declared that his house will continue working. Mr. Silver has the right idea. The Legislature has hardly covered itself in so much glory this term that it can afford to walk away from so many important priorities.

HEADLINE: Governor Could Hold Up A Deal on Minimum Wage 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA

DATELINE: ALBANY, June 18 

 BODY:
The Senate and Assembly have reached a consensus on raising the minimum wage to $6.75 an hour from $5.15 over the next year and a half, but officials said today that resistance by Gov. George E. Pataki was keeping the Senate from closing the deal.
 Legislators and top aides sent conflicting signals today about whether the two houses actually have an agreement on the issue. A top member of the Senate's Republican majority said a deal was at hand; the Assembly's Democratic leadership confirmed that, then the Senate Republicans insisted that there was not. 
 "Unless we've got something that looks like it'll get signed by the governor, we don't have anything," said Senator Joseph L. Bruno, the majority leader. "Hopefully, we can get something together tomorrow."
Mr. Pataki, a Republican, has said that he does not favor raising New York's minimum wage above the federal minimum of $5.15, which went into effect in 1997, arguing that it would put the state's businesses at a competitive disadvantage. Business groups, an important constituency for the governor, have fought hard against an increase.
"We continue to believe that an increase at the federal level would be preferable to taking action at the state level," said Joseph Conway, a spokesman for the governor.
Vetoing a minimum wage bill would be an unpopular move in many quarters, particularly among the labor unions that Mr. Pataki has ardently courted as he runs for re-election this year. It would give his Democratic opponents a potent issue to use against him.
Republican Senate officials have said they want to raise the wage, but the governor has expressed reservations, and they are reluctant to put Mr. Pataki in a position of having to sign or veto such a bill. "We're not going to jam the governor," one said.
The state A.F.L.-C.I.O. and the Working Families Party, a labor-backed group, have campaigned hard this year for a minimum wage bill, suggesting that passage could mean endorsements for some Republican senators in tight races for re-election. The A.F.L.-C.I.O. said the bill would mean increased pay for 600,000 workers who now earn less than $6.75 an hour.
When asked late this afternoon how things were progressing on the issue, Senator Guy J. Velella, the chairman of the Labor Committee and sponsor of the bill, said: "I think it's pretty well resolved. Everybody's on the same page, conceptually. All that's left is working out the language."
But, he cautioned, "It could all blow up in the next minute."
When asked to confirm that, legislative aides put it more strongly, saying that a deal had been struck by the two houses.
"We've done this bill for three years, and I'm glad that the Senate has finally seen the wisdom," Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver said.
But tonight, Mr. Bruno insisted that there was still no agreement. To support that argument, he handed his phone to Mr. Velella, who described the situation much as he had originally.
The tentative deal officials described would raise the minimum wage from $5.15 to $6 on Jan. 1, 2003, and to $6.75 on Jan. 1, 2004.
That would put New York in a tie for the second-highest minimum in the country, after Washington state, whose minimum is $6.90 and indexed to inflation, so that it automatically rises every Jan. 1. Massachusetts and California have $6.75 minimums now, and Connecticut is next, at $6.70. In all, 10 states and the District of Columbia have minimum wages higher than the federal minimum, according to the United States Department of Labor.
In other business today, the governor and two legislative leaders announced that they had reached an agreement on changes in requirements for teenagers to get a driver's license. Under the agreed-upon bill, a teenager could still get a learner's permit at age 16, but would have to complete 20 hours of driving over a six-month period with supervising adults before being allowed to take a driver's test. That would qualify the teenager for a junior license, which would be valid for driving only from 5 a.m. to 9 p.m.
To resolve complaints of rural legislators who have teenage constituents who need to drive to work, the legislation would create a limited-class license for minors with a learner's permit, letting them drive to school, work, medical appointments and day care. The Senate passed the bill today, and the Assembly could take it up as early as Thursday.

HEADLINE: Some Neighbors Seek Greater Voice on Plans For Sept. 11 Memorial 

BYLINE:  By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
Nearly everyone who has addressed the subject agrees that a memorial to the victims of the Sept. 11 attack should be central to the rebuilding of the World Trade Center site. But few people agree how to proceed -- or even how to get started.
 Downtown residents and civic groups say they are worried that the early planning for a memorial is being left behind or closed to public input. Meanwhile, the official rebuilding effort is hurtling toward a master plan for the site. Work on transportation projects has already begun in the pit, and an urban planning and architectural firm hired by the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation will unveil six proposals for an overall design within the next month. And while an advisory committee of family members of victims has begun memorial discussions, few if any others have been invited to the table so far. 
 "The more the planning for the site goes forward without an integrated memorial process, the harder it will be to integrate the two and come up with a comprehensive plan," said Jill Lerner, a co-coordinator of the memorial process committee for New York New Visions, a civic group that has worked on recommendations for the redevelopment of downtown. 
Development corporation officials disagree, saying that planning for the memorial should begin with the families. They add that the memorial is dependent to a large extent on options in the master plan proposals being put together by Beyer Blinder Belle, the architectural and planning firm working on the initial six designs for the site.
"Some people have said that they don't feel included, but it seems to us that the families is the logical place to begin," said Louis R. Tomson, president of the corporation. 
Questions about the memorial process came into stark focus last week after Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and others made comments about the memorial and plans for the site. Mr. Bloomberg, in response to a question, said that a small, graceful memorial would be most appropriate. He also said that the process of creating a memorial was likely to be marked by much "yelling and screaming" and that few people would welcome the idea of turning the site into "a cemetery."
John C. Whitehead, the chairman of the development corporation, and Mr. Tomson each said last week that it was likely that the memorial would be in the southwest quadrant of the 16-acre site, in a parcel created by reinstating Greenwich and Fulton Streets through the site. Such a parcel, measuring up to seven acres, would include the footprints of the twin towers, which many family members have said they would like to have as part of the memorial.
But Madelyn Wils, the chairwoman of Community Board 1, which represents Lower Manhattan residents, said residents were concerned that a memorial planned without input from many different sectors would cast a pall over an area that needs to be vibrant once again.
"People in the neighborhood want to see a memorial that honors all of the people who were lost in the attack, but one that also honors the people who survived it," said Ms. Wils, who is also a member of the development corporation's board.
"It is very difficult to live and work in an area that other people consider a cemetery," she said. "I can understand how the families of victims feel that way. But this isn't Gettysburg; it isn't Normandy Beach. This is a place that is vital and one that wants to be vital again."
One thing that has held back planning for a memorial, even as the planning for the site has accelerated, is that relatives of many victims of the attack have not even been able to bring themselves to visit ground zero, much less talk about what should go there. 
The Families Advisory Council of the development corporation has started that discussion, said Nikki Stern, a member of the council. The group's 25 or so members have divided into two committees, one to focus on how to develop a memorial design and the other to discuss the content.
The development corporation is also planning to appoint someone to oversee the memorial process, but does not yet have a timetable for doing so, Mr. Tomson said. Ultimately, a competition is likely to be conducted for the memorial's design.
In mid-July, according to the development corporation's schedule issued in May, a memorial design process will be announced. Yet participants say that the location and size of a memorial plot will not be known until the end of the year at the earliest, because only then will a master plan for the site be chosen, under the corporation's schedule. 
"We need to be establishing benchmarks and integrating the memorial process with the planning effort," said Marian Imperatore, chairwoman of the memorial process committee for the Civic Alliance to Rebuild Downtown New York, a group put together by the Regional Plan Association and other civic groups. Ms. Imperatore's family owns NY Waterway, the ferry service that shuttles people between Lower Manhattan and New Jersey.
Not least among the planning considerations for a memorial is the need to accommodate millions of expected visitors each year, and the tour buses that bring them, in a heavily trafficked business district.
Holly Leicht, a co-director of Imagine New York, the largest effort so far to include the general public in discussions about the rebuilding, said the 4,000 participants in its forums were passionate about their desire to be included in the memorial discussion.
"They made clear that the public participation element had to become more prominent," Ms. Leicht said.
At a seminar last week sponsored by the New York chapter of the American Institute of Architects, some designers who have worked independently on ideas for the site said that limiting the memorial to one corner of the site precludes more attractive options for the development as a whole. 
Such options include, for example, creating a memorial plaza extending westward along the northern border of the site from St. Paul's Chapel on Broadway, which became a temporary shrine to the victims and rescuers, to the World Financial Center on West Street.
Others say they believe the memorial should occupy some central portion of the site, drawing visitors in through a corridor, similar to the way the entrance to Rockefeller Center from Fifth Avenue draws in visitors to the central plaza. Hundreds of ideas have been floated already, including placing a memorial on the roof of a tall tower or forming a memorial's perimeter from the outlines of the towers' shadows at the times they were struck.
Until a memorial is completed -- likely to be several years -- the entire site is expected to be surrounded by a viewing wall, which will allow the site to be seen at ground level.
"I think it would be short-sighted to say that one quadrant needed to be the memorial, without considering something that in the long run might be more successful," said Margaret Helfand, co-chairwoman of the executive committee for the New York New Visions project. 
Ms. Stern, whose husband, James E. Potorti, was killed at the trade center, said that in the advisory council's discussions, many family members said they were counting on the footprints of the towers being part of the memorial. 
"I have to believe that is being taken strongly into consideration," she said.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS; 
INTERNATIONAL PAPER IS SELLING A PLANT IN CORINTH, N.Y.

BYLINE:  Reuters 

 BODY:
 Citing a sluggish economy and reduced demand, the International Paper Company said yesterday that it would close and put up for sale its Hudson River mill in Corinth, N.Y., in the fourth quarter, eliminating 290 jobs. The company said on Monday that it had scrapped plans to sell two businesses as part of a revamping. International Paper, which has sold $3 billion worth of assets during its revamping, said it would not pursue the sale of its Arizona chemical business and its industrial papers business. The company announced plans in November 2000 to sell the Arizona business, which supplies the adhesives, inks and coatings markets. The unit employs 1,800 people and is based in Jacksonville, Fla. The industrial papers unit, which makes paper products for food packaging and hygiene markets, among others, was put up for sale in November 2001. In announcing its decision to scrap the sales, the company said it would support both units and focus on making them more profitable. Shares of International Paper, which is based in Stamford, Conn., closed at $43.89 yesterday, up 58 cents.

HEADLINE: Electricite de France Buying Seeboard, a British Utility 

BYLINE:  By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: LONDON, June 18 

 BODY:
The American Electric Power Company said today that it would sell its Seeboard regional power utility in Britain to the state-owned French power monopoly Electricite de France for $975 million in cash and the assumption of $1.05 billion in Seeboard debt. 
 The move raises the possibility of European regulatory difficulties because the French market remains closed to similar deals. 
 Electricite de France, Europe's biggest power company, already owns London Electricity and Western Electricity.
The acquisition of Seeboard's two million retail customers will give Electricite de France "a large share of the competitive market" that is developing, said Mark Robinson, a utilities analyst with Commerzbank here. 
Earlier this year, RWE of Germany bought Innogy, Britain's biggest electricity retailer, while E.ON of Germany is close to acquiring Powergen, another utility in the fragmented British market that has emerged from the privatization of electricity and gas businesses since 1990.
Seeboard was the last remaining independent energy supplier in Britain.
With the acquisition of Seeboard, Electricite de France will have about five million customers -- regarded by analysts as sufficient to establish a critical mass. 
"Once you get north of four million customers you are most of the way there," Mr. Robinson said. The deal puts Electricite de France in a position to catch up with rivals like RWE and Centrica of Britain, each of which supply power to around five million customers.
Like its rivals in the United States, American Electric Power of Columbus, Ohio, the biggest domestic electricity generator, is selling overseas assets to cut its debt as credit rating companies scrutinize energy companies more closely after the bankruptcy of Enron. 
In a statement, American Electric said it would use the proceeds of the Seeboard sale to cut its debt.
"The risks inherent to the competitive retail energy business are best undertaken by consolidators like London Electricity Group," said E. Linn Draper Jr., the chief executive of American Electric. He has said that he wants to cut the company's $15.8 billion debt through asset and securities sales.
American Electric said London Electricity would also assume obligations valued at $146 million related to a power purchase agreement with Medway Power of Britain. Seeboard has a 37.5 percent stake in Medway. 
In bidding for Seeboard, Electricite de France was up against three other competitors -- E.ON, Scottish and Southern Energy of Britain and the TXU Corporation of Dallas. 
The deal raised speculation that other combinations could follow, including a merger of Scottish and Southern with Scottish Power or an attempt by E.ON to bid for Scottish and Southern.
Some analysts said, however, that a more likely next step was a share buyback by Scottish and Southern to reduce its cash reserves, which could tempt a hostile bidder. The company has a reputation for hard-nosed management and a refusal to overpay for assets.
In its statement, American Electric acknowledged that the Seeboard deal was "conditional only on the European Commission approving the transaction under its merger regulations."
Mr. Robinson of Commerzbank said: "We shouldn't dismiss regulatory concerns. You can't go and compete in the French market the same as you can in the U.K." This, he added, would lead European regulators to "look to see whether this is in the public interest on the basis of nonreciprocity."
The newly elected center-right French government has promised to oversee a reduction of the state presence in the economy. The government has lagged some of its European neighbors in selling stakes in businesses like telecommunications and power.
But that is likely to be a slow process and deals like today's revive complaints that Electricite de France has an unfair advantage over publicly owned companies because it uses government funds to outbid rivals that have no access to the French market.

HEADLINE: Battle to Beat Schroder Finds Hope in Europe's Tilt to Right 

BYLINE:  By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: BERLIN, June 18 

 BODY:
The conservative challenger for the German leadership, Edmund Stoiber, made an unusually emotional and bitter attack today on the current chancellor, Gerhard Schroder, and promised to oust the current government in elections Sept. 22.
 Often considered dry and pedantic, Mr. Stoiber, who is from Bavaria, hopes to ride the rightward mood in Europe to victory, concentrating on issues like economic competence and stricter controls on immigration, which have been important in recent elections in France and the Netherlands. 
 Today he made a fiery speech to a conference of the Christian Democratic Union in Frankfurt that was dotted with emotional references to his wife, his children and his country. 
Mr. Stoiber, the joint candidate of the Christian Democrats and his own Bavaria-based Christian Social Union, has maintained a lead in the opinion polls over Mr. Schroder's Social Democrats, who are in alliance with the Greens, a so-called "red-green coalition."
"In 96 days, this red-green nonsense in Berlin will be over," Mr. Stoiber told delegates as sweat stained his collar. "We believe it and polls show most Germans believe it, too. In 96 days, Germany starts moving again."
Mr. Stoiber urged Germans to shift to the center-right, as the French have just done. Mr. Schroder and Britain's prime minister, Tony Blair, are among the few leftist leaders remaining in Western Europe.
Mr. Stoiber, who is running on a reputation for economic competence, called Mr. Schroder the "chancellor of broken promises" for having failed to get unemployment down to below 3.5 million -- a Schroder vow -- and presiding over a Germany that has the lowest growth rates in Europe.
"With these red-green troops, Germany has lost economically compared with France, Italy, Denmark and even Portugal and Greece," Mr. Stoiber said, pointing to high bankruptcy figures and unemployment, currently hovering about four million.
"Years ago," Mr. Stoiber said, "Schroder rattled the gates of the chancellery and said, 'Let me in.' My dear friends, now it's time to kick him out."
Mr. Stoiber, 60, has benefited from a new media consultant -- Michael Spreng, a former editor -- and he has pushed a slogan of "40-40-40," promising to cut the top rate of tax, social security contributions from salaries and the level of public spending in the economy all to under 40 percent.
But Mr. Stoiber has not challenged Germany's powerful unions very strongly, talking of fewer structural impediments to hiring and firing while always repeating that "the American system" is not appropriate for Germany.
But he has also promoted a respected "competence team," a kind of cabinet in waiting, to reassure voters on areas where Mr. Stoiber is not so strong. 
They include Wolfgang Schauble, a former Christian Democrat chairman entrusted with foreign and security policy, and Lothar Spath, a former prime minister of Baden-Wurttemberg who now heads a successful high-tech company in eastern Germany called Jenoptik.
Mr. Stoiber also returned today to what has become a familiar theme, calling again for stricter controls on immigration. He has tried to block a Schroder-drafted law that would allow more immigration from well-educated workers, especially in computer sciences, that the aging German population needs to compete.
The president of the Federation of German Industry, Michael Rogowski, told the delegates today that the conservatives should be "more reasonable" on immigration. The country needs more skilled workers and soon, he said, to promote economic growth.
But the likely finance minister in a conservative government, Friedrich Merz, said Germany could not make room for immigrant workers until it found more jobs for Germans, and he and others said immigration would remain a central issue.
"Our central aim must be to integrate four million unemployed into the labor market," he said. "There is no room for immigrant workers from outside the European Union until we have filled the 1.5 million vacancies in Germany."

HEADLINE: Agreement Is in Sight on City's Budget Gap 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL COOPER

 BODY:
Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and the City Council edged closer to an agreement last night on how to close the city's nearly $5 billion budget gap, after the mayor agreed to restore some proposed cuts and the Council scaled back its demands.
 Peace began to break out between the two branches of city government around midday, as the rising tensions of the past few days ebbed. Although both sides cautioned last night that there was still plenty of work to be done, and details to be hashed out, they said they could reach an accord on the city's nearly $42 billion budget as early as today. 
 "I would say we have an agreement in principle," David Weprin, chairman of the council finance committee, said last night. "Anything can fall apart, and it's not in writing on the mayor's side either, but we have an agreement in principle." 
Marc V. Shaw, the first deputy mayor, said: "I think it will come together tomorrow. At the end of the day, both sides had a desire to reach a negotiated budget."
Officials said that the agreement closely resembled the mayor's executive budget proposal, but offered partial restorations of some of the most onerous cuts, including those that had been planned for centers for the elderly, libraries and child care programs, and that it would probably contain a compromise to save part of the city's recycling program.
This has not been an easy budget to agree on. The slumping economy, the economic fallout from the attack on the World Trade Center, and the bill coming due for the heightened government spending during the Giuliani years all left New York City with a nearly $5 billion gap in the fiscal year beginning July 1.
How to close that gap left the mayor and the Council at odds on a number of issues. 
The Council originally wanted to raise taxes to avoid service cuts, while the mayor opposed most tax increases, saying they would be bad for the economy and unlikely to win the approval of the State Legislature. The mayor wanted to suspend the recycling of glass, metal and plastics, while the Council wanted to preserve the program. Most of all, though, the two sides differed on cuts: the Council wanted to restore many of the mayor's budget cuts, while he argued that there was simply not enough money to go around.
"Nobody likes to have any services cut or removed," Mayor Bloomberg said yesterday, before the breakthrough. "On the other hand, we just don't have the money."
Last night officials offered few details on how the two sides were overcoming their many differences.
Forrest R. Taylor, chief of staff to Gifford Miller, the Council speaker, said last night, "Some of the issues that have been playing out previously -- recycling, education, those sorts of things -- we are trying to finalize those details on those issues."
But Council officials said the administration had made overtures to meet them part way, and last night the Council leadership and the members held a series of meetings to decide how to scale back the list of restorations they had been demanding -- deciding, in effect, which cuts they could live with and which they could not. Lobbyists descended on City Hall, and made a series of last-ditch efforts to save their programs.
The late flurry of activity came after the Council postponed a vote that had been designed to pressure the mayor. It was a threat of sorts. 
Yes, the Council said, it would ask the Legislature to approve the fees, taxes, surcharges and other budget actions that Mayor Bloomberg was seeking. But they also planned a second vote to ask Albany to do two things the mayor opposes: reinstate the commuter tax and add a tax on some absentee landlords. 
Neither tax had much chance of succeeding, but they put pressure on the administration, signaling that the Council was still thinking about passing a budget of its own, over the objections of the mayor's side. 
Mr. Bloomberg has long opposed most tax increases. Asked about the Council's plan to vote to ask Albany for both his package and their package, the mayor said bluntly, "One of them, I think, makes a lot of sense, one of them does not."
The vote was set for 3:30 p.m. The Council was summoned. And then, around 2 p.m., the vote was abruptly postponed until today. Both sides reported progress.
"There's a possibility that we may reach an agreement by tomorrow, and as a result we agreed to postpone our stated meeting," Mr. Weprin, the Council's finance chairman, said. 
Council officials said that when they convene today, they expect to send only one message to Albany, asking for actions both the mayor and the Council are seeking.

HEADLINE: Senate Passes Aid to Insurers On Terrorism 

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH B. TREASTER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 18 

 BODY:
The Senate passed legislation today requiring the government to pay the overwhelming majority of financial losses in a major terrorist attack, though the measure takes a markedly different approach from one approved by the House.
 The Senate measure, approved 84 to 14, provides for the government to pay 80 percent of losses resulting from a terrorist attack up to $10 billion -- after insurers have absorbed a portion of the losses based on their share of the market -- and 90 percent of all losses after that. In contrast to the Senate bill, the House measure on terrorism insurance, adopted last fall, provides mainly for long-term low-interest loans to help insurers cope with claims from a major attack. 
 Despite the differences, both Republicans and Democrats in the Senate said they expected to reach a compromise with the House and come up with a bill that President Bush would sign. 
"The president wants this very badly," said Senator Harry Reid, the majority whip from Nevada. "We want it. The House wants it. It's ripe for compromise."
Senator Trent Lott, the Republican minority leader from Mississippi, said that while he thought the bill had some shortcomings, "I think they can be worked out."
Faced with the difference in the Senate and House versions of the bill, some Republican aides suggested that a compromise was far from certain. "It's not impossible," one aide said. "But it's going to be hard."
Senators said they had become convinced that government intervention was necessary to ensure that terrorism coverage becomes widely available at affordable prices, thus eliminating what many of them said was an increasingly significant drag on an already sluggish economy. The bill provides government help for up to two years.
Insurers have contended that they could not offer blanket terrorism coverage without assurances from the government that their maximum losses would be limited. Under the Senate bill, insurers would be required to provide the coverage.
Despite the measure's strong support, some Republican leaders had said the measure was too generous to insurance companies and also opened the way for "predatory lawsuits" by victims of terrorism. 
The bill stalled in the Senate last December over restrictions on lawsuits by victims of terrorism. The Republicans, strongly backed by the White House, contend that neither the government nor businesses should be held legally responsible for damages caused by terrorists. The Democrats have agreed on limiting suits against the government. But they say that eliminating lawsuits against businesses diminishes their incentive to try to prevent attacks.
Until Sept. 11, terrorism insurance was provided as a part of most general commercial insurance policies. The insurers agreed to pay losses estimated at up to $50 billion in the attacks but immediately withdrew coverage for further strikes. 
Within a few weeks, though, some insurers began offering up to $25 million in coverage at several times the cost of an equivalent amount of general commercial insurance. 
Prices have fallen sharply since then, and brokers say up to $1 billion in coverage is available. But owners of skyscrapers in New York and other big cities say that the costs are still staggering and that they cannot obtain what they regard as full coverage against a terrorist attack.
The White House has been one of the strongest advocates of government intervention, along with lobbyists for the insurers, banks and real estate companies. The proponents have cited only a few examples of harm to the economy: construction projects being stalled or lenders trying to cancel loans or raise interest rates because of inadequate terrorism insurance. But they contend that the prospects for a crisis are increasing each month as more commercial policies come up for renewal.
It was clear today that the lawmakers preferred to err on the side of caution. Several senators suggested that the bill might change significantly in the give and take with the House and in their own chamber.
For example, responding, to criticism from Senator Phil Gramm, Republican of Texas, that the measure provided too much government money to insurers and failed to provide an incentive for them to take back responsibility from the government eventually, Senator Christopher Dodd of Connecticut suggested in an interview that the threshold for the government's payment of 90 percent of the losses in an attack might be raised to $15 billion from the proposed $10 billion.
As a result of an amendment by Senator Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, the bill provides for the government to intervene on behalf of individual companies when their losses in an attack exceed a percentage of the $10 billion, based on their market share.
For some companies, Mr. Gramm said in the debate, that would mean the government's payments would start after losses of tens of millions of dollars rather than billions. "The taxpayer is exposed very, very early in the process," Mr. Gramm said.
By raising the threshold to $15 billion, the losses based on market share would also rise, Mr. Dodd said.
"The caps are going to have to be higher," Mr. Lott said.

HEADLINE: SENATE COMMITTEE APPROVES MEASURE ON AUDIT INDUSTRY 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD A. OPPEL Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 18 

 BODY:
Overcoming fierce lobbying by the accounting industry, the Senate Banking Committee approved legislation today that would ban accounting firms from selling many forms of consulting services to their audit clients, limit the time an individual partner could review one company's books and create a regulatory board made up mostly of people outside the industry.
 The measure, a response to the collapse of Enron and to accounting scandals in other industries, was approved 17 to 4 in committee. But despite that unexpected level of support, its fate remains unclear. Assuming it is passed by the Senate, the legislation will go to a conference committee to be reconciled with a substantially different proposal, already passed by the House, that is favored by the accounting industry. 
 "We still have to go to conference so there are plenty of hurdles ahead, and I don't think there ought to be any element of overconfidence that we will get this process to completion," Senator Jon S. Corzine, Democrat of New Jersey and a former co-chief executive of Goldman Sachs, said in an interview. "We will have to work very hard to do that." 
Consumer groups and many of the lawmakers who backed the measure said the bill would go the furthest toward preventing future financial meltdowns. The proposal is the only legislation that would help end the "systemic problems in the accounting profession involving conflicts of interest and lax oversight," Consumers Union said today. "This bill would definitely fix some of the accounting problems that we've seen crop up in the daily news over the last six months."
If no measure makes it out of Congress, there may still be change coming. The Securities and Exchange Commission is already working on its own proposal for an accounting oversight board. Like the bill in the Senate, the proposal by the S.E.C. would require the board to have a majority of members who are not current or former accountants.
Also, the members of the board with accounting backgrounds would not play a role in determining disciplinary actions or sanctions against firms. The S.E.C. plan would also force publicly traded companies to comply with any review or proceeding undertaken by the board.
The Senate bill approved in committee makes some concessions to the accounting industry. But it keeps many provisions that just a month ago had engendered such a furious reaction from lobbyists that its sponsor, Senator Paul S. Sarbanes, Democrat of Maryland and chairman of the committee, had to postpone a vote on the measure for fear that it might be defeated. 
But three days after the guilty verdict in the obstruction of justice trial of the accounting firm Arthur Andersen, the committee passed the bill, with 6 Republicans and all 11 Democrats voting for it. Four Republicans voted no: Rick Santorum of Pennsylvania, Michael D. Crapo of Idaho, John Ensign of Nevada and the former committee chairman, Phil Gramm of Texas, who had led efforts to defeat the measure.
The wide vote came after a deal on Monday night by Mr. Sarbanes and Senator Michael B. Enzi, a Wyoming Republican who is an accountant, that gave ground to the industry in some areas but kept the most significant parts of the bill. In addition to the regulatory board and the ban on many forms of consulting, the bill also requires that every five years, publicly traded companies change the individual lead audit partners who review their books.
It also prohibits investment firms from retaliating against research analysts who write negative reports on the firm's clients. And it forbids investment bankers to supervise research analysts or clear their reports.
The deal by Mr. Enzi and Mr. Sarbanes added provisions ensuring that two of the five members of the regulatory board have accounting backgrounds and also that disciplinary proceedings by the regulatory board be kept confidential unless the parties agree otherwise. 
While the bill specifically prohibits accounting firms from selling eight types of consulting and other services to publicly traded companies that they audit, the legislation does allow auditors to provide certain tax services and other services -- so long as the company's audit committee approves the arrangement in advance. 
Under the Enzi-Sarbanes deal, minor services that require prior approval but are initially overlooked can be retroactively approved by the audit committee -- as long as they account for no more than 5 percent of the auditors' fees.
Some lawmakers said the continuing discovery of accounting problems at large corporations, and the flight of some foreign investors from the United States, had helped create more support for the measure. Speaking to reporters after the vote, Mr. Sarbanes also suggested that the fierce lobbying efforts by the accountants had backfired and cost the industry some credibility. 
"Some of the lobbying was really over the top -- scare stuff," Mr. Sarbanes said. He also credited comments recently from some leading figures in finance, especially a speech by Henry M. Paulson Jr., chief executive of Goldman Sachs, who criticized American corporations and said that to avoid the appearance of a conflict, companies should not buy consulting services from the same accountants that audit their books.
Before the vote, Mr. Gramm offered a competing proposal that was defeated. It would have created a regulatory board with a higher portion of members with accounting backgrounds and would have let the board resolve on its own some issues explicitly addressed in the Sarbanes bill.
In an interview tonight, Mr. Gramm said that while the bill had improved somewhat, its fundamental thrust had not changed, and he was not sure why support for the measure increased so quickly. Mr. Gramm said it would have been smarter policy to give the new board more leeway and not legislate so many specific rules.
"This is one of those things people want to be on record as being for," Mr. Gramm said, adding that he hoped that the bill could be amended when it reached the Senate floor. If not, he said, there is little chance it will make it out of conference committee in its current form. "There's no doubt," he added, that the final bill will be different.
The current atmosphere in Congress, Mr. Gramm said, "is a little bit of the environment of 'let's just go out and beat up a bunch of accountants, that way we're tough on accountants'; that's not what I'm looking for."
The accounting industry's main lobbying group, the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants, said this afternoon that both the Sarbanes bill and the S.E.C.'s proposal raised concerns about how the industry would be regulated.
Both create "uncertainties about whether auditing professionals will continue to remain actively engaged in setting auditing standards and that auditors will have sufficient latitude to respond to the needs of both investors and public companies," the organization said. 
Mr. Enzi, who said he had been meeting frequently with accounting representatives, said the industry was still concerned, among other things, about being protected from what he characterized as frivolous lawsuits. "I'm not sure anybody on any side of this issue likes" all the Sarbanes bill, Mr. Enzi said.
Lawmakers today did not try to amend the bill with a provision that would derail investigations into the securities industry by officials in various states, including Eliot L. Spitzer, the attorney general of New York. An official close to the industry, however, said that Wall Street firms hoped to raise the issue when the bill arrived in conference committee, where they believe Republicans from the House will have some sympathy for the initiative.
This evening, an aide to Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the Senate majority leader, said the accounting bill would most likely be brought up on the Senate floor in September, after Congress returns from a monthlong recess. Mr. Daschle would usually bring up the bill much sooner, the aide said, but he remained focused on legislation to create a new department and other antiterrorism measures.
