HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Senate Panel Approves Strict Accounting Measure
The Senate Banking Committee has approved accounting legislation that would impose tough measures to limit the lucrative consulting that accounting firms can do on companies they audit and would put the industry under a regulatory board composed mostly of people outside the industry.
 Despite a 17-to-4 vote in committee, the bill's fate remains unclear. Assuming the measure passes the Senate, it will go to a conference committee so it can be reconciled with the House bill, which is favored by the accounting industry. If the bill dies, the Securities and Exchange Commission is working on its own proposal for an oversight board. Page A1. 

A Change Sought for Prilosec
Procter & Gamble is expected to ask a regulatory panel to approve sales without a prescription of AstraZeneca's Prilosec. Manufacturers are shifting to over-the-counter sales because of competition from generic copies. C2.

Republicans have begun to push their prescription drug bill through the House. Democrats, and many of their allies, are intent on portraying the bill as a cynical exercise in political self-protection. A20.

Income Falls for Lehman Brothers
Lehman Brothers Holdings reported that its second-quarter net income fell 31 percent as a decline in merger advisory work and stock underwriting more than offset strength in bond operations. It was the fifth decline in the last six quarters for the firm. Analysts said that other investment firms were likely to post similar results. Market Place. C2.

Profit Declines 23% at Oracle
Oracle posted fourth-quarter net income of $655.9 million, down 23 percent from $854.9 million in the period a year earlier. C4.

Executive Promoted at Citigroup
Citigroup has named Stanley Fischer as president of Citigroup International, a new unit that will include the company's emerging markets business. C4.

Disclosures for Martha Stewart
Trying to resolve questions about her sale of ImClone shares in December, Martha Stewart has hired a new lawyer and has submitted several documents to investigators. C7.

Diversity for Agnelli Family at Fiat
Fiat has always been considered the fief of the Agnelli family. A decade ago, Fiat represented 80 percent of the Agnellis' investments. But the family has been diversifying, and today, Fiat is less than half of the family's investments. World Business, Section W.

Stephanopoulos Selected as Anchor
As expected, ABC has named George Stephanopoulos as the sole anchor of the public affairs program "This Week." He is expected to receive $1 million a year for at least three years. For Mr. Stephanopoulos, the hard part of the job may be assuring Republicans and White House officials that his days as an operative for Bill Clinton are behind him. C6

French Company Buys British Unit
American Electric Power plans to sell its Seeboard power utility in Britain to the state-owned Electricite de France for $975 million and the assumption of $1.05 billion in debt. World Business, Section W.

Housing Construction Increases
Home construction grew 11.6 percent in May, increasing at the fastest rate in nearly seven years. Consumer prices, a measure of inflation, were unchanged last month. C2.

The Dow Jones industrial average rose 18.70 points, to 9,706.12. The Standard & Poor's 500 inched up 0.97 points, at 1,037.14, and the Nasdaq declined 10.33 points, to 1,542.96. C9.

Downtown Loses Out to Its Fringe
The core of downtown Columbus, Ohio, is struggling, even as vibrant development grows right on its fringes and pulls business away. Commercial Real Estate. C8.

HEADLINE: CURRENTS: DESIGN; 
In a NoHo Penthouse, Economy of Function on a Grand Scale

BYLINE:  By ELAINE LOUIE 

 BODY:
"Everything had to move and retract," Suzan Wines said of a 3,000-square-foot, two-story penthouse she and Azin Valy, her partner at I-Beam Design, created in NoHo. The penthouse, a loft intended to be playfully minimalist, was for Ted Petroulas, a founding partner in the Clinton Group, an asset management firm in lower Manhattan; his wife, Nasim Alikhani; and their 7-year-old twins. Nothing -- kitchen cabinet, bathroom sink, or bathroom window -- wound up with only one function, if it could have two or three. 
 The stainless-steel steps, left, that lead from the kitchen to the children's playroom, are part staircase, part storage, part countertop -- and can be moved around. "They use the steps to reach high, upper cabinets," Ms. Wines said. The master bedroom has a sink behind the headboard and retractable mirrors that pop up at the push of a button. In the master bathroom, an aquarium window facing a corridor uses electric current to change a liquid crystal film inserted between two panes of laminated glass from dark to clear. "When you turn the power off, it goes almost opaque," Ms. Wines said. 
 In the guest bathroom, the secret lies in the glass counter, which extends through a slit in the corridor wall and acts like an "occupied" sign. "If you turn on the light in the bathroom," Ms. Wines said, "it illuminates at the edge and indicates someone is in there." The children's bathroom vanity, above left, is made of fluorescent-colored acrylic in orange, yellow and blue, and is illuminated from within, so it acts like a multicolored night light.
In the living room, a mahogany mantelpiece, above, wraps around the slate hearth and hides storage cabinets for CD's and tapes. A low cabinet has drawers to store Ms. Alikhani's antique jewelry and textiles and the couple's collection of ornamental metalwork. The total cost was $500,000. I-Beam, (212) 244-7596. ELAINE LOUIE

HEADLINE: Gucci Posts 42% Decline In Net Income 

BYLINE:  By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: PARIS, June 19 

 BODY:
Dragged down by the painfully slow recovery of the global economy, Gucci said today that its income in the first fiscal quarter -- February to April -- slumped 42 percent.
 The only bright light in its otherwise grim results was a 63 percent revenue increase at Yves Saint Laurent, the fashion and perfume business that the Gucci Group bought for $1 billion in 1999 and has been painstakingly rebuilding. 
 Analysts said the news shed little new light on a possible revival of the luxury goods market, which investors have been watching intently, particularly in light of plans by two big European fashion houses, Prada of Italy and Burberry of Britain, to sell shares this summer in initial stock offerings.
Gucci said that first-quarter net income fell 42 percent, to 35.5 million euros ($34 million), or 0.35 euro a share, from 61.4 million euros, or 0.61 euro, last year. Revenue fell 1.5 percent, to 607.6 million euros. 
The chief executive of Gucci, Domenico de Sole, said that sales in destinations that rely on tourists from East Asia, notably Japan, were weak. Revenue from retail sales in the United States fell 26 percent in the quarter, he said. Mr. De Sole said he expected the difficulties to continue through the rest of the first half. He said he hoped for a rebound in the second half of the year.
Dorothy Lakner, an analyst at CIBC World Markets, said Gucci's results were no surprise. "I don't know that it changes much," she said of the decline.
Investors appeared to agree, bidding up Gucci's shares at one point by as much as 1.5 percent, largely because of the positive results at Saint Laurent.
In April, the market leader, LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton, reported sluggish sales in the first quarter; earlier this month, Richemont of Switzerland, which is second to LVMH, said revenues from retail sales remained flat in April and May.
Despite the slump, Great Universal Stores, which controls Burberry, said in May that it planned an initial stock offering by mid-July. Earlier, Prada announced it would offer shares on the Milan stock exchange by the end of summer, after canceling two previous offerings. Both companies are betting that a recovery in luxury goods after the Sept. 11 attacks will attract investors, despite the shakiness of global stock markets. Neither company would comment today, citing regulatory restrictions.
Anne-Catherine Galetic of Schroder Salomon Smith Barney noted that shares in groups like LVMH and Richemont dropped 10 percent to 15 percent in the last several weeks. For Prada and Burberry that meant, she said, that, "some investors are not going to be willing to pay multiples of one month ago, when the whole market is penalizing the sector."
The sole bright spot in the Gucci report was Saint Laurent, apparently buoyed by successes like the deer-bone-handled Mombasa bag, a hot item in the United States, where it sells for more than $700, and by the spring and summer selections of Tom Ford, the Gucci star who designs for Saint Laurent.
"They've done a very strong job in a very short time in a very difficult environment," said Armando Branchini, president of InterCorporate, a Milan fashion consulting company. He added that he considers Gucci's overall results "quite good for a year that's not been so good."
Mr. De Sole said there had been no sign as yet in the three months to April of a revival of retail sales at destinations, like Hawaii and Las Vegas, that are favored by Japanese tourists, who are heavy purchasers of luxury items.
Mr. Branchini said that "for the first time ever, the condition of the general economy is strongly influencing luxury goods." He said that was because as luxury goods conglomerates broadened their customer base in recent years from the particularly well-heeled to average consumers who occasionally indulge their taste for luxury brands, they have made themselves vulnerable to factors like the travel market.

HEADLINE: AT HOME WITH: Mark McDonald; 
Mr. Modernism Leaves Town

BYLINE:  By DAVID COLMAN 

 BODY:
ARE you just starting to explore midcentury style? Seduced by magazine spreads of plate-glass-walled bungalows in Palm Springs, Calif.? Browsing on eBay, perhaps, for the groovy molded plywood work of the famous Eames brothers, Charles and Ray?
 If so, Mark McDonald wants nothing to do with you -- or anyone else who still needs to be told that Ray was Charles Eames's wife, not his brother. 
 Not that Mr. McDonald ever suffered amateurs gladly. For 20 years, he has sold some of the most exalted pieces of midcentury modern design ever to come up for private sale (a lot of it at exalted prices). Along the way, he straightened out plenty of neophytes and dabblers and answered thousands of questions -- usually dispensing about four times as much information as the asker anticipated. 
Now, two decades after opening his influential first gallery, Fifty/50, this walking, talking 20th-century-design database is going off line -- to the great disappointment of collectors and connoisseurs, for whom he was an invaluable storehouse of both objets d'art and encyclopedic knowledge about them.
"I'm gone, and they won't be able to ask me!" Mr. McDonald said with a triumphant whoop colored by his faint Texas lilt as he shut down Fifty/50's successor, the Gansevoort Gallery, for the night a couple of weeks ago.
At the end of the month, Mr. McDonald, 51, will permanently close his gallery, which he opened seven years ago on a forlorn (now fashionable) stretch of Gansevoort Street in the meatpacking district.
"I have to cut the cord," he said while sipping coffee recently at his home in Germantown, N.Y., a small, bright, two-story house perched on the side of a gully over a creek's churning rapids. Having opened a small gallery, 330, in nearby Hudson in November, Mr. McDonald said he plans to spend less time in his small Manhattan apartment and more at his new base of operations.
The design world may be sorry to see him retreat, but many colleagues are not surprised. High-end shops that specialize in midcentury furnishings are falling victim to a sluggish economy; others have been wounded by competition from Internet sales and encroaching auction houses.
The race to find the best mid-mod design has become fierce. Form and Function, a midcentury design store in SoHo, closed three months ago.
Troy Halterman, owner of Troy, another high-end SoHo design emporium, said he was steadily phasing out midcentury pieces in favor of new design.
"It's just gotten too difficult to find interesting vintage pieces," Mr. Halterman said, "and I've been finding young designers more stimulating, which didn't use to be the case."
Mr. McDonald may have been the only game in Eamestown 20 years ago, and he still ranks as one of the country's leading dealers of modernist design, but there is now an onrushing pack of young dealers, like Evan Lobel of Lobel Modern in Chelsea, or Kim Hostler and Juliet Burrows of Antik in TriBeCa, who are willing to hustle for inventory.
"I just don't have the 24-hour energy it takes to keep a retail business going in Manhattan," Mr. McDonald said with a trace of melancholy.
"I really do feel that that era is over when you can assemble a great collection without spending a fortune. Today, it would cost probably 10 times as much as it did 10 years ago." (Gansevoort Gallery's remaining inventory will be sold at 330.)
Determined to go out on a high note, Mr. McDonald has mounted an exhibition called "Highlights: Collecting Modern 1982-2002." Open through the end of the month, the show includes more than 125 of the most rarefied and exemplary pieces of modern design Mr. McDonald has sold since he and two partners opened Fifty/50 in 1983.
The show includes silver jewelry by Alexander Calder and Harry Bertoia; furniture by Gio Ponti, Gilbert Rohde, Donald Deskey and Frank Gehry; ceramics by Stig Lindberg, Berndt Friberg and Axel Salto; glass by Venini, Barovier & Toso, Carlo Scarpa and Bianconi; desk clocks by George Nelson -- all of it borrowed back for the month from his customers. Together they amount to an impressive illustration of the broad and crucial role Mr. McDonald has played in the cult of modernism that has grown up around him.
Even today, serious collectors and design purists credit Fifty/50's trinity of owners -- Mr. McDonald, Mark Isaacson and Ralph Cutler -- with blazing the trail. "They invented the whole thing," said the architect Lee Mindel, an early customer. "Now midcentury is today's Chippendale."
A nearly instant success, Fifty/50 fired interest in the look that would later become known and fetishized as "midcentury modern." It was also a crucial Saturday-afternoon stop on the art-world itinerary; frequent customers included Robert Mapplethorpe, Francesco Clemente and Julian Schnabel.
Terence Riley, the chief curator of architecture at the Museum of Modern Art in New York, was a practicing architect when Fifty/50 opened at the height of postmodernism. He remembers its opposition to that reigning style as having a subversive edge -- the design world's answer to a speak-easy.
"Going to Fifty/50 was like belonging to a secret club where you didn't have to pretend you didn't like this stuff," he said. "By reinventing a love for modern furniture, which was less threatening to people than the architecture, they paved the way for the demise of postmodernism."
While many a serious design collection started with something bought out of Fifty/50's window, many a design connoisseur was educated in the store's back room, which was lined with an enormous library of design reference books that even today Mr. McDonald calls his biggest and most serious investment.
"It was one thing to buy something from the store, but the thing was to get invited into the back to talk and look through the books," recalled Murray Moss, the owner of the popular design store Moss in SoHo, who was then the owner of a fashion company.
But the modernist past shone brighter at Fifty/50 than its future. Mr. Cutler, who was Mr. McDonald's personal as well as professional partner for 13 years, died of AIDS in 1989. Mr. Isaacson died of the disease in August 1993; Mr. McDonald closed the store within a month.
Mr. McDonald said that he has been H.I.V.-positive himself since 1985, staying healthy in recent years with protease inhibitors. But while his business life was turned upside down by the deaths of his partners, Mr. McDonald felt his loss most acutely when visiting the Germantown house.
"When we bought the house in 1980, there was really no one else we knew up here," he recalled. Then a gay couple with whom they were friendly bought a place nearby; then another couple did the same, and another, and another.
"There were 10 of us up here, five couples," he said. "Every single one of those people died. I had no friends here. No one was left."
As a result, he said, the country house and its grounds, which had been Mr. Cutler's project, came to seem almost unbearably bleak.
But as the 1990's wore on, Hudson's emergence as an antiquing destination brought new friends to the area. After he closed Fifty/50, Mr. McDonald, a contractor's son who grew up doing carpentry as a hobby, threw himself into gardening, picking up where Mr. Cutler had left off years earlier. Today, every square inch of ground, just under an acre, is painstakingly planted and landscaped, overflowing this month with irises, poppies, clematis and allium -- no small feat, considering that a good part of the lot tumbles down a cliff, and that when he and Mr. Cutler first happened upon the place, he said, "there was nothing but trees and poison ivy."
Gardening might seem to clash with Mr. McDonald's obsession with midcentury design, much of which has a cosmopolitan, machine-made edge. But it is the organic and crafted aspect of modernism that he has always favored.
One case in the Germantown house is crowded with Scandinavian pottery by Stig Lindberg; a nearby shelf is covered with Japanese bronze vases. Other rooms contain a mix of Arts and Crafts furniture from the early 20th century, 1950's and 60's ceramics, and personal, idiosyncratic mementos from travels. Much of the artwork is by friends like William Wegman and Lynn Davis. Many things in the house are of anonymous design but captivated Mr. McDonald with their modernist feel, like the stained-glass window and the brightly colored geometric-pattern Danish wool blankets that adorn the beds in the two bedrooms.
"His interest in midcentury stems from that craftsman, hands-on quality that most people don't identify with the period," said Thad Hayes, an interior designer and longtime customer.
"Of the pottery he gets," Mr. Hayes continued, "what he keeps for himself are the things that are very tactile, with beautiful glazes, with an almost Woodstock-hippie Arts and Crafts edge."
Mr. McDonald has always tried to find pieces that have not been restored but are in nearly their original condition, a reflection of his uncompromising, sometimes obdurate, attitude about the purity of what he sells. Likewise, he has limited patience for midcentury amateurs who complain that his rarefied inventory is too expensive, and even less with the clueless newcomers who want information about those Eames brothers. Mr. McDonald has come to see himself as a kind of custodian for modernism, and on this subject his sense of humor evaporates.
So if he spends more time upstate and less time dealing with the business of modernism, his views on the sanctity of the subject aren't going anywhere.
"Mark's modernism is the modernism of an existence -- he does have a mission, with a high moral tone," said Mitchell Wolfson, the noted design collector who created the Wolfsonian design museum in Miami Beach with Mr. McDonald's help. "He has a missionary's zeal which is very focused."
And none of that will change just because Gansevoort is closing, Mr. Wolfson said. "When you're the head of a church, you know who your congregation is. He doesn't need new converts."

Country Decor With a Bit of an Edge
MARK McDONALD'S new store, 330, in the relaxed town of Hudson, N.Y., will have a looser mix than he offered in his New York shops, although his current inventory includes pieces from Fifty/50 and Gansevoort Gallery. "I want to be a little bit broader," he said. "I'd like to have some slightly funky things that don't necessarily have a designer's name attached to them. And vases you can use, that aren't just museum-quality collectibles. I want it to be more country friendly, and slightly more affordable."
The store offers an unsigned stainless-steel serving cart from the 1950's for $700, and anonymous American and Finnish rugs from $400 to $4,500. For the devout modernist's front porch, there is even an Eames rocking chair. People looking for Mr. McDonald's brand of connoisseurship can be satisfied too. There is a Donald Deskey table for $22,000 and an Aalto table from a Harvard library for $25,000. 
The store will also be a bookstore of sorts, carrying a wide range of new titles on design, fashion and photography. And in the back room, Mr. McDonald sells a large selection of out-of-print and rare design books -- in homage to the famed office of Fifty/50, where many design aficionados first perused the owners' library. The store, at 330 Warren Street, is open Fridays through Mondays from noon to 5 p.m., or by appointment; (518) 828-6320.

HEADLINE: Goldman Profits in Sale of Korean Bank Stake 

BYLINE:  By DON KIRK 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, June 19 

 BODY:
In a long-awaited move for maximum profit from one of the largest foreign investments in the Korean economy, Goldman Sachs sold about 60 percent of its stake in the Kookmin Bank for $633.6 million today.
 The sale of 13.2 million shares in Kookmin, by far Korea's largest bank, netted Goldman Sachs three times the price that it paid for the shares when it invested in the bank three years ago. 
 Goldman sold the shares, valued at 59,200 won apiece on the Korean Stock Exchange, for $48 each in exchange for American depository receipts eligible for listing on the New York Stock Exchange. 
Officials at Kookmin, who are in the process of modernizing and overhauling the bank after merging it with the Housing and Commercial Bank last November, denied that Goldman's sale of shares reflected any lack of confidence in the bank's future.
"Goldman had been planning the sale for a year," said Donald MacKenzie, executive vice president for risk management at Kookmin. "Goldman was here for financial purposes," he added. "There's nothing here that concerns me."
If there was any surprise, it was the size of the sale. Goldman had originally planned to sell about 11 million shares, half the 6.82 percent stake that it bought in 1999, but wound up with 2.66 percent of the bank's shares after selling 4.16 percent of the total shares in the bank.
Goldman sold the shares with the strong support of Kim Jung Tae, the bank president, who came to Kookmin from the Housing and Commercial Bank with the mission to get tough on risky loans to corporations while greatly expanding the bank's retail loan business. Mr. Kim, the former chief of a securities firm, returned today from a trip with Goldman executives to help promote the sale.
Underlining the success of the sale -- and of the bank -- was that stock in Kookmin rose 1 percent, closing today at 60,700 won ($49.67) on the Korean Stock Exchange, while the market over all fell 4.1 percent, to 776.37, down 33.03 points, the largest daily drop in nearly eight weeks.
The broad market downturn came after news that the United States Justice Department was investigating Micron Technology on suspicion of collaborating with other manufacturers -- including two Korean companies, Samsung Electronics and Hynix Semiconductor -- to fix the price of memory chips.
As for the Goldman sale, Mr. MacKenzie said, "Goldman wanted to sell, and there were buyers." The sale of more shares than anticipated, he said, showed the popularity of the stock.
"It wasn't a distress sale," he added.
Mr. MacKenzie, who came from the ING Group of the Netherlands to work on bringing Kookmin to the level of banks in the United States and Europe in technology and efficiency, compared Goldman's motive for investing in the bank with that of ING, which owns a 4 percent stake.
"ING is here for the long run," he said. "It's a strategic investment." The Dutch bank, he added, may increase the size of its investment.

HEADLINE: ...In Manhattan, A Lust for Large 

BYLINE:  By TRACIE ROZHON 

 BODY:
LIKE their suburban brethren, New Yorkers have been struck by the urge for big, with sales of larger apartments surging, even as prices continue to rise.
 The average apartment sold in Manhattan since May 1, whether a condo loft in TriBeCa or a three-bedroom on Park Avenue, is 21.4 percent more expensive than before Sept. 11, said Jonathan Miller, president of Miller Samuel, an appraisal firm that handles 4,000 appraisals a year. 
 The rise in cost is largely a function of square footage. The average apartment sold from May 1 through June 18 is a lot bigger than in the month before the terrorist attacks: 1,263 square feet versus 1,101 square feet in August 2001. At the same time, the price per square foot has been edging upward, confounding those who last fall predicted a dive in real estate. 
"The recovery is now across the board; our sales of apartments over $5 million are up 300 percent," said Paul Purcell, president of Insignia Douglas Elliman, the city's largest real estate company.
Mr. Purcell said the company sold three grand apartments -- co-ops and condos -- in April and 11 in May. 
"We sold them to families and to foreign investors," he said. Such mega-sales took place at 845 United Nations Plaza, 65 Crosby Street in SoHo, 920 Fifth Avenue, 1185 Park Avenue and 1965 Broadway, among other addresses, he said. Scott Durkin, chief operating officer at the Corcoran Group, a large Manhattan broker, said that "people are trading up to bigger apartments." He said brokers were seeing a sudden release of cash after a pent-up urge to buy. "They've been keeping their money under the mattress for quite a while because the stock market is so volatile, and gradually they're spending it," he said.
Hall Willkie, president of Brown Harris Stevens, which specializes in higher-end real estate, said that although the general residential market has been "hot, hot, hot" since January, the hottest properties had been the smaller apartments: those under $1 million. That changed, he said, at the beginning of May.
Since then, he said, the biggest, most expensive apartments -- particularly those over $7 million, the firm's bread and butter -- have found buyers.
"In May, we sold more units than ever before, including some from the highest end," Mr. Willkie said.
In this steamy market, buyers are finding it difficult to find a bargain, even if they're looking for a studio or a one-bedroom. Taken by the square foot, the cost of an apartment in Manhattan is higher than it was just before Sept. 11. Miller Samuel said the properties it has appraised have shown a rise in the sale price per square foot from $728 in August to $770 now, or almost 6 percent.
"People forget that the market was already dipping before the World Trade Center attacks," said Mr. Miller, whose statistics measure his company's appraisals from Battery Park City to 116th Street on the West Side and 96th Street on the East Side. 
"In August of last year," he said, "the market was slowly eroding. We were seeing a drop in volume and a modest drop in prices, attributable to the recession gaining momentum."
Since January, the market has rebounded, he said, "not unlike most real estate markets in the country."
When viewed through a slightly longer lens, the recovery is even clearer.
Compared with the May 1-June 18 period a year ago, the average sale price of a Manhattan apartment has risen 9.8 percent, from $885,911 to $972,807. The square-foot price has gone up, too, from $669 to $770, a whopping 15.2 percent, according to Miller Samuel.
After a dismal season due to the economy and post-Sept. 11 shock, things started to move in January.
"January was psychologically important," Mr. Willkie said. "It was like a hurdle, like a birthday. People had been waiting to buy, and they decided they couldn't delay it any more."
Because of the rise in prices, New Yorkers have started seeking innovative ways to get the most square feet for their dollar. Some are looking for apartments that need work. Diane Ramirez, president of the Halstead Property Company, said some were also trying to obtain the studios or one-bedrooms next door to their apartments or in the same building rather than hunt -- and pay for -- a bigger apartment elsewhere. Others, when buying anew, start off looking for two adjacent apartments they can combine.
If a building's rules allow it, buyers of adjacent apartments may decide to rent one out while they build up their stock portfolios, or just take their time fixing them up. By buying now, they can take advantage of the low mortgage interest rates (some of the lowest in 40 years).
"Buyers are getting more creative, trying to find the biggest apartments, at the lowest prices," Ms. Ramirez said. 
In all this real estate giddiness, there is one contradictory note.
Frederick W. Peters, president of Ashforth Warburg, says that in the last two weeks his brokers have noticed a chill. "There are fewer people coming to the open houses," he said. "One broker had 10 people last week, and she got over 30 for an apartment in the same line a month ago." This perceived leveling off of the market has not yet shown up in statistics.
Ms. Ramirez has also noticed it, but attributes it to a normal June. "The kids are out of school, packing off to camp; everybody's taken a breather," she said. There has not been this kind of breather in the last two or three Junes, she said, but they occurred for decades before then.
"Since January, the market has been too hot," she said. "It's been a tough market for buyers, and now they're taking a breather. They'll be back in the fall."

HEADLINE: The Enforcers Of Wall St.? Then Again, Maybe Not 

BYLINE:  By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
Owen Cheevers, 51, was head of high-yield bond research at the Bank of Montreal in New York when he wrote a cautionary report on companies in the radio industry. An experienced analyst, Mr. Cheevers was asked by investment bankers at his firm to make his report more glowing. He refused and pleaded with the bank's compliance department to intervene. He received no help. Two months later he was fired. 
 Joseph M. Mulder, 59, was a brokerage firm auditor with decades of experience, including identifying two money launderers who later went to prison. But soon after Mr. Mulder alerted his superiors to what he said were serious violations by a broker at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, Mr. Mulder was fired. More than a decade later, the broker in question was accused by regulators of stealing $3.2 million from clients. 
 It has become a well-worn refrain after scandals at Enron and other companies that if people want to deceive accountants, employees or shareholders, it is awfully hard to stop them. But even though both the institutions involved deny wrongdoing in the terminations, the stories of these two men, although very different, raise an even more troubling proposition: What if the people who want to do the right thing can get no support, especially from executives hired to make sure regulations are followed? What if people like these are in fact punished for speaking out? 
Federal regulators are asking such questions as they undertake a series of examinations of brokerage firm compliance departments. After several prominent cases in which illegal activities of brokers slid past compliance departments, the Securities and Exchange Commission is scrutinizing compliance at firms from the top down, not the bottom up, as has been its custom. 
The new focus comes not a moment too soon. Investors' faith in the financial markets has been shaken by failures in safeguards intended to protect the public. As a self-regulated industry, the brokerage business employs cops inside its walls as a first line of defense for investors. But regulators and investors are wondering if those cops are encouraged to identify wrongdoing by an individual or group that produces significant revenues. 
"If you are a revenue producer or your importance to revenue production exceeds that of the compliance component that is dealing with you, it's very likely that compliance is going to be secondary," said Jeffrey L. Liddle, a lawyer at Liddle & Robinson in New York, who often represents brokerage employees in wrongful termination cases and who represents Mr. Cheevers. 
Compliance professionals on Wall Street number about 150,000, according to the National Association of Securities Dealers. These people are charged with scrutinizing the activities of 650,000 securities representatives in 90,000 branch offices at 5,500 firms.
An especially embarrassing breakdown came to light earlier this year when Frank D. Gruttadauria, a branch manager and producing broker at Lehman Brothers in Cleveland, was sued by the S.E.C., which accused him of stealing more than $40 million from 50 clients over six years. 
But equally disturbing is that compliance executives at major firms under investigation for conflicts of interest were apparently unable or unwilling to prevent investment banking executives, eager to drum up new offerings with upbeat research reports, from interfering with analysts.
Industry guidelines say firms "should emphasize the high value of their reputation and interest in contributing to enhanced investor protection and the integrity of the securities industry."
"Therefore," the guidelines continue, "they should be committed to high standards of conduct and to support the positive and unique role served by those at the firm whose responsibilities are related to compliance or legal functions."
Brokerage firms must have a system of supervision "reasonably designed to prevent and detect violations by their employees." If they do not, executives can face action from the New York Stock Exchange, the N.A.S.D. or the S.E.C. for a "failure to supervise."
Dan Scotto, a bond analyst at BNP Paribas Securities in New York, was fired late last year after writing a negative report on Enron bonds in August 2001, just as the company began to unravel. Mr. Scotto, who had been an analyst for 25 years, said he had seen a deterioration in compliance in recent years.
"Twenty years ago, firms worried more about their reputations," he said. "Research wasn't a sales job. But as the commission structure broke down, there was a shift in compliance departments to be more sensitive to the revenue side of things, or the 'deal' side of things. That accelerated in the '90's." 
A BNP Paribas spokeswoman said the bank's personal issues with Mr. Scotto "resulted from longstanding deficiencies in his performance as a manager and were unrelated to any research recommendations he made." 
Now that revenues and profits are down, regulators worry that compliance departments will come under even more pressure to look the other way when big producers stray. 
It was in just such an economic environment -- 1991 -- that Mr. Mulder was fired from Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, shortly after he told superiors that R. Christopher Hanna was routinely violating brokerage firm and New York Stock Exchange regulations intended to protect customers. Mr. Hanna, a big-producing broker, was left in place at the firm, which was later bought by Credit Suisse First Boston, and apparently continued to violate regulations. He was fired in May 2001, and in February, 12 years after Mr. Mulder identified his questionable practices, the S.E.C. sued Mr. Hanna, contending he stole $3.2 million from clients. That case is pending.
"If they had listened to my first report in September 1990, they would have stopped him right in his tracks," Mr. Mulder said. The firm's response struck him as "a willful blindness."
Mr. Mulder took his report to his supervisors, but nothing was done. Six months later, he was fired. He had worked for D.L.J. since 1978. Mr. Hanna remained at the firm.
The reason D.L.J. gave for the firing was that the firm was downsizing. But Mr. Mulder sued the firm and won $114,000. He never got another job on Wall Street.
A Credit Suisse First Boston spokeswoman said two arbitration panels rejected Mr. Mulder's claim that he was fired for making these allegations. "At the time these allegations were raised D.L.J. conducted an internal review and retained outside counsel to fully investigate this matter," she said. "After those internal reviews and external reviews were concluded, Mulder's allegations were found to be without any support." 
Mr. Hanna could not be reached for comment. 
Les Trager, a lawyer at Morley & Trager in New York, represented Mr. Mulder. He said his client had been let down not only by his firm, but also by the S.E.C., which he had told of Mr. Hanna's violations. 
An official at the S.E.C. declined to comment.
Although Mr. Cheevers declined to comment on his termination from Bank of Montreal, his wrongful termination case states his side of the story. According to the complaint and internal e-mail messages from the bank, Mr. Cheevers was asked by Michael Andres, an investment banker, to make an extensive report he had written in March 2001 on the radio industry "more bullish." Mr. Andres wrote: "We accomplish nothing marketing-wise by being negative about prospects for industry." He added: "Our research should have a stronger positive emphasis on medium-sized radio operators as these will ultimately be our high-yield clients."
According to his complaint, Mr. Cheevers declined to comply and complained to his boss, who did not respond, and to the bank's compliance department. In April, the bank's investment bankers killed Mr. Cheevers's report, and Robert Bade, head of United States compliance for the bank, asked Mr. Cheevers what happened. In an e-mail message, Mr. Bade wrote, "There may be some serious securities law considerations here." 
But by the next month, nothing had been done, and on June 7, 2001, Mr. Cheevers was terminated. The reason given, as in Mr. Mulder's case, was downsizing. But according to his complaint, Mr. Cheevers was the only person fired and a person who reported to him was given his job.
Gary D. Friedman, partner at Mayer, Brown, Rowe & Maw in New York City, represents Bank of Montreal in the matter. He said that Mr. Cheevers's allegations were thoroughly investigated by the company after his termination and found to be meritless. "Bank of Montreal Nesbitt Burns Corporation intends to defend against them vigorously," he said. 
Mr. Trager said one way to ensure that companies could not fire compliance employees for pointing out violations was to require the S.E.C. to interview every compliance professional who is fired. "If the guy is no good, then that's the end of it," Mr. Trager said. "But people should feel that Big Brother is watching them."
Mr. Scotto said that in his experience, compliance officers at most American firms try to do a good job keeping people in line. "Some firms made more of an effort, they had dedicated people who resided in a department," he said. "They can serve as the perfect shock absorber between the firm's interests and those of an individual analyst.
"But there again," he added, "who do they work for? They can't keep saying, 'There was a breach of the wall here and a breach of the wall there, let's scrap this deal.' They keep doing that often enough and they'll find themselves unemployed."

HEADLINE: 15 Are Accused of Defrauding Sept. 11 Charities 

BYLINE:  By SUSAN SAULNY 

 BODY:
In several cases, people who had been unemployed for weeks or months lied that they had lost work because of the attack on the World Trade Center, officials said yesterday. Others were still collecting their regular paychecks when they filed similarly false claims, investigators said. 
 At a news conference, the Manhattan district attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau, announced that 15 people had been charged in the latest wave of arrests in the investigation into theft from charities and government agencies that help people who suffered losses in the attack. 
 The charges, which include grand larceny and falsifying business records, among others, are felonies, and each defendant could face up to seven years in prison.
In total, Mr. Morgenthau alleged, 10 of the defendants, working independently, stole more than $52,000 from the Red Cross, the Salvation Army and the Federal Emergency Management Agency. The other five people arrested were caught before they received any funds, Mr. Morgenthau said.
The defendants were expected to be arraigned in Manhattan late last night or early this morning.
Among those arrested were four employees of the New York City Housing Authority.
Some of the claims resulted in immediate cash payments, while others were paid in the form of checks to landlords, officials said. 
While noting that the amount of money involved in each case was relatively small, given the millions of dollars paid out in relief since Sept. 11, Mr. Morgenthau said he wanted "to get the word out that if you defraud the government or charities, you'll be prosecuted."
The arrests announced yesterday bring to 91 the number of New York City defendants charged with financial schemes associated with the trade center attack. In one of the most audacious cases, a Michigan man was charged with claiming that his brother had died, and he was flown to New York and put up in a hotel by the Red Cross. Officials said he received more than $272,800 from Safe Horizon and the Red Cross days after submitting false affidavits to them. Officials later determined that no brother had existed. 
Mr. Morgenthau and Leroy Frazer, the bureau chief in the office of special prosecutions, said the fake claims likely slipped through because of the speed at which the agencies and charities distributed funds.

HEADLINE: Masses in Transit, to Anywhere but Work; 
Riders Like a Safer, More Reliable System, With MetroCard Discounts

BYLINE:  By RANDY KENNEDY 

 BODY:
It has been many years since the image of New York City's transit system was one of a crumbling and dangerous place used with grim determination only by those who had no better way to get to work.
 But a study of newly released transit data from the 2000 census has found a remarkable reversal: with the huge improvements to subway and bus service in the last decade and discounts introduced for riding it, mass transit is now used less frequently as a way to go to work than it is to go everywhere else in the city: shopping, eating, to the beach or to see your grandmother in the Bronx. 
 The trend is one that transit officials have long seen in their own statistics, with weekend ridership climbing rapidly in the last several years and many subway stations crammed even in the middle of the night. In the 1990's, that kind of growth helped push subway ridership up by 34 percent and bus ridership by 27 percent, and combined bus and subway weekday ridership topped seven million last year. 
But the census numbers show exactly how profound the shift has been in New Yorkers' perceptions about mass transit as a reliable and cheap way to go not just where they need to go but also where they want to go.
Bus and subway ridership for nonwork trips -- shopping, recreation and personal business -- increased by a surprising 62 percent in the 1990's, according to the analysis by Bruce Schaller, a consultant on urban transportation issues, who examined the census numbers, along with other transit statistics. By contrast, work-related trips on mass transit increased by 6.7 percent.
As a result of that divergence, work trips now account for less than half of all subway and bus trips, dropping to 44.1 percent in 2000 from 54.5 percent in 1990.
The shift helps explain why transit ridership has continued to increase in 2002 despite falling employment in New York City in the last year, Mr. Schaller said. 
But more significantly, it shows that the city seems to be in the midst of a return to the kind of relationship it had with mass transit several decades ago, before the Robert Moses era and the rise of the automobile.
"What has happened here is that the transit system has essentially been reincorporated back into people's life outside of work," Mr. Schaller said.
"You would have to look back to the 40's and 50's, I think, to find the last time it was like that." (In fact, he pointed out, the car was long such a minor player in city transportation that until 1950, it was illegal to park overnight in Manhattan.)
While the rebuilding of much of the subway system and the purchase of new trains and buses has made mass transit cleaner and more reliable, 
Mr. Schaller said that probably the strongest motivator moving people back to transit was the MetroCard, which was introduced in 1994 and began to offer discounts in 1998.
Now, according to New York City transit officials, 40 percent of MetroCard users buy one-day, 7-day or 30-day unlimited cards, which can reduce the price of their trips to significantly below the $1.50 fare if used frequently.
Mr. Schaller believes that the unlimited cards have transformed the mental calculations New Yorkers make when they think about mass transit, especially for discretionary trips.
"You don't think about a trip costing something in the way that you thought with a token," he said. "There's this sense of freedom now that you can hop on a bus to go just 10 blocks and you don't feel like you're getting ripped off."
Regional transit figures show that, five years ago, the frequency of trips of any kind -- by car or mass transit, even by foot -- were relatively low in the city compared with the suburbs, probably because of differences in the way suburbanites and city dwellers perceived the cost and ease of traveling.
If the tank had gas in it, a hop in the car for a quick spin to the suburban mall could feel as if it cost nothing. Driving was more difficult in the city, however, and subway and buses had a definite cost that, even though small, could discourage a whim to travel. The MetroCard, Mr. Schaller said, has changed that.
"The way you can look at it is that there was a kind of pent-up demand for travel in the city that's now able to express itself," he said.
That kind of expression, on subways and buses, has been considered a major public policy victory in New York, undoubtedly good for the environment and one that other cities are trying to emulate.
The downside is that, even though transit service has been increased significantly on the weekends and in off-peak hours in the last several years, it has yet to catch up with the demand in many parts of the system.
As Mr. Schaller put it, "It's always hard to find a seat on the subway during the rush, but now it can be hard to find one on Sunday mornings, literally."

HEADLINE: Economic Scene; 
Microsoft, ChickenDelight and competition for an imperfect world.

BYLINE:  By Virginia Postrel; Virginia Postrel is the author of "The Future and Its Enemies" and is writing a book on the increasing importance of aesthetics in the economy and society. E-mail: vpostrel@dynamist.com.

 BODY:
THE biggest antitrust case in recent years is drawing to a close. Yesterday in Washington, lawyers for Microsoft and the nine states pursuing antitrust action against it completed their final arguments. In addition to ruling in the states' case, Federal District Judge Colleen Kollar-Kotelly must decide whether to approve the settlement Microsoft reached in November with the Justice Department.
 The Microsoft case showcased recent economic scholarship on imperfect competition, which uses mathematical game theory to understand the strategies companies might pursue to gain advantage in markets that depart from the abstract notion of perfect competition. 
 In perfect competition, many indistinguishable and anonymous buyers and sellers trade a homogeneous good at the price at which supply matches demand. No buyer or seller can influence that price individually. 
While the perfect-competition model offers useful insights, away from the blackboard it is more the exception than the rule. It is not surprising that economists are interested in more complex and realistic arrangements. Hence the growth of theories of imperfect competition, in which companies' strategic choices affect market outcomes.
Under the right conditions, some theorists argue, it's possible to sustain and extend a monopoly that would break down under idealized competitive pressures. Often the way to do this would be for the monopolist to use exclusivity clauses or other "nonstandard" contract provisions.
This theory helped give intellectual impetus to the Clinton administration's antitrust activism, including the Microsoft case.
As economic theory, the work is sound. But if applied naively to antitrust policy, it "is likely to lead to poor legal rules and remedies," argues Paul L. Joskow, an M.I.T. economist, in The Journal of Law, Economics and Organization. He points to a different strand of economic research -- "transaction cost economics" -- that also needs to be taken into account.
This work begins with the insight, first made by Ronald H. Coase in a 1937 paper that would help win him the Nobel in economic science 54 years later, that making and enforcing contracts isn't cost free.
Professor Coase argued that reducing transaction costs helped explain why companies exist in the first place. Some exchanges might be easier and cheaper to manage if the parties are within the same organization.
In the 1970's, the economist Oliver Williamson began to develop this idea into a detailed program of research, with implications for antitrust policy as well as business management. Many economists have since done empirical and theoretical work on how organizational governance can lower contract costs.
Just because a contract is unusual or exclusive doesn't mean it hampers competition. The important question is whether competition existed before the contract. The unusual terms may provide a way to avoid enforcement problems.
Consider Chicken Delight, a franchise operation that was the subject of a 1971 antitrust case. Instead of collecting a percentage of store revenue, Chicken Delight required franchisees to buy all supplies from the parent company. From a transaction-cost perspective, this was an elegant solution to a basic problem: in a cash business, it is easy to lie about sales.
Supplies made a good proxy. If business was good, a store would need more supplies, and it would be harder to cheat.
Some franchisees sued, and a federal appeals court ruled that Chicken Delight had engaged in an illegal so-called tie-in arrangement.
But, Professor Joskow notes, the franchisees didn't have to sign up with Chicken Delight in the first place. There was plenty of competition. He teaches the case as an example of bad antitrust policy.
Or consider vertical integration, in which a company owns its supplier or customer. Despite the suspicions of antitrust regulators, in some cases integration may be the easiest, or only, way to benefit from long-term investments.
"The classic example is when you build a power plant next to a coal mine," Professor Joskow explains. "Before you make the investment in either the coal mine or the power plant, you have lots of choices. You can build a power plant almost anywhere. You can use coal, gas or oil. But once you sink the investment, you're locked into the relationship." The coal mine can exploit the power company by breaking its contract and jacking up prices.
"What my work showed," he said, "was you were more likely to get vertical integration in those cases, and if you don't, you get very, very detailed contracts with specific provisions for how to resolve disputes."
An antitrust lawyer who looked only at the situation after the plant was built might question whether the mine had been illegally tied to a long-term contract. A transaction-cost approach demonstrates why such a contract, or an acquisition, would come out of a competitive marketplace.
The imperfect competition school's "possibility theorems" make good social science. But they create too much uncertainty to make good law.
"They show that it's possible under some set of conditions this could be a bad thing, but it's also possible, maybe even probable, that it could be a good thing," Professor Joskow says.
As for Microsoft, he declines to weigh in on the merits of the case. But his article criticizes the original breakup order, noting that it didn't consider the costs or benefits or even how the divestiture would be done.
"This approach reflects the inaccurate assumption that organizational design does not matter for economic performance and that restructuring complex firms is a 'piece of cake' without the need for careful analysis or any significant economic consequences," he writes. "It ignores everything that we have learned from theoretical and empirical work" in transaction cost economics.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
US Airways and Unions Still Trying to Reach Deal
US Airways and several unions have yet to settle on concessions, even though they have to agree on the cuts in order to bolster an application for a federal loan guarantee. The airline is also talking with rivals about a partnership that would be crucial to its recovery.
 US Airways wants $950 million in union concessions because the government expects to see that the carrier can be successfully restructured if it gets a guarantee. Page C4. 

Questions About Tax Techniques
In meetings with wealthy Americans and their financial advisers, Ernst & Young has been selling four techniques to eliminate or reduce income taxes. Ernst & Young says the techniques are legal and proper. But some experts say they may amount to tax evasion. A1.

Goodrich Acquires TRW Unit
TRW, the military contractor and automotive company, said that it would sell its aeronautical systems business to Goodrich for $1.5 billion amid the threat of a hostile takeover from Northrop Grumman. The sale is expected to make TRW even more attractive to Northrop and other potential suitors. C7.

$5 Million Awarded in Tobacco Suit
A jury has awarded $5.5 million to a flight attendant who blamed secondhand smoke for her breathing problems. Tobacco companies plan to use the decision to challenge a ruling governing the $349 million settlement with flight attendants nearly five years ago. A16.

Connecticut's Enron Inquiry Stalls
Despite a loss of about $200 million by the Connecticut trash authority in a deal with Enron, the state's inquiry has bogged down. B1.

Opposition to Radio Mergers
A survey by a music coalition has found that many radio listeners oppose federal laws that encourage more consolidation among radio conglomerates. C6.

Goldman Sells Stake in Korean Bank
Goldman, Sachs has sold 13.2 million shares, or about 60 percent of its stake, in the Kookmin Bank in South Korea, the nation's largest, for $633.6 million. World Business, Section W.

U.S. Attorney Joins Drug Inquiry
The United States attorney's office in Newark is involved in an investigation into how the Schering-Plough made one or more prescription drugs, the company said. C4.

A Panel on Corporate Governance
The Conference Board is expected to announce the creation of a commission that will offer recommendations on overhauling the way corporations govern themselves. C12.

Different Earnings for 2 Firms
Morgan Stanley said its quarterly earnings fell 14 percent, reflecting the weakness in stock trading and merger activity. But the Bear Stearns Companies, a firm that specializes in selling and trading bonds, reported a 20 percent increase in earnings, excluding a big gain from a single investment. Market Place. C8.

Applying Theory to Microsoft Case
The Microsoft case was a showcase for "imperfect competition," a mathematical theory used to understand the strategies a company might pursue to gain an advantage. But if applied naively to antitrust policy, it could lead to poor legal rulings, one economist argues. Virginia Postrel: Economic Scene. C2.

HEADLINE: American Troops Will Begin Tighter Operations With Filipinos 

BYLINE:  By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 19 

 BODY:
Army Special Forces soldiers will soon begin training Philippine troops in smaller units than they do now and will join them on some jungle patrols to hunt a dwindling band of Muslim guerrillas linked to Al Qaeda, Pentagon officials said today.
 But the Americans will accompany only 20 to 25 Philippine companies that have mastered certain combat skills, and only on tightly defined missions, the officials said. 
 The conditions appear to have satisfied the concerns of Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld that training at the company level would expose the Americans to greater risk without increasing the likelihood of killing more Muslim extremists. 
Mr. Rumsfeld's deputy, Paul D. Wolfowitz, and nearly all of his senior military advisers recommended the smaller-unit training as an important step toward enhancing the Philippine Army's ability to fight terrorists, including the small Abu Sayyaf group in the southern Philippines. The 160 Special Forces soldiers on Basilan Island are currently confined to training at the larger battalion level and do not patrol.
Mr. Rumsfeld has also been reluctant to commit a large American force to an open-ended training mission in the Philippines. As a result, a formal six-month training mission on Basilan Island will end as scheduled on July 31, and most of the 1,300 Americans supporting it will gradually return to their home bases.
But a small contingent of American military planners, less than 100 people, will remain to help share intelligence information and coordinate a long-term security assistance and counterterrorism program with the Philippine Army, officials said.
If the Philippine military requests that the company-level training be extended beyond July 31, President Bush has authorized Pentagon and State Department aides to negotiate a new timetable, officials said.
That is important because American and Philippine commanders on Basilan said in recent interviews that American advisers could accomplish only limited goals in the mission's six remaining weeks.
Apart from the Special Forces advisers, about 350 Navy and Marine Corps engineers are on Basilan rebuilding nearly 40 miles of roads, digging new wells and clearing a vine-covered airstrip for cargo planes. Military construction projects, which would provide long-term benefits to the small island's 300,000 residents long after the troops leave, would likely continue after July 31, officials said.
Mr. Rumsfeld has said that an overarching issue has been how current and future training missions would fit the Pentagon's longer-term goals in the Philippines, an important ally in Southeast Asia. He has also said he needed to weigh the commitment of resources in the Philippines against other priorities.
Mr. Wolfowitz, an Asia expert, favors deeper engagement in the Philippines. He has argued that to fight terrorism successfully, Western nations need to bridge the gap with tolerant Muslim nations and their people. Nearly 10 percent of Filipinos are Muslims, most of whom live in the more economically depressed areas in the south, like Basilan, that have been considered crucibles for terrorist groups.
For that and other reasons, American officials said today that the current training mission will be replaced by a long-term security assistance and counterterrorism plan.
President Bush has already committed $100 million in assistance to the Philippine military. That includes a C-130 cargo plane, two Coast Guard cutters, 8 UH-1 Huey utility helicopters and 30,000 older-model M-16 assault rifles that the Pentagon no longer needs.

HEADLINE: One Man Stands Watch On Billions In Farm Loans 

BYLINE:  By ALISON LEIGH COWAN 

 BODY:
Behind the door of Room 3300 at the Farm Credit Administration in McLean, Va., sits Carl A. Clinefelter, director of the Office of Secondary Market Oversight, and his lone employee, an administrative assistant.
 The responsibility for overseeing the Federal Agricultural Mortgage Corporation and its billions of dollars of potential government obligations rests largely on this man. "It's really an agencywide effort," Mr. Clinefelter said. "I happen to be the focal point." 
 But the fact that so much rides on the judgment and drive of one person speaks volumes about the oversight of a program that, when it was formed, Congress said would not create risk to taxpayers. 
The Federal Agricultural Mortgage Corporation, a government-sponsored enterprise, was formed in 1988 to develop the secondary market for farm loans, much as Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, two other government-sponsored enterprises, did for home loans.
For many years, Farmer Mac, as the program has become known, did this by buying farm loans outright. More recently, its business has come mostly from guaranteeing loans on other companies' books. Both methods are intended to encourage lenders to keep making fresh loans.
The Office of Secondary Market Oversight, part of the Farm Credit Administration, has monitored Farmer Mac for financial safety and soundness since 1992. Its director can draw on other farm credit employees, including examiners, as needed -- one reason that the Farm Credit Administration estimated the cost of regulating Farmer Mac at $642,500 last year.
But the responsibility for Farmer Mac rests mainly on Mr. Clinefelter, who reports to the three-person Farm Credit Administration board.
That may have been sufficient when Farmer Mac was small. In fact, its first director, Suzanne J. McCrory, said in an interview that she thought it was almost "extravagant" to have a full-time government employee monitoring Farmer Mac when she had the job from 1992 to 1996, especially since Farmer Mac was then barred by law from doing anything very risky.
Besides new powers, Farmer Mac now has roughly $5 billion in outstanding loan guarantees -- far more than the $1.5 billion of emergency funds that the government might make available if Farmer Mac could not make good on its guarantees. For the last three years, its book of guarantees has been growing at 34 percent compounded a year, as management's ambitions and its allotment of stock options have swelled. 
In an interview -- monitored by a lawyer, a spokesman and a spokeswoman of the Farm Credit Association -- Mr. Clinefelter brushed aside any suggestion that his office might need reinforcement. "The agency has all the resources we need to examine Farmer Mac," he said. 
When pressed, though, he acknowledged that he had recently proposed adding one person to his office to ease the load. "It just didn't work out," is all Mr. Clinefelter would say, adding that he would try again in the coming year.
Others suggested that he and Michael M. Reyna, the chairman of the Farm Credit Administration board, had clashed over who that person should be. Mr. Reyna declined to be interviewed.
Over at the Office of Federal Housing Enterprise Oversight, a regulatory body that Congress created in 1992 to review the safety and soundness of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, such requests would be considered rounding errors. It has 115 employees and a $27 million budget at its disposal, nine times its original budget.
Several people have led the Office of Secondary Market Oversight. After Ms. McCrory came Larry W. Edwards, a former fingerprint technician for the F.B.I., and George Irwin, a Ph.D. in agricultural economics. Mr. Clinefelter, the current director, has extensive experience dealing with troubled institutions.
Beyond a question of resources, there are other structural reasons a lone employee of the Farm Credit Administration, even a dogged, independent-minded one, might be hard pressed to police Farmer Mac.
Forty-two percent of the business that Farmer Mac has booked over the last six years has come from guaranteeing loans made by other parts of the farm credit system, itself a government-sponsored enterprise. That climbed to 70 percent last year.
There is nothing wrong with one so-called government instrumentality shifting risk to another. But it accomplishes very little, critics say, since they would both be likely to turn to the same lender of last resort -- the federal government -- if they ran into trouble.
More worrisome is the way the system shunts the riskiest loans to the most rickety part of the network, according to an analysis published by the Department of Agriculture in February.
To hold a farm loan that is not guaranteed, farm credit banks and other lending institutions that make up the farm credit system are required to have nearly 10 times the regulatory capital that Farmer Mac must have to guarantee the same loan. So, a kind of arbitrage occurs, in which credit risk migrates from the well-capitalized farm credit banks to the more thinly capitalized Farmer Mac.
"Relative to the farm credit system, Farmer Mac has less capital and may not be able to withstand a shock to credit quality and farm asset values," the report said. 
As of the latest public filings, the farm credit system had $16.3 billion of equity, equivalent to 16 percent of its assets, money that would be at risk before a taxpayer bailout might be required. Farmer Mac, in contrast, has $169 million in shareholder equity, barely 3 percent of its assets and guarantee obligations.
Confidential examinations by the Farm Credit Administration, copies of which The New York Times obtained, raised many issues and areas for improvement. But the system is essentially pass-fail. Short of bringing an enforcement action or putting the institution into conservatorship, both drastic steps, or writing new regulations, which often takes years, the regulator has few ways to force change. And because the details of the reports are not routinely made public, shareholders and taxpayers simply see that the company's regulators have signed off.
For instance in 1996, Mr. Edwards sharply criticized the lack of diversification in one of Farmer Mac's loan pools as violating company policies and lacking appropriate documentation. He recommended eight changes to "assure that risk concentration in future pools are reduced to more prudent levels."
Farmer Mac's nine-page reply, signed by Eugene Branstool, its chairman, was polite, but dismissive. It explained that in each case, it was the board and management's "belief" that the company was not taking on excessive risk. 
"The board will continue to monitor" and "take action as necessary," Mr. Branstool promised. 
Mr. Edwards lasted one more year before leaving the government. He declined to discuss much about the experience other than to confirm that he later did business with Farmer Mac, assessing loans that he was helping sell to Farmer Mac. Mr. Clinefelter and the other Farm Credit Administration employees at the interview said Mr. Edwards's subsequent work, which does not appear to violate any government ethics rules, was news to them. 
There are signs, though, that the office is working to stay ahead of the news. On May 28, Mr. Reyna sent a confidential memo to Mr. Clinefelter urging him to accelerate this year's scheduled examination of Farmer Mac, along with a demand that he answer 33 questions about Farmer Mac's business practices by July 1. 
The questions, obtained by The Times, range from an inquiry over Farmer Mac's statutory authority to guarantee loans on other companies' books to whether Farmer Mac's officers have "undue influence" over the board's nomination process.
In light of the questions being raised about Farmer Mac, Mr. Reyna promised Mr. Clinefelter that "the board stands ready to provide you with whatever resources you need to get us this information in a timely fashion."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Carl A. Clinefelter, head of the Office of Secondary Market Oversight, in his office yesterday in McLean, Va., examining a notebook of material about Farmer Mac. (Linda Spillers for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: NEW YORK CITY BUDGET: RECYCLING; 
No to Plastics And Glass; Yes to Paper And Metal

BYLINE:  By DIANE CARDWELL 

 BODY:
New Yorkers will no longer recycle glass or plastic, at least temporarily, but will continue bundling paper and separating metals from their garbage, under a tentative city budget deal. 
 Originally, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg had argued that recycling glass, metal and plastic was too expensive and inefficient, and should be suspended until the program was overhauled. But the City Council -- which had proposed creating a separate authority to fix the problems and to jump-start a successful market for other recyclables (like the one that exists for paper) -- argued that if the program were interrupted, New Yorkers would abandon the hard-won habit of sorting their trash. 
 In a compromise, the two sides agreed to continue recycling metal, but to suspend recycling plastic for one year and glass for two years. Mr. Bloomberg said that the suspensions would save the city about $40 million, in part because of reduced sorting cost. But advocates maintain that what New Yorkers will do with their glass and plastic trash could wind up on the street. City officials say that nonrecyclables thrown into garbage could provoke bottle collectors into ripping open garbage. Or sanitation workers will just keep carting it away, if residents keep placing their nonrecyclables with metal trash. 
The statewide 5-cent bottle deposit law remains in effect, and city residents will still be able to redeem their bottles at various outlets. Mr. Bloomberg earlier proposed changing state law to allow the city to keep the 5-cent deposit on carbonated beverage bottles to help finance a new program, but as of last evening, that was no longer part of the plan. 
Even within the Council, which lobbied hard to save the program, recycling faced steep opposition from members who could not rationalize fully restoring a flawed environmental program while cutting human services, they said. But they did not want to let the administration appear to ride roughshod over a law the institution considered a laurel. Metal became the material of compromise, officials said, because there is a clearer market for recycled metal than for that of glass or plastic. 
But recycling advocates, many who had hovered and lobbied and rallied at City Hall in recent weeks, appeared distinctly unmollified. "It's an irrational process with a stupid outcome," said Laura Haight, a senior environmental associate at the New York Public Interest Research Group, arguing that there was no economic rationale for the compromise, which she called the result of a power struggle between the mayor and the Council.
"The metals recycling staying is great, but as long as you've got those trucks tooling around picking up blue bags of recycling, there's no reason why they can't collect plastic, for which there are many markets," she said, adding that glass was more difficult to recycle than plastic. 
Mark A. Izeman, a senior lawyer at the Natural Resouces Defense Council, agreed. "Significantly, recycling will continue for paper and metal, which are the two most valuable commodities in the waste stream," he said. "But the rash decision to suspend recycling for glass and plastic is short-sighted and not in the city's best longterm economic interests." 
While advocates said they were hopeful that a task force, to be appointed in the wake of the agreement, could help fix the program, they also voiced concern that the suspension could spell the end of glass and plastic recycling. 
Whatever ultimately happens, how the new plan will play out on the streets remained unclear. "What's the city going to do, ticket them for having the audacity to throw a ketchup bottle in the recycling bin?" asked Ms. Haight, noting that Mr. Bloomberg's proposed budget raises the penalty for recycling violations. It was not immediately clear last night whether or not that would remain in the agreed-upon budget. 
But Catherine Collins, director of development at We Can, a redemption center on the West Side that works with poor and homeless people, said the suspension would not have a deleterious effect on her organization, especially if the State Legislature expands the 5-cent deposit to noncarbonated beverages.
"There's going to be a huge influx coming our way, since people will still be able to collect the plastics and glass and bring them to us," she said. But in the city, "there's going to be that much more litter, and that much more that's not going to be recycled." 
"It's going to be confusing to New Yorkers to have to deal with new information on what they can and can't recycle," she added. "It took so many years to get people to separate their trash, now it seems that a lot of people just won't want to participate."

HEADLINE: NEW YORK CITY BUDGET: NEWS ANALYSIS; 
Once Again, Bloomberg Displays His Power as a Rainmaker

BYLINE:  By JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

 BODY:
Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is not responsible for the rain. But since he sat down in his bullpen six months ago, most of what he has wished for has come his way. He has gained control of the city's public schools, settled a protracted contract dispute with teachers and cobbled together two major social policy initiatives. Even the drought emergency seems as if it might end, thanks to a series of downpours.
 By shaking hands with the City Council speaker, Gifford Miller, on a deal that largely reflects the budget proposed by a mayoral team this spring, Mr. Bloomberg appears to have scored his latest big victory at a time of great fiscal uncertainty. 
 The administration restored about 25 percent of the planned cuts to favorite City Council programs -- about the same percentage usually restored during boom times -- and compromised on the mayor's controversial retrenchment on recycling. But Mr. Bloomberg otherwise managed to persuade Mr. Miller -- who in turn brought around his members -- to see the balance sheet the mayor's way.
"When you are new to a job, you find out what can't be done," Mr. Bloomberg said yesterday during an informal chat in the rotunda of City Hall. And then, he reasoned, you take it on. 
Mr. Bloomberg was aided greatly by his first deputy mayor, Marc V. Shaw, and other staff members who once worked for the City Council and know intuitively which programs the body cannot live without. Further, the gravity of the budget gap -- at nearly $5 billion -- did not delude anyone into wishful spending.
By allowing the Council to lay claim to the same amount of restorations enjoyed during a strong economy, and by giving the members credit for enriching the budget of schools and other high-profile areas, the Bloomberg team shrewdly paved the way for the rest of his agenda. That agenda includes heavy trimming to almost every agency and one costly pet project, a new 311 caller system for people to contact city government.
When Mr. Bloomberg met resistance and harsh words from the East Side of City Hall, he did what he always does with adversaries: he ignored them, and talked blandly about mutual concessions. 
Or, he fed them. In the last two months, Mr. Bloomberg has invited six council members to his East Side town house for six different dinner parties, where they shared potpies with famous authors, actors and other notable New Yorkers. Mr. Miller was one such government guest. 
Although Mr. Bloomberg said from the day he was inaugurated that posturing and dancing would not be part of the budget process this time, dance he did. In fact, the entire budget process resembled many sessions of the last eight years, with perhaps fewer verbal grenades lobbed from the west side of City Hall to the east.
The mayor's side proposed tough measures that they were never going to get -- the closing of senior centers and the scrapping of child care programs -- and the City Council threatened to pass its own budget and did not even come close to doing so. Both said they would not budge. They budged.
So while many experts surmised that a largely freshman City Council -- there are 38 new members this year because of term limits -- and a novice mayor could only spell disaster when it came to the budget, yesterday's deal suggests that may not be so, perhaps largely because the City Charter confers far more powers to the mayor than to his legislative partners. A Council can pass its own budget, but the mayor can then essentially impound city funds. 
"The process is more important than the individuals," said Joseph J. Lhota, who negotiated six budgets during his time as budget director and deputy mayor in the Giuliani administration. "Mayors come and mayors go, and now we know that councils come and councils go. But that process is the process." 
But Mr. Bloomberg also brings a certain personality to that process, one that is informed by his years running a private media company and not by serving in government, which until this year, he never had. Like a chief executive trying to close his deal, Mr. Bloomberg has relied on hiding his cards and keeping a smile on his face as he negotiates his way toward what he wants. 
Further, whether it is gunning for control of the school system or putting together a welfare policy, the Bloomberg administration is careful to invite dozens of people who have a stake in the issue through the doors of City Hall to provide input, even if it then ignores them. "It has been the normal democratic process of back and forth," Mr. Bloomberg said last night, when the budget agreement was announced. "That's why the public should feel that everybody was represented. And while everybody isn't going to get what they want -- some people aren't going to be happy -- they at least know their issues, their interests were discussed."
Because Mr. Miller has had fewer challenges to his leadership since he was elected, yesterday's announcement did not solve the mystery of how he would ultimately lead this Council. Was Mr. Miller bringing a sage hand to the process by declining to take the city through a rancorous budget process at a raw time in its history? Or did he fold under the polite pressure of a mayor who is nearly twice his age and who is surrounded by old budget hands like Mr. Shaw?
Last night, Mr. Miller said: "It's not what the mayor got; it's what the people of the city of New York got."
Either way, council members seemed pleased. "What we see here is $175 million in restorations, which is one of the greatest victories the Council can have," said Councilman Joel Rivera, the majority leader. "These could not have been put back in if the Council was not united, and I think the speaker did a very good job of making sure we stayed focused and on point."
