HEADLINE: NEW YORK CITY BUDGET: THE DEAL; 
Bloomberg and Council Agree On Budget to Close Big Deficit

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL COOPER 

 BODY:
Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and the City Council agreed last night on a budget that would close New York City's worst deficit in decades by going into debt, cutting many city services, suspending recycling of jars and bottles and raising the tax on cigarettes.
 Both sides expressed relief that they had reached an amicable accord on closing a nearly $5 billion deficit in the fiscal year that begins on July 1, but there was little celebration. The budget will shrink the Police Department through attrition, cut nearly $60 million from education, cancel some ambulance shifts and scale back social services. 
 "It is an agreement that we all feel is in the best interest of all eight million people that live in this wonderful city," Mr. Bloomberg said last night, as he and City Council Speaker Gifford Miller met under the rotunda of City Hall to announce the accord. Mr. Miller called it a budget that "reflects the priorities and values of New Yorkers." 
Officials know that if this year's budget is a bitter pill to swallow, next year's will be a bitter horse pill: the city's budget gaps are projected to widen to $6 billion in three years as the city reels from the economic aftershocks of the national recession and the attack on the World Trade Center, and struggles to bring its spending in line with its revenues. While Mayor Bloomberg has repeatedly contended that it would be politically unrealistic to ask Gov. George E. Pataki and the State Legislature to raise various taxes in an election year, he has pointedly refused to rule out tax increases next year.
The $42.3 billion budget accord hewed closely to the proposal Mayor Bloomberg outlined in February, a little more than a month after he took office. It calls for no layoffs and very little in the way of new taxes, instead relying heavily on a fiscal practice that is frowned on in normal times: borrowing $1.5 billion to help pay the city's operating expenses.
But if the Republican mayor could point to the plan as substantially his, the overwhelmingly Democratic Council could point to a number of concessions it had won as well.
The Council persuaded the mayor to restore $175 million that was to be cut, ensuring that no centers for the elderly would be closed, libraries would remain open six days a week, the city could add some day care slots, some cuts to cultural institutions could be restored, and 40,000 summer jobs for teenagers would be saved. Council members could also claim a measure of victory for the mayor's decision to restore nearly $300 million out of the $358 million that he had proposed cutting from education, though the restoration was made possible largely by an increase in school aid from Albany.
Mr. Bloomberg said last night that the city would be able to pay for the restoration of the $175 million because the city would close the current fiscal year, which ends on June 30, with more money that it had expected. The mayor did not say how big the surplus would be, but said that the city had spent less than it had planned and saved some money on pension costs and debt service.
On recycling, the mayor met the Council a third of the way. The mayor wanted to suspend recycling of metal, glass and plastic to save roughly $50 million; the Council wanted to preserve the program, arguing that it had taken years, and millions of dollars, to teach the public to separate its trash. In the end, the two sides agreed that the city would keep on recycling metal, but would suspend recycling plastic for one year and glass for two years. Environmentalists criticized the deal, which the mayor said would still save roughly $40 million a year.
The budget contains a number of risky assumptions. Mr. Bloomberg said he was confident that Albany would approve actions worth more than $400 million to the city, including permission to raise the cigarette tax by $1.42 a pack (bringing the cost of a pack to more than $7) and the monthly surcharge on phone bills by 65 cents. But the budget still depends on nearly half a billion dollars in help from the federal government and the city's labor unions that has not yet materialized.
When Mayor Bloomberg presented his executive budget plan in April, he outlined $500 million in contingency cuts that were to be put in effect in the event that the state, federal or union aid failed to fall into place. But those contingency cuts were not included in the budget yesterday; Mr. Bloomberg said he was still optimistic that the aid would come.
"We're halfway, roughly, with the federal monies, and we're more than halfways with the help that we've asked from the municipal unions," the mayor said last night. "So I'm optimistic that we'll get full ways with both of those."
That strategy of waiting for the aid to materialize is not without its drawbacks, though, because the longer the city waits before making a cut, the deeper the cut will have to be in order to yield the desired amount in savings by the end of the year.
Even the help from Albany proved harder to get than some city officials had expected. The city's final agreement was held up for much of yesterday by disagreements in Albany, where state officials differed over what they would approve for the city and Republicans and Democrats feuded about matters altogether unrelated. One of the sticking points there was whether to approve a $17 million program for teacher recruitment and retention. The Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, a Republican, said the city's package "had things in it that we had not agreed on."
So last night's tentative deal came after a long day of hurry-up-and-wait at City Hall.
Although aides to the mayor and the Council announced that they had a tentative agreement in principle on Tuesday evening, the final handshake on the deal remained tantalizingly elusive for most of the day. The morning began with Deputy Mayor Marc V. Shaw and Forrest R. Taylor, the chief of staff to Mr. Miller, the Council speaker, taking a stage-managed stroll through City Hall Park so that news photographers could get shots of the two sides acting warmly toward each other (and, as it turned out, images of a man on a nearby bench berating them for the city's homeless policies).
But the formal announcement of a deal did not come. Aides spoke of staging handshake ceremonies at 2 p.m., 3:30 p.m., 6 p.m. and 8 p.m., postponing each time. City officials said they were waiting on the State Legislature.
Mayor Bloomberg, apparently unperturbed, left City Hall in the evening to throw out the first pitch of opening day for the Brooklyn Cyclones in Coney Island.
Finally, the long-awaited handshake ceremony was scheduled for 8:30, but even that was delayed until around 9:45 p.m. The mayor began the news conference by announcing the score of the ballgame.
For all the work that went into yesterday's agreement, the budget is only a starting point, a best guess as to how much money the city will collect in taxes and aid, and how much the city will need to spend on services. Some budget watchdog groups have already warned that its basic forecasts are too optimistic.
Looking at the mayor's budget plan last month, when it contained even more cuts, the New York State Financial Control Board, which took over the city's finances during the fiscal crisis of the 1970's and now monitors its budgets and financial plans, warned that "2003 budget balance appears to be in jeopardy" and added that "additional action on the city's part is necessary." The city and state comptrollers pointed to risks as well.
But the city, which is required by law to end each year with a balanced budget or risk a takeover by the comptroller, typically modifies its budgets several times in the course of the fiscal year to make sure its spending and revenues remain in line.
Mr. Bloomberg said he was confident that the plan was prudent. "It is the best compromise given all of the needs to this city," he said, "and it sets the stage for us to deal with our economic problems down the road."

LENGTH: 1096 words

HEADLINE: A Buoyant Karzai Is Sworn In as Afghanistan's Leader 

BYLINE:  By CARLOTTA GALL and JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: KABUL, Afghanistan, June 19 

 BODY:
Afghanistan's new president, Hamid Karzai, was in an ebullient mood this evening after being sworn in as president for the next two years. Just minutes before, the grand council had approved his new cabinet and the appointment of several vice presidents. 
 Mr. Karzai had tried to appoint a balanced cabinet to ease ethnic divisions in the country and to weaken the power of the warlords by drawing them away from their power bases to the capital, but his first steps appeared tentative. 
 The day had been exhausting and difficult, he said in an interview afterward in the gardens of Kabul's old royal palace, adding, "I never want to have to pick a cabinet again." 
But Mr. Karzai said he hoped his new legitimacy would strengthen his hand in securing peace for Afghanistan and winning the country much-needed international aid.
Mr. Karzai's main difficulty was finding a balance in the cabinet that would satisfy the country's powerful factions and ethnic groups and ease the tensions that have brought them to war in the past. He was under pressure to reduce the power of Tajiks, who dominated the interim cabinet, holding the powerful defense, foreign and interior ministries. Pashtuns, the largest ethnic group in Afghanistan, in particular have demanded more representation in the government.
Mr. Karzai opted for a halfway step, retaining the defense minister, Marshal Muhammad Qasim Fahim, but appointing a Pashtun, Taj Muhammed Wardak, an elderly former governor, as interior minister. Delegates approved his cabinet, but few saw Mr. Wardak as a serious counterweight for Marshal Fahim.
Dr. Abdullah, another of the influential Tajiks, will remain foreign minister, and Yunus Qanooni, who resigned as interior minister, will be minister of education.
Mr. Karzai said he was looking further than just a balanced distribution of posts. "We have to have technical people in the interior ministry, to take away the political character of this ministry, and we need a technical and professional minister." 
Of Mr. Wardak, he said: "He is a man who has experience of provincial matters, who has governed before. Let's give him a chance."
Mr. Karzai defended keeping Marshal Fahim, saying it would maintain continuity in the campaign against terrorism. "He's the minister of defense," he said. "He has people that he has, the coalition is working with him and we have an antiterrorism campaign to complete. We cannot just turn things upside down and bring changes overnight." 
Mr. Karzai said a new defense commission would oversee the building of a national army, which Marshal Fahim has not always supported, and he emphasized that the institutions would become more important than individuals.
In a clear attempt to strengthen his central government and to loosen some of the warlords from their power bases, Mr. Karzai appointed three of them vice presidents this week: Marshal Fahim, the Hazara leader, Karim Khalili, and Haji Abdul Qadir, the Pashtun governor of Nangarhar. They would move to Kabul to take on portfolios yet to be announced. The aim, Mr. Karzai said, was to create "a national effort to bring more security and safety to the Afghan people, and to bring institutions to Afghanistan." 
But in this plan he was also only partly successful. Two of the most powerful regional warlords, the Uzbek general from the north, Abdul Rashid Dostum, and Ismael Khan, from Herat in the west, declined to be take vice presidential posts unless they could maintain their regional interests. He said he would keep talking to them and would continue to offer posts in hopes of bringing them in. 
Another warlord, Padsha Khan Zadran, who has openly defied Mr. Karzai and attacked his own town with rockets to try to seize power, was effectively sidelined by the loya jirga, or grand council of 1,600 delegates. "The loya jirga voted overwhelmingly for me," Mr. Karzai said. "And he was there. And he campaigned." 
Mr. Karzai also removed Mr. Zadran's brother, Amanullah, from the cabinet, complaining that he had attended only two cabinet meetings.
"Stability, security, peace, economic well-being of the Afghan people, reconstruction" were his aims for the next six months, he said.
Mr. Karzai said he would not hesitate to implore the United Nations to expand the international security force now patrolling Kabul to other cities if violence erupted there. But he said he did not see an immediate need for that, though there have been recent reports of lawlessness and factional fighting among warlords in the Mazar-i-Sharif area. 
Mr. Karzai also said that he did not believe that the remnants of Al Qaeda and their Taliban supporters posed a serious threat to his government. 
But he insisted that the United States and its coalition partners should maintain their current forces in Afghanistan -- more than 12,000 soldiers -- to finish the hunt for those Al Qaeda fighters, most of whom are thought to be operating along the Pakistan border. 
"Let me be very blunt: there is no mercy there," he said. "They are criminals who have killed people. In Afghanistan they have killed people, they have killed people in America. They must be found, they must be taken to court and societies must be free from their menace."
Asked if he thought that Mullah Muhammed Omar, the leader of the Taliban, was still in Afghanistan, Mr. Karzai said he did, and that Mullah Omar was probably moving from sanctuary to sanctuary in the southern provinces of Helmand and Kandahar.
"He is around," Mr. Karzai said. "Eventually, we'll find him." 
During his speech before the loya jirga and again in the interview, Mr. Karzai called for the immediate release of more than 600 Taliban soldiers being held by commanders in the north. Many of those soldiers are from the south, and Mr. Karzai's call for amnesty is clearly intended to foster regional reconciliation and national unity.
"We must have a distinction between the Taliban and terrorists," he said. "The common talib, he can go home." 
The loya jirga, which has been meeting for nine days, drew to a close today. Still unresolved are the powers and membership of a parliament, but Mr Karzai asked representatives from each electoral zone to remain behind for 20 days to work things out. In the interview, he said he supported the creation of a legislature with the power to enact laws and approve budgets, rather than just the advisory body that some delegates advocated.
"There are lots of things that will come to me and burden me and consume time without a legislative body," he said. "A legislative body will take a lot of my problem away from me."

HEADLINE: OPERA REVIEW; 
An Edith Wharton Novella, Set to Music

BYLINE:  By ALLAN KOZINN

 BODY:
For 20 years the Center for Contemporary Opera has been making the case that there are new operas out there, and that even if most of them are unlikely to find a place in the standard canon, the least they deserve is an occasional hearing. On Wednesday evening at the Kaye Playhouse, the company closed its season with the New York premiere of Stephen Paulus's "Summer," a work that was given its world premiere in 1999 by another small but enterprising company, the Berkshire Opera.
 Mr. Paulus knows his way around the stage: "Summer," which has a libretto by Joan Vail Thorne, based on the novella by Edith Wharton, is the seventh of his eight operas. His writing for the voice is streamlined and attractive, and if the score does have passages in the awkwardly angular style common in contemporary opera, that style is by far outpaced by straightforward, inviting lyricism. 
 His orchestral writing is equally striking, not least because Mr. Paulus is adept at finding exactly the right coloration and textures -- anything from lush strings or solid brass choirs to delicate harp and percussion tracery -- to underscore what is happening in the drama. Richard Marshall, the company's general and artistic director, was the conductor, and he had a responsive orchestra at hand. Only an occasional brass figure gave the musicians any trouble. The string playing, in particular, was strikingly beautiful.
One thing that Mr. Paulus's music accomplishes is a softening of the current of New England dourness in the Wharton story, which is about Charity Royall, a young woman who was born in the Berkshire Hills but raised in the town of North Dormer by one of its prominent citizens, Lawyer Royall. When the opera begins, Charity is an adult, and her guardian wants to marry her.
The prospect doesn't interest Charity. Not much else does either, certainly not her job in the town's musty, rarely visited library. But when a newcomer arrives -- a young architect, Lucius Harney -- she is immediately drawn to him. Charity has become pregnant by the time she learns that Lucius is engaged to someone else, and at the end of the work she agrees to marry Royall.
The production, directed by Charles Maryan, with a spare set and 19th-century costumes by Lana Fritz, is an economical and attractive frame for the two-hour work, which also benefited from an able, well-balanced cast.
Jessica Grigg did a fine job of bringing to life Charity's variety of conflicts -- everything from class insecurities because of her mountain origins to more commonplace adolescent angst -- while making her essentially likable. She also sang the role with an attractive fluidity, a quality matched by Richard Lippold, who sang Lucius. He shares the stage with Charity much of the time, but he is not as vividly drawn a character. If Charity has a true male counterpart in complexity, it is Lawyer Royall. Michael Lofton sang the role vividly and conveyed Royall's essential kindness as well as the authoritarian streak (and even occasional drunkenness) from which Charity hoped to break free.
The singers in the smaller roles -- Tracy Bidelman as Miss Hatchard, Jody Sheinbaum as Ally Hawes and Joanna Mongiardo as Annabel Balch, Lucius's intended -- all made solid contributions.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Jessica Grigg and Richard Lippold in Stephen Paulus's "Summer." (Nan Melville for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: The Treasures of a Private Collector, From Copenhagen 

BYLINE:  By GRACE GLUECK

 BODY:
"I might just as well confess now rather than later that I have been rash and made substantial purchases," Wilhelm Hansen (1868-1936) wrote to his wife, Henny, in 1916. "I know, though, that I will be forgiven when you see what I have bought; it is all first class with honors."
 Hansen, a Danish insurance magnate whose inspired acquiring was enabled by his cleverness at business, had just bought the beginnings -- two landscapes by Sisley and one by Pissarro, a Monet cathedral and a portrait by Renoir -- of what was to become the most important collection of 19th-century French paintings in northern Europe. An acute and dogged planner, he got together the Impressionist part of it in only two years, from 1916 to 1918; lost much of it later in business reversals and then managed to rebuild it. 
 The collection, along with a fine group of paintings by Danish artists of Hansen's day and earlier, was given a handsome setting at his 14-acre country place in the town of Ordrupgaard outside Copenhagen. After his wife's death in 1951, the house and the paintings became the state-owned Ordrupgaard Museum. Now, while the museum undergoes expansion, a touring show of its holdings, "The Age of Impressionism: European Paintings From the Ordrupgaard Museum, Copenhagen," is summering at the Metropolitan Museum.
Its 84 works make a splendid display, what with eight paintings by Gauguin (tying in handily with the Met's current show in another gallery, "Gauguin in New York Collections: The Lure of the Exotic"); eight by Degas, six by Pissarro, five each by Monet, Renoir, Sisley and the Danish painter Vilhelm Hammershoi, and treasures by Cezanne, Corot, Courbet, Delacroix, Ingres, Manet and Matisse, among others.
Hansen's maneuverings as a collector were certainly cued by his commercial know-how. A huge success in business at an early age, he turned from an avocational interest in developing a new universal language known as Volapuk (superseded by Esperanto) to art collecting shortly after his marriage in 1891.
At first he and his wife filled their Copenhagen home with Danish art of the early 19th century, by so-called Golden Age painters like C. W. Eckersberg (1783-1853) and his pupil Christen Kobke (1810-1848); romantic landscapists like P. C. Skovgaard (1817-1875); and contemporaries like the Symbolist-oriented realists Hammershoi and L. A. Ring.
But later, visiting Paris on frequent business trips, Hansen began to dream of a significant collection of French art, specifically a dozen paintings by each of the great 19th-century artists important to the rise of modernism. His interest may have been triggered by a 1914 show of 19th-century painting in Copenhagen that was stranded there by the outbreak of World War I.
Prices for art were lower during the war, when Americans were absent from the European market, and Hansen made his first purchases in 1916. Although he, too, stayed away from Paris for the next few years, he was in touch with scouts and advisers there, particularly an important critic, Theodore Duret, a friend of Manet and an Impressionist advocate.
Duret recommended that Hansen buy Manet's "Basket of Pears" (1882), a small, quiet, almost sculptural still life, on view in the show, that was to become one of the businessman's favorite works. After a dinner at his home in 1917 he showed the painting to guests as "an extra dessert." 
Predictably, prices rose immediately after the war, with the advent of an economic boom. Joining a Danish fellow collector and two art dealers, Hansen formed a consortium. Their aim was to obtain "good and outstanding art for Scandinavia," and each contributed money for purchases en bloc, or wholesale, with the idea of keeping individual works and selling the rest.
They bought the Montaignac collection of 233 works before its scheduled sale at a Paris auction, from which Hansen got Daumier's poignant view of a broken-down fighter, "The Wrestler" (1852), and Delacroix's small but feisty "Lion in the Mountains. Lion Attacked" (1851), a king of kings whose body reflects the surrounding landscape. Both paintings are in the show. 
They also got the holdings of a Paris dentist, George Viau, which included more than 200 paintings; part of Degas's collection and studio, sold at his death; and 28 pictures from the well-known French collector Alphonse Kann. Buying from dealers, too, they secured three Degas works from Ambroise Vollard, among them the late pastel "Three Dancers" (circa 1898) -- also in the show -- depicting ballerinas onstage in a whirl of colors. 
By 1918 Hansen could announce the completion of his plan. A three-floor picture gallery was added to the house at Ordrupgaard, designed to showcase his 156 French pictures, ranging from David and Delacroix through Realism and Impressionism to Matisse as the first Fauve. 
At the Met, the Danish and French collections are separated, a good thing, as showing them together would invite unnecessary comparisons. The most interesting of the Danish artists is unquestionably Hammershoi, the last of the great 19th-century Danish painters. His spare, somber interiors and portraits had no traffic with the developing language of modernism (his work in fact is reminiscent of Vermeer), and for years he was ignored. 
But its elegaic moodiness, touching on symbolism -- sometimes suggesting the work of the Swedish filmmaker Ingmar Bergman -- has recently brought it back into critical consciousness. A Hammershoi retrospective, organized by the Ordrupgaard, actually found its way to the Guggenheim Museum in New York in 1998. 
The larger French section of the show has true delights, among them a lively Fauve still life by Matisse, "Flowers and Fruits" (1909), and a brilliantly colored Symbolist rendition of still-life components by Redon, done in 1901. Two Gauguins especially stand out, the 1896 Polynesian-flavored "Portrait of a Young Woman (Jeanne Goupil)" and his pre-Fauve masterpiece, "Your Turn Will Come, My Beauty: The Blue Tree Trunks, Arles" (1888). Degas's great portrait of his New Orleans cousin, Mathilde Musson (1872-73), dazzles, as does a bold likeness by Renoir of a Romanian woman, Madame Iscovesco (1877). 
Sisley's strongly composed "Flood, Banks of the Seine, Bougival" (1873), depicting a rather pretty factory and its smokestack reflected in water, comes off as a fine example of Impressionism even though its basis was probably drawing, rather than brushwork improvisation. A great Pissarro representation includes that artist's powerful evocation of springtime, "Plum Trees in Blossom, Eragny, the Painter's Home" (1894), a light-struck tribute to the fecundity of the season.
But back to the collector for a moment. Disaster struck in 1922 with the collapse of a bank that had made heavy loans to the consortium. To pay his debts, Hansen had to sell a number of works, including seven masterpieces by Cezanne. Eventually, he recouped substantially, adding works by Delacroix, Courbet, Daumier, Corot and the Degas portrait of Mme. Musson. He mourned the loss, but what's here is banquet aplenty. 

"The Age of Impressionism: European Painting From the Ordrupgaard Collection, Copenhagen" is at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710, through Sept. 8.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Above, "The Flood, Banks of the Seine, Bougival" (1873), by Sisley, and right, a large detail from "Dust Motes Dancing in the Sunlight, Interior of the Artist's Home" (1900), by Vilhelm Hammershoi, at the Metropolitan Museum this summer. (Photographs from Ordrupgaard Collection, Copenhagen)

HEADLINE: TV WEEKEND; 
So Much More Than Just a Bodily Fluid

BYLINE:  By Julie Salamon

 BODY:
In the same way that people lined up to donate blood after the Sept. 11 attacks, Americans felt compelled to send blood to Britain during the London blitz of World War II. The man responsible for organizing the American Red Cross's Plasma for Britain campaign was Dr. Charles Drew, an African-American physician. 
 Yet when the United States entered the war, Dr. Drew couldn't donate blood himself because he was black and the country's white policy makers were afraid of "contamination." Later in the war, blacks were allowed to donate blood to soldiers overseas, but the African-American blood was segregated (just as African-Americans were in the United States Army). All the while, the Allies were supposedly combating Nazi bigotry built on notions of racial purity derived from bloodlines. 
 Dr. Drew's story appears in the second episode of "Red Gold: The Epic Story of Blood," a four-part PBS series beginning on Sunday night and concluding the following Sunday. It was inspired by Douglas Starr's book "Blood: An Epic History of Medicine and Commerce" (Alfred A. Knopf, 1998). 
While watching, it's worth being mindful of the business interests of the program's sponsors, Chiron Blood Testing and Ortho-Clinical Diagnostics, a Johnson & Johnson affiliate. These companies have a stake in the series's ultimate conclusion that dire mistakes in the handling of blood have been made in the name of technological advance, but things are better now -- at least for blood-transfusion recipients in the United States. 
"Red Gold" covers obvious blood-related crises like AIDS, but it is most interesting when delving into blood's historic importance in war, commerce, literature and religion. Count Dracula rates barely a mention, but the significance of bloodletting is expounded on at length in the opening episode, "Magic to Medicine." The practice, which helped kill George Washington and gave barber poles their striped design, continues in many places, including India.
Intelligent and enjoyably kaleidoscopic, the series covers the poignant moment when scientists declared that the heart was just a pump, not the seat of the soul. (Couldn't it be both?) It celebrates the volunteers who created blood banks after World War I, solving the problem of finding donors in emergencies. It explores the way plasma became mired in politics in the 20th century, as American drug companies profited mightily from blood donations from prisoners and people in third-world countries. "America was the OPEC of plasma," says Mr. Starr, the author, who appears as a commentator.
The program deals with the fatal mishandling of the AIDS crisis and the consequent contamination of the world's blood supply. (It includes striking images of unrepentant French officials and of Japanese executives bowing in apology to families of people infected with the virus through blood transfusions.)
The producers value braininess over style, and sometimes the programs can be downright fusty. In Episode 2, "Blood and War," after describing the Soviet practice in the 1930's of using cadavers as blood donors, the narrator intones, "In Britain, cadaver blood was nobody's cup of tea."
That quaint word play leads directly, however, to one of the series's strengths: its small portraits of individuals whose practical notions on how to solve problems resulted in profound transformations. One was Percy Lane Oliver, an English Red Cross worker who recognized the need for systematic blood donations in 1921, when a hospital called and asked if he could find a volunteer for an emergency transfusion.
The technology for blood storage hadn't developed yet, so hospitals were always looking for "donors on the hoof," as walk-in volunteers were called. Mr. Oliver realized that serendipity wouldn't do, so he began organizing volunteers who agreed to register their blood types and be on call for emergencies. He ran this operation from his parlor, expanding from that first lone call in 1921 to 7,000 in 1938.
The theory and practice of blood transfusion courses like you-know-what throughout the series, beginning with early calf-to-human experiments conducted in 17th-century France. (A contemporary French physician wonders wryly why this seems so untoward, since people eat animal meat full of blood.) "Red Gold," referring to the economic importance of blood, makes an unusual and unusually clinical history lesson -- fascinating rather than gross or gruesome, though it helps to be able to stand the sight of the stuff.

RED GOLD
The Epic Story of Blood

On most PBS stations Sunday night and June 30 (check local listings)

Episode 1: Magic to Medicine; Episode 2: Blood and War; Episode 3: Tainted Blood; Episode 4: New Blood. Produced and directed by Alex Marengo and Nick Read; Stephen Segaller, executive producer; Gino Del Guercio, coordinating producer. A production of Thirteen/WNET New York by Optomen Television.

HEADLINE: Uruguay Lifts Limits on Peso to Assist Economy 

BYLINE:  By LARRY ROHTER

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, June 20 

 BODY:
The government of Uruguay announced today that it would allow the country's currency, the peso, to float freely against the American dollar, in an effort to soften the blow of a deepening regional economic crisis.
 The change in policy, though not unexpected, immediately unleashed a heavy demand for dollars, with Uruguayans rushing to exchange houses in Montevideo, the capital. In the first few hours of panicky trading, the value of the Uruguayan peso dropped by nearly 20 percent against the dollar. 
 In the last decade, the government of Uruguay, South America's smallest country, has let its peso trade within limits set by the Central Bank. But largely because of the current crisis in Argentina, Uruguay's foreign reserves have dropped by more than 40 percent this year, to $1.8 billion, and its bank deposits by 20 percent. Those changes have made the peso vulnerable to market speculation and the support of the trading limits increasingly costly.
"The Central Bank is going to limit itself to assuring that the transition is an orderly one," the president of the bank, Cesar Rodriguez Batlle, said this morning. "Other than some very precise interventions, this is going to be a clean float."
The economy in Uruguay is strongly linked to those of two much larger neighbors, Brazil and Argentina, and depends heavily on agriculture and tourism. Those segments of the economy, already weakened by four years of recession, have suffered severely because of the collapse of the Argentine economy six months ago and recent market turmoil in Brazil.
The Argentine peso has lost more than 70 percent of its value since it was freed from a one-to-one exchange rate with the dollar in January, while the Brazilian real has weakened by more than 15 percent in the same period. As a result, Uruguayan exports like meat are less competitive, and Uruguay's hotels, beach resorts and restaurants have become more expensive for Argentine and Brazilian visitors.
"The changes in the two neighboring countries are adding a very strong element of uncertainty for us," the economy minister, Alberto Bension, said in announcing the new currency policy. In the first quarter of the year, the Uruguayan economy contracted 10 percent, causing bond prices to drop sharply and credit agencies to downgrade ratings of the once-solid Uruguayan economy.
In an effort to halt the slide, the International Monetary Fund recommended on Tuesday that Uruguay's credit line be increased by $1.5 billion. That action came on top of a two-year credit package worth $769 million that the I.M.F. approved in March and the additional assistance of $500 million from the Inter-American Development Bank and $400 million from the World Bank.
"The crisis affecting the region has had more adverse effects on the Uruguayan economy than previously anticipated," Eduardo Aninat, the deputy managing director of the I.M.F., said this week.
Mr. Bension said Uruguay decided to float the peso after consulting the I.M.F., which strongly encourages developing countries to follow that approach. On Tuesday, the government also said it would ask Congress to approve 50 new measures meant to reduce state spending sharply, one condition demanded by the monetary fund in return for the additional aid.
"We are not attacking superfluous expenditures, we are proposing fundamental reforms," Carlos Ramela, an adviser to President Jorge Batlle, said in announcing the austerity package, which he estimated would save the government $260 million. In May, Congress approved a tax increase, mainly on salaries and retirement benefits, that is expected to increase revenue by $230 million but has led to protests and strikes.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Crises in Brazil and Argentina add "a very strong element of uncertainty for us," Uruguay's economy minister, Alberto Bension, said yesterday. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: European Summit Talks Open Today; Focus Is Immigration Control 

BYLINE:  By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: SEVILLE, Spain, June 20 

 BODY:
The European Union is at an important crossroads, 15 countries looking to enlarge to 25 while transforming its own ponderous procedures, trying to become both efficient and democratic. But the Union's summit meeting here Friday and Saturday will barely make a dent in the organizational problems. 
 Instead, stung by a political shift to the right in Europe, the leaders have turned this meeting into one dominated by immigration, which was shoved onto the agenda only after the far-right politician Jean-Marie Le Pen did so well in the first round of the French presidential vote in April. 
 The meeting will also face the now common demonstrations against globalization and Europe's confusion in pressing for open trade while continuing to subsidize its own businesses, including an outdated and wildly expensive system of farm subsidies that takes up 45 percent of the European Union budget. 
In fact the host, Jose Maria Aznar, the conservative prime minister of Spain, which is ending its six-month presidency, had to postpone the beginning of the meeting by several hours on Friday to allow his colleagues to arrive. There was a general strike today in Spain, which left few open businesses and no taxis. 
The strike was about domestic changes to social security, but it has made the leaders ever more sensitive to the political backlash from voters concerned about their living standards, crime and foreigners. 
Immigration as a general issue has been roiling Europe and providing votes for right-wing and populist candidates. It has become a major election issue in Germany, with its stagnant economy, high unemployment and history of generosity to refugees.
In Germany, as in France, Britain and Spain, the issue of immigration has also become associated with a perception of rising crime and has taken on a tinge of terrorism. Muslim immigrants in all four countries have been linked to the Sept. 11 attacks on New York and Washington.
Urged on by Mr. Aznar and Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain, the leaders will debate how to press other countries to stop the flow of illegal immigrants to a Europe grown wealthy and attractive. 
Britain has suggested economic sanctions or reductions in aid, but other countries, like France and Sweden, are looking for softer solutions, arguing that punishing poor countries will only generate more illegal migration.
But the leaders are expected to endorse plans to increase the number of border guards and to set a timetable to work out a common asylum policy and rules on how applicants are treated. 
The European Commission, the Union's executive body, estimates that half a million illegal immigrants enter each year, almost as many as the 680,000 legal immigrants. But most of the illegal immigrants are believed to be economic migrants who overstay their visas, not people abusing the asylum process. In fact the number of people seeking asylum in Europe has dropped steadily since the end of wars in the Balkans.
Prime Minister Aznar has rejected allegations that Europe is seeking to seal its borders to anybody from outside, which the candidate countries of Eastern Europe fear also means them. "I have said it clearly and I want to reiterate that debates about a 'Fortress Europe' make no sense," Mr. Aznar said. "Europe is not going to be a fortress, nor do we want it to become one, but it will not either be a chasm where anything can pass through."
But both the United Nations Commissioner for Human Rights, Mary Robinson, and its High Commissioner for Refugees, Ruud Lubbers, have warned European leaders not to toy with people's fears. 
"There is a kind of public mood which unfortunately is not being addressed by political leaders with sufficient leadership," Ms. Robinson said. Efforts to seal borders must be coupled with clear legal channels for immigration, Mr. Lubbers said.
The leaders are also struggling with Europe's economic downturn and the requirement that all countries balance their budgets by 2004, and keep budget deficits less than 3 percent of gross domestic product in the meantime. 
Germany was warned for approaching that ceiling, infuriating Chancellor Gerhard Schroder, who faces a tough election fight. So his government has leaked figures showing that France is coming close to the ceiling now.
Finance ministers are trying to soften the 2004 target, making it subject to "growth remaining in line with forecasts," a Spanish official said, one more example of how reality often undermines European Union commitments.
Similarly, Mr. Schroder has said that unless Europe's agricultural policy is reformed, his country cannot afford to pay farm subsidies that would be due to new, poorer members when they join.
European leaders want to keep new members from getting full benefits right away, but that would only postpone the real problem, which is to change a subsidy system that hugely benefits the 5 percent of European workers who are farmers. The 10 candidate countries will more than double the number of farmers and increase the amount of land under cultivation by 42 percent. 
The leaders will also work to resolve another embarrassing problem: The Union wants to have a first real task for its own security and defense program, which is formally separate from NATO. 
The current NATO peacekeeping force in Macedonia is only about 800 troops, and the Europeans want to take it over as a European Union project. But they still need the use of the larger group's equipment, and squabbles between Greece and Turkey -- a member of NATO but not of the Union -- has blocked this small effort to project European power. 
The leaders will also discuss proposals from the president of the European Commission, Romano Prodi, to create an "inner cabinet" to work more efficiently, especially once the Union enlarges. But all such proposals are complicated, touching national interests and even affecting political coalitions within states.
So as usual, major structural change will be put off for another time, awaiting the results of a "convention" talking about a new constitution for the new, larger European Union.

HEADLINE: Fears for Jobs Could Bring Shutdown of West Coast Ports 

BYLINE:  By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: LONG BEACH, Calif., June 19 

 BODY:
For decades, the West Coast longshoremen's union could boast that its members had some of the highest-paying blue-collar jobs in the nation. Workers who unload ships commonly earn more than $85,000 a year.
 But now the longshoremen fear that their jobs -- and those of future generations of longshoremen -- are under siege. 
 Those fears could lead to a shutdown of all seaports from San Diego to Seattle on July 1, a move that could send shock waves through the nation's already fragile economy. 
In the giant Los Angeles-Long Beach port complex, by far the nation's largest port, burly longshoremen complain that the shipping companies want to install more computerized technology that they fear could throw hundreds of union members out of work -- and take away jobs for future dockworkers.
Officials with the shipping companies insist that their role is to run an efficient port, not to protect the jobs of the unborn. 
The shipping companies complain about work rules from the 1940's and argue that more modern rules -- and more modern technologies -- are needed or the ports will choke on their own inefficiencies.
These clashing views could lead to the biggest work stoppage on the waterfront since 1971, when the longshoremen staged a four-month strike. While officials with the International Longshore and Warehouse Union say they have no plans to call a strike, the shipping companies fear a crippling job slowdown if no contract is reached by July 1. 
Union members say they worry that management will beat them to the punch and lock out the 10,500 West Coast longshoremen, who load and unload cargo from ships and record all merchandise that goes in or out of the ports.
"If you have a shutdown of these ports, it would be devastating," said Jack Kyser, chief economist for the Los Angeles County Economic Development Corporation. "It's not just what it would do to the West Coast economy, it's what it would do to the U.S. economy."
A study by Stephen S. Cohen, a professor at the University of California, estimated that a five-day work stoppage would cost the nation's economy $4.7 billion and that the cost of a 20-day stoppage would be $48.6 billion. The West Coast ports handle more than $300 billion in goods annually.
Department stores, car dealers, hardware companies and many other businesses fear that a shutdown of the ports could quickly interrupt their supply lines. 
That explains why business groups across the nation are pressuring the union and the management group, the Pacific Maritime Association, which represents shipping lines and stevedores, to reach a settlement before July 1. 
But not much optimism is heard about the negotiations, and that, economists say, is one reason Wall Street has slumped in recent weeks. Not surprisingly, some business groups are urging President Bush to use his powers under the Taft-Hartley Act to order a cooling off period to prevent a strike or lockout.
"It's hard to think that all this is being managed in a way that it will be resolved by July 1," said Robin Lanier, executive director of the West Coast Waterfront Coalition, which represents a variety of companies, including shipping lines, retailers like Target and automakers like Toyota.
For months before negotiations officially began on May 13, management officials said the crucial issue was technology. They said greater use of technology would save money, reduce the two-hour lines of trucks waiting to enter the ports and increase security in cargo-handling when the nation fears new terrorist attacks. 
Management dislikes rules like the one that requires clerks in the longshoremen's union to type in information about all arriving merchandise when that information was already typed in when ships left Asia. 
A study by Michael Nacht, a public policy professor at the University of California, found that not using technology more efficiently cost the shipping industry at least $1 billion a year.
"We cannot avoid the issue of new technology," Joseph Miniace, president of the Pacific Maritime Association, told the union when negotiations began last month. "Currently, the West Coast is behind. We must see to it that the West Coast moves to the forefront."
While acknowledging that technology might reduce the number of jobs, management negotiators promised that it would not cause layoffs for any current workers. Many longshoremen are unimpressed by that promise because they do not trust management. But that is not the only reason union members fear more technology. 
"The union doesn't look at these jobs as jobs to trade away," Steve Stallone, the union's spokesman, said when the negotiations began. "We hold these jobs in trust to pass down to other people in the community. We negotiate for the next generation of longshoremen."
Union officials insist that theirs is an enlightened union that has often entertained the greater use of technology. They point to the landmark agreement 40 years ago that allowed ports to handle cargo in large containers. In return, the union shared in the rising profits -- in the form of unusually high wages -- made possible by modernization.
Some union officials acknowledge that the focus on technology has put them on the defensive. They point to other important issues in the talks, among them management's proposals to require retirees and current workers to begin contributing toward their health insurance.
"It's not fair that all these foreign-owned shipping lines want American workers and elderly American retirees who live on a fixed income to pay more for health coverage," said Ramon Ponce de Leon Jr., president of the largest longshoremen's local for the Los Angeles-Long Beach port. 
In a brief interview, Mr. Miniace and James Spinosa, the union's president, defended the pace of the talks. They said in a joint statement that the two sides had successfully negotiated contracts over the past 30 years, and that "we are confident that we will succeed again."

HEADLINE: 2 Columbus Circle Will Be a Museum Again 

BYLINE:  By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
The long-abandoned marble-clad confection of a building at 2 Columbus Circle that New Yorkers loved to hate -- but hated to let go -- will be reborn as what it was intended to be: a museum.
 Ending seven years of uncertainty about the structure, originally Huntington Hartford's Gallery of Modern Art in 1964 but more recently a city office building, the Bloomberg administration said yesterday that it would sell 2 Columbus Circle to the American Craft Museum, now at 40 West 53rd Street. The price was not disclosed. 
 The museum plans to spend at least $30 million to renovate the building as its new home, said its director, Holly Hotchner. Galleries will be used again for art, the underground auditorium for performances and the penthouse restaurant for dining. (It was once the Gauguin Room, specializing in Polynesian cuisine.)
Ms. Hotchner said she hoped for 600,000 visitors a year. "There's a tremendous amount that we'll bring to the mix at Columbus Circle," she said. "We will return it to the full glory of being a museum. We think that's important to everyone in the neighborhood."
Andrew M. Alper, president of the New York City Economic Development Corporation, said the museum would complement the array around Columbus Circle: the AOL Time Warner Center, now under construction; the Central Park gateway; and the Trump International Hotel and Tower.
(Donald J. Trump's bid for the 2 Columbus Circle site was turned down by the city, as was a bid from the Dahesh Museum of Art.)
The sale will be subject to the city's uniform land-use review procedure, which requires public hearings, Mr. Alper said. "This is an important project and we think it's worthwhile getting public comment," he said.
The new craft museum will have more than three times the space of the current one, which also specializes in decorative arts, architecture and interior design.
It is too early to tell whether the almost windowless facade of 2 Columbus Circle will end up still recognizable as a "die-cut Venetian palazzo on lollipops," as Ada Louise Huxtable, the architecture critic of The New York Times, described it in 1964.
Though the museum has not yet chosen architects for the renovation, Ms. Hotchner said the facade would almost certainly be changed. "We'd like the museum to add to the architectural landscape of New York," she said.

HEADLINE: Dollar Hits A 2-Year Low Against Euro 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 20 

 BODY:
The dollar, after rising sharply in value for years in a reflection of American economic might, is weakening markedly, mirroring concern about the fragility of the economic recovery and the nation's financial condition.
 The dollar fell to a two-year low against the euro today and also edged down against the Japanese yen, continuing a months-long slide. The decline came after new data showed that the United States trade deficit had widened to what some economists said was a worrisome level. 
 The monthly trade deficit in goods and services rose in April to $35.9 billion, a record, as rising exports were swamped by an even bigger increase in imports. A broader measure of the country's international financial standing -- the current account balance, which measures investment flows as well as trade in goods and services -- also posted a record deficit of $112.5 billion for the first quarter, the Commerce Department reported. 
In late trading today, the euro was worth 96.52 cents, up from 95.67 cents a day earlier. The dollar was worth 123.37 yen, down from 123.82 yen.
Since January, the dollar has lost 7.8 percent of its value against other major currencies, according to an index compiled by the Federal Reserve, after rising 33 percent since the mid-1990's. While the dollar is still strong or even overvalued by some measures, its downturn has become pronounced enough that many economists judge it to be at the start of a correction that could continue for some time.
A declining currency would have both positive and negative effects. It would help American manufacturers by making their products less expensive in foreign markets, thereby increasing exports, and could allow domestic manufacturers to recapture sales in the United States by making competing imports more expensive.
But a steady fall in the dollar could put upward pressure on inflation by pushing up import prices, and would make foreign travel more expensive. If the fall in the dollar led investors from abroad to stop putting their money into stocks and bonds in the United States -- and there is already evidence of such a pullback -- interest rates could rise and stock prices could fall further.
Analysts said the dollar's decline appears to have been driven in large part by concern among investors that the United States is not bouncing back as strongly as first hoped from last year's recession. 
But they said it was accelerated by other factors, including fear of terrorist attacks and concern after the Enron scandal that more companies will turn out to have overstated their earnings and hidden their liabilities. The Federal Reserve's decision to hold interest rates at very low levels has also held down returns on dollar-denominated investments.
While sticking to its official position that it supports a strong dollar, the Bush administration has shown no inclination to intervene in currency markets to support the dollar's value. As a result, investors have concluded that the administration is content to allow the currency to slide, at least for a while.
The crucial question for the economy is whether the erosion in the dollar, should it continue, will be gradual and orderly, as it has been so far, or whether it will turn into a rout that could destabilize the financial markets and endanger the recovery.
"We're probably going to see a substantial decline in the dollar over the next 12 months," said Robert D. Hormats of Goldman Sachs International, the investment firm. 
"A gradual decline in the dollar shouldn't be surprising and shouldn't be disruptive," he said. "It would be helpful in improving the outlook for the U.S. economy by boosting U.S. exports. But a very sharp decline would induce foreign investors, and indeed U.S. investors, to get out of U.S. financial assets."
When countries run large trade and current account deficits -- in effect consuming more than they produce -- they must make up the gap by borrowing and attracting investment from abroad. 
History suggests that no country can go on financing an expanding trade deficit forever. And though there is a spirited debate among economists about when the United States might reach that point, the dollar's current slide suggests that foreign investors are already scaling back the flow of capital into the United States and putting more of their money into stocks, bonds and business ventures elsewhere.
One outcome, economists said, is a cycle in which a growing current account deficit spurs an exodus by nervous foreign investors, pushing up inflation and interest rates and putting the already weak economy into a stall.
But even a more benign result, in which the dollar remains under pressure but does not collapse in value, could still leave Wall Street on edge.
"Let's be clear: the ballooning trade deficit is reason to sell the greenback," said Kenneth T. Mayland of Clear View Economics, a consulting firm in Pepper Pike, Ohio. "We risk seeing a flood of dollar selling as everybody tries to get through the door at the same time." 
Jay H. Bryson, an economist at Wachovia Securities, said there were signs in today's report on the current account deficit that the pace of foreign investment in the United States was slowing substantially. He said that private foreign purchases of American securities ran at an annual pace of about $260 billion in the first quarter, compared with $400 billion last year, a 35 percent decline.
Clyde V. Prestowitz Jr., president of the Economic Strategy Institute, a Washington research organization, said it was impossible to know for sure how lengthy and pronounced a slide was in store for the dollar.
"But we've known for a long time that the dollar has been at the way upper range of its value," Mr. Prestowitz said. "We've known for a long time that the trend of the current account deficit is unsustainable, and we've known that the longer it goes on the greater the chance that the adjustment could be disorderly. Now we're at the beginning of an adjustment and we have to hope it's an orderly one."
Laurence H. Meyer, a former Federal Reserve governor, said the currency's strength was likely to be influenced mostly by whether the American economy rebounded convincingly this year. 
"It's not that there's a better place to invest right now," he said. "It's just that people are concerned about the vulnerabilities of the U.S. economy."

HEADLINE: Leading Indicators' Rise Is Above Expectations 

BYLINE:  Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 20 

 BODY:
A crucial index of United States economic activity rose in May, signaling that the economy could pick up momentum in the second half of the year, a business research firm said today.
 The research firm, the Conference Board, said its index of leading indicators rose 0.4 percent in May after posting a revised 0.3 percent drop the previous month. The board's chief economist, Ken Goldstein, said the data pointed to a slow recovery with strength in consumer spending and investment. 
 The April decline, originally reported at 0.4 percent, was the first since September, while the increase last month surpassed the expectations of Wall Street economists, who had forecast a 0.2 percent increase. 
"What we have in the first half of the year is a weak recovery with pockets of strength," Mr. Goldstein said.
"There is no risk of a double dip," he said, but added, "we are not looking at a roaring recovery yet."
The Labor Department reported today that first-time claims for jobless benefits declined slightly last week, suggesting only modest improvement. The claims remained below 400,000 for the third consecutive week, dropping by 2,000, to 393,000, in the week ended June 15 from a revised 395,000 the previous week. This was not as low as Wall Street expectations for a fall to 387,000 from the 390,000 originally reported for the week ended June 8.
Among the leading economic indicators, 5 of the 10 rose in May -- led by money supply, weekly jobless claims and consumer expectations. 
Four components -- including stock prices and new orders for consumer goods -- fell. The average workweek remained unchanged for the month. 
Consumer spending, which accounts for most of the gross domestic product and has fueled the first-quarter bounce in the economy, went through a "temporary moderation" in recent months, said Mickey Levy, chief economist at Bank of America.
Yet despite this, "the recovery is already unfolding," Mr. Levy said. 
The question, Mr. Goldstein said, remains how much of a recovery will occur in the vital area of capital investment and when. 
He minimized the impact of Wall Street's ups and downs on a broad economic recovery. "We could see an economy improving without an improving stock market," he said.

HEADLINE: Charitable Contributions in 2001 Reached $212 Billion 

BYLINE:  By STEPHANIE STROM 

 BODY:
The bleak economy and the shock of terrorism failed to appreciably depress charitable giving last year, the latest annual survey by a major fund-raising group shows.
 Americans contributed $212 billion to charity in 2001, a 0.5 percent increase over the previous year when they gave $210 billion. 
 But adjusted for inflation, giving fell 2.3 percent, roughly twice the drop experienced in recent recessions. 
"I'd call that a modest drop," said Leo P. Arnoult, chairman of the American Association of Fundraising Counsel Trust for Philanthropy, which compiles the survey, Giving USA. "Don't lose sight of the fact that it's the largest amount of money ever given by Americans, in spite of two big reasons for uncertainty."
Charitable giving represented 2.1 percent of the gross domestic product, up from 2 percent last year. Before 1999, when it reached 2.1 percent, it averaged 1.8 percent of economic activity, Mr. Arnoult said.
Giving by individuals accounted for roughly three-quarters of charitable contributions, or $160.72 billion in 2001, a 1.7 percent decrease when adjusted for inflation. Personal income, which has a significant influence on individual giving, grew at the slowest rate since 1993.
Corporate giving, which accounts for 4.3 percent of total contributions, plummeted 14.5 percent when adjusted for inflation, reflecting the 18 percent average drop in corporate profits. United Way campaigns around the country have reflected this decline, though over all, United Way contributions are up.
The impact of a volatile, falling stock market was reflected in the amount of giving derived from bequests, which fell 7.1 percent adjusted for inflation to $16.33 billion last year, and in a 2.3 percent inflation-adjusted drop in giving to educational institutions, which tend to receive a lot of appreciated stock as gifts.
Foundation giving was up to $25.9 billion, a 2.5 percent inflation-adjusted increase, which reflects the peculiarities of the foundation budgeting process. Foundations set their budgets a year in advance and are required to pay out at least 5 percent of the value of their endowment to retain their tax-exempt status.
If the value of their endowment falls because of a decline in stock prices, foundations often stick to their budgets and adjust for the lower value the next year. Thus, experts contend foundation giving will fall this year, reflecting the shrinking of foundation endowments in 2001.
The biggest surprise in the Giving USA report was the sharp increase in giving to human services agencies, which received $20.71 billion, or 11.9 percent more on an inflation-adjusted basis than in 2000. 
Mr. Arnoult said the preference for giving to human services agencies reflected their increasing sophistication with fund-raising and heightened public awareness of the sector after Sept. 11.

HEADLINE: Panel to Look for Banned Corn 

BYLINE:  Reuters 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, June 20 

 BODY:
An environmental commission set up under the North American Free Trade Agreement said today that it would investigate reports of transgenic corn growing in southern Mexico. 
 The commission is responding to concerns that imported transgenic corn has contaminated native crops. 
Scott Vaughan, head of the economy and trade division of the panel, the Commission for Environmental Cooperation, said genetically modified corn was a "huge issue" for Mexico and warranted additional investigation. 
 The results of the inquiry, in the southern state of Oaxaca, could come in nine to 10 months, he said. 
The commission is an environmental body set up under Nafta, which joins the United States, Mexico and Canada. Commission scientists from the three countries are to begin the investigation in mid-July. 
The cultivation of transgenic corn was banned in Mexico in 1998 amid fears that it would contaminate the hundreds of wild creole varieties growing in Mexico, believed by many to be the birthplace of corn. 
But scientists from the University of California at Berkeley published studies last year saying they had found transgenic corn, also known as genetically modified corn, in the mountains of Oaxaca.
The results from Berkeley have been challenged since then, though the scientists and local groups maintain that the mutated corn is still spreading in the Oaxaca Sierra.
Genetically modified crops are plants spliced with foreign genes to help them resist drought and pests. No health risks have proved to be linked to the consumption of transgenic corn.

HEADLINE: With No New Taxes or Emergency Cash, Albany Won't Play Hero for City 

BYLINE:  By SHAILA K. DEWAN

 BODY:
When local governments complain of financial burdens too heavy to bear, Albany often comes to the rescue, plugging budget holes with millions of dollars in state money. But for New York City, the pumping heart of the state's economy, that has not held true.
 The new state budget has given New York City little more than permission to sink deeper in debt. And Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has been quick to acknowledge that he does not want to be unrealistic in his requests to Albany. 
 But fiscal analysts say the state has actually helped worsen the city's finances, through actions taken both before and after Sept. 11.
In October, in one of their first actions after the terrorist attack, Albany leaders finalized a budget that eliminated a $114 million payment the city had gotten every year starting in 1978.
"There's no two ways about it," said E. J. McMahon, a budget expert with the Manhattan Institute, a conservative research center. "It's little short of amazing how little the state has done for the city."
Albany officials protest that charge, saying they lobbied hard in Washington to win $21.5 billion in federal aid to the city. The governor has committed $40 million to promoting tourism; the first ad featured himself. He takes credit for persuading the federal government to pay for 100 percent of the disaster cleanup costs, instead of the usual 75 percent, said a spokesman for the state budget office, Kevin C. Quinn.
"Despite its own unprecedented fiscal challenges, the state has been working every day since 9/11 to help the city recover both fiscally and economically," Mr. Quinn said.
Yet the state has increased its overall spending by 6 percent, including a health care package that requires the city to raise wages for its employees. Critics have complained that the health care deal was politically motivated to help Governor Pataki in an election year.
"I would have more sympathy for the state saying 'We have our own fiscal problems' if they hadn't done a multibillion-dollar health deal a week before the budget came out," said Elizabeth Lynam, a senior research assistant at the nonpartisan Citizens Budget Commission in Manhattan. "The state is not acting like it has a fiscal crisis."
Some state measures related to 9/11, like refunding income tax to the families of victims or extending Medicaid coverage, will actually cost the city. But there is some good news in this year's budget: the city got a slightly higher percentage of total school aid than in the past.
The percentage of state school aid the city receives figures in a longstanding contention that New York City gets less than its share of state funds, for everything from economic development to environmental cleanups. But in the late 1990's, when the city was running a surplus, the argument that the city should get more carried little weight.
In 1999, the Legislature abolished the city's commuter tax -- it would now be worth an estimated $500 million a year -- pointing to the city's robust finances. Although the economic picture has changed drastically, no one is hustling to restore that revenue stream.
The big-ticket items on the state's list of relief for the city involve nothing more than permission: to borrow $435 million against money the state has owed the city for years, to collect a business-investment tax that the state and federal governments have chosen to forgo, to refinance debts and to raise the cigarette tax (with Albany taking half the proceeds).
By contrast, the state bails out other local governments with cash, albeit much less than a city the size of New York might require. This year, under a program once known as aid to distressed cities, Buffalo will receive $49 million. Yonkers gets $47 million. The city of Auburn, population 28,500, gets $1.1 million. Nassau County, which was on the brink of self-inflicted bankruptcy, will get the second of five $20 million installments. New York gets nothing.
Some fault Mayor Bloomberg for not asking for more, particularly in a year when the city could make a strong case for sympathetic ears. The mayor asked Albany for $400 million from a menu of requests, many of which, like debt refinancing, would cost the state nothing.
Democrats have complained that the Republican mayor has protected the Republican governor by not making difficult demands. Mr. Bloomberg, who has argued that new taxes would be impossible for Albany in an election year, did not ask for an income tax surcharge, as the City Council had suggested, or restoration of the commuter tax. (He did, however, ask for the $114 million back. The answer was no.)
William Cunningham, the mayor's communications director, said the modesty of the mayor's requests was born of pragmatism. "The goal was to close the gap," he said. "It was not to drive an agenda. It was not to look valiant carrying a banner that you knew would never get over the line."
Yet the package of benefits, which passed in Albany last night, falls short of the $400 million -- by some estimates far short.
State officials say the difference has been made up by other measures, like a tax amnesty program that is expected to reap $20 million. Another $50 million is a loan purchase, a short-term windfall. The costs of one stimulus measure, nine days of tax-free shopping in Lower Manhattan, will be borne by both city and state.
Albany could have provided much more help, say critics like Jonathan Bowles, research director of the Center for an Urban Future, a nonpartisan policy research group. 
"The city's facing a structural economic problem, including the loss of half a dozen companies, and the best they can come up with is a couple of tax-free holidays and allowing the city to raise its cigarette tax and parking fines?" Mr. Bowles said. "That's pathetic."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: In Albany, Compromise Proves Elusive 

BYLINE:  By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr.

DATELINE: ALBANY, June 20 

 BODY:
Clergy members would be required to report allegations of child abuse to the authorities under a tentative agreement between the Senate and the Assembly today, one of the few compromises lawmakers forged on the last official day of the legislative session.
 But as the day wound down, it became clear that the Republicans in control of the Senate and governor's office would not reach agreements with the Assembly's Democratic majority on a host of significant bills. 
 So little progress was made by the evening that the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, reversed his longstanding opposition to extending the session and said he would call back the Senate next week if agreements could be hammered out with the Assembly speaker, Sheldon Silver.
Deals were scarce today. A tentative deal reached last week on a bill to ban smoking in restaurants across the state fell apart after the Republicans insisted on carving out an exception for small restaurants. Lawmakers also failed to resolve differences over how to reduce the state's lengthy sentences for drug crimes enacted in the 1970's under Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller. 
Gov. George E. Pataki, a Republican seeking a third term, also could not find common ground with the Assembly Democrats on how to change the clean-up standards for toxic waste sites. Neither could he persuade the Democrats to pass a raft of bills aimed at giving state and local police greater authority to investigate terrorist organizations.
All day, the halls of the Capitol were jammed with well-dressed lobbyists, advocates and protesters. Senior citizens in red T-shirts, wheelchair-bound protesters and former inmates jailed for drug crimes swarmed through the Capitol, buttonholing elected leaders and urging them to forge compromises on bills.
Late in the evening, the two houses passed a bill that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg had requested to help the city close a $5 billion budget gap. The bill saves the city $125 million by allowing it to collect taxes on business investments that the state and federal government have agreed to forgo this year as part of an economic stimulus package.
The mayor had asked for an additional $400 million, but the package is worth between $300 million and $370 million, depending on whose estimates are used. The measure gives the city the authority to raise taxes on cigarettes and telephone service, both wireless and conventional, as well as increases fines for parking violations. The bill would also provide money for recruiting teachers and let the city refinance some of its debt.
The Senate Republicans held the tax package up for a day after the governor and the Assembly Democrats tried to tack on a $17 million appropriation for training teachers in the city. The bill finally passed after the Assembly Democrats agreed to add a sweetener for the Senate Republicans -- more aid for school districts upstate and on Long Island.
The Assembly and Senate also passed a bill sought by the rental-car industry that would allow companies to again charge customers a $9-per-day fee to avoid liability for any damage to the car from a collision. New York State banned the fees, known as collision damage waivers, in the late 1980's, after a scandal involving rental car companies charging customers for bogus repairs. 
Proponents of the bill said that forcing companies to absorb the costs of damaged cars had put many small rental companies out of business. They also argued that most people were covered under their private car insurance or through their credit cards.
But critics characterized the fees as a lucrative giveaway to rental-car companies without exacting any promise in return that rates would decline or the companies would stop what some call discriminatory practices. "This gives away the store to companies that will pocket the difference with no commitment whatsoever to clean up their business practices," said Assemblyman Alexander B. (Pete) Grannis, a Democrat from Manhattan who led the fight against the bill on the floor.
Governor Pataki has not said whether he will sign the bill. "We're going to take a look and review the details," Joseph Conway, a spokesman for the governor, said.
Perhaps the most important bipartisan agreement reached today adds priests and other clergy members to the list of professionals, like teachers and doctors, who must report credible allegations of abuse within a family. More than 20 professions are now on the list.
Under the tentative agreement, the new law would also expand what these professionals must report. Not only must they report allegations of abuse within a family but abuse by others as well. Family abuse would be reported to social workers in the State Office of Children and Family Services. Abuse by others must be reported to the police.
The bill calls on religious organizations to review the last 20 years of their personnel files and to turn over any old allegations of abuse to the authorities. Failing to report an allegation would be a Class A misdemeanor, punishable by up to a year in jail and a $1,000 fine. Prosecutors could only press charges for incidents of abuse within the last five years. Clergy members would not have to report anything they learned during sacred confession in a church or some other temple.
The bill was sparked by the scandal over the sexual abuse of teenagers and children by Catholic priests, though it covers all religious groups. Legislative leaders and the governor had agreed in principle to the bill last night, but lawyers were haggling over some of the language.
One worry was that the bill's provisions were too broad and would force, for instance, a doctor or social worker to report teenagers who are having consensual sex to the police. Those flaws were expected to be ironed out on Friday, and the legislative leaders said they hoped to pass the bill as early as next week. The Assembly will return on Tuesday, and Senator Bruno said tonight the Senate would return once final agreements were reached on several bills.
Late in the evening, Mr. Pataki and the two legislative leaders announced that they had reached an agreement on legislation to create the crime of identity theft, punishable by up to seven years in prison. The bill would make it illegal to steal Social Security numbers, addresses, drivers' license numbers, credit card numbers or codes for automatic teller machines with the intent to commit a crime. Some criminals use this information to apply for credit cards, take out loans or raid bank accounts.
The deadlock over how to shorten the state's lengthy sentences for drug crimes seemed only to worsen today. A group of former inmates who had received 15-year-to-life sentences under the Rockefeller-era laws met with the governor to urge him to work harder to find a compromise with Mr. Silver.
Afterward, some blamed Mr. Pataki for the impasse. On Wednesday, the governor and Senate Republicans passed a bill that only reduced sentences for Class A offenders, who currently receive 15 years to life. More than 200 people in prison would be immediately eligible for release if the bill passed.
But family members of prisoners and former inmates said the bill was a cynical attempt to get them to choose between possibly freeing their loved ones or holding out for a more comprehensive overhaul of the laws.
"We hold Governor Pataki responsible for the breakdown in negotiations," said Elaine Bartlett, who served 16 years in prison for delivering 4 ounces of cocaine to a dealer in Albany. "They need to go back to the table. People are doing crazy time for small amounts of drugs."
Mr. Silver reiterated his position that he would not pass a law affecting only the top category of offenders. He said it would give the governor the ability to say he had reformed the laws during the election campaign without doing anything for the majority of inmates, who are charged with Class B offenses.
For his part, the governor put out a statement casting the blame on Mr. Silver, saying his legal team "has been waiting for days for the Assembly to come to the table."
The legislature passed hundreds of minor bills as well. One bans the use of the fur and flesh of dogs and cats in manufactured goods like clothing and coats. The bill passed both houses overwhelmingly, much to the delight of animal-protection groups.
