PERSON: Attiyat Al-Abnoudi 

HEADLINE: THE SATURDAY PROFILE; 
Weaving Nile's Daily Life Into Dream of Change

BYLINE:  By NEIL MacFARQUHAR 

DATELINE: CAIRO 

 BODY:
THE phone rang late one evening and Attiyat al-Abnoudi picked it up to find a journalist from a leftist Egyptian newspaper on the line, asking her what she thought of boycotting products from America because of its support for Israel. 
 Ms. Abnoudi demurred. The reporter pressed and within minutes, Ms. Abnoudi was shouting. "What? I'm supposed to throw away the Avid machines that I use to edit my documentaries?" she bellowed. "The boycott is backwards, backwards, I tell you." 
 She hung up steaming. Like any Arab, she wants an end to the Israeli occupation of the West Bank, but she has no patience for tired old formulas. "They think of me as an old revolutionary who will automatically start shouting in support of the boycott," she railed. "We were talking about a boycott because of Vietnam back in the 60's. Are we supposed to go back to all that?"
The spirit of the 1960's inspired and still informs her work as a pioneer female documentary filmmaker, a career marked by 25 films that underscore Egypt's gritty social reality, particularly for its poorest. 
It is a focus that awes her supporters and inflames her critics, bringing acclaim abroad but, closer to home, charges of trading on the poverty of her country. Although she has been interviewed often on state-run television, the network never shows her films. There is no official ban; it is more that, as she told the Egyptian paper Al Ahram on winning a national award in 1998, "everybody wants you to entertain them all the time."
Ms. Abnoudi's films, shown most often internationally at festivals, have won more than 30 prizes, many in Europe. 
"We know about Egypt from 7,000 years ago by the documents they left behind," she said. "If you see my films years from now, you will know about the Egyptian people, how they look, how they dress, how they eat, how they joke, what they are like when they are sad." 
But Egyptian critics are stung by that immediacy -- the poverty and misery unflinchingly captured. "There is no need to show reality in such an ugly way," said Hosn Shah, of the newspaper Al Akbar. "I am not against showing poor people, but the films should be more sympathetic, not all those flies and the filthy little kid with a snotty nose who is naked, barefoot and lacking underpants. Don't show me people who live like animals." 
To Ms. Abnoudi's mind, such images have a purpose. She described it almost wistfully: "We had a dream that we could change our society. We thought we could change the world by showing people how they live, that showing them would inspire them to make a revolution. Instead they hated us because they didn't want to see their reality." 
She went on, "Of course I still dream about changing the world, I am still young inside, but wiser." 
MS. ABNOUDI was born in 1942, the sixth of seven children in a family of once prosperous spice and textile merchants in a Nile village. Traditionally, the eldest daughter stayed home to help until she married and the task fell to the next daughter. "But by the time the sister right above me married, I was already in university, so they couldn't stop me," Ms. Abnoudi chortled. 
She was of the generation that benefited from Gamal Abdel Nasser's granting virtually free education to all. She keeps a framed picture of Nasser but remains ambivalent about the man whose revolution shaped modern Egypt. "He opened all kinds of dreams for us," she said. "But he made all the decisions for us, he didn't want to share. We would switch on the radio in the morning and suddenly discover we were a Socialist country."
While studying law at Cairo University, she was drawn to free movies at European cultural centers around the capital. That led her, in 1968, to enroll in the first class of postgraduates accepted to Egypt's new Film Institute. Lecturers, often drawn from abroad, emphasized film as social dialogue.
Ms. Abnoudi made two short films as a student. The first, in 1971, "A Horse of Mud," focused on illiterate women earning a pittance shaping bricks from Nile mud. Shot in grainy black-and-white on 16-millimeter film, it won many prizes, assuring her a spot in an English film school and lifelong financing.
Her second film, in 1972, was her graduation thesis, "The Sad Song of Toha," which showed snippets of the lives of a troupe of bedraggled Cairo street performers. The only words were a poem by Abdel Rahman al-Abnoudi, who became her second husband after a courtship of 15 days. (She was divorced from her first, a painter, at 21.) 
Mr. Abnoudi, who became famous for reviving the folklore and music of Upper Egypt, was once jailed for six months for his open Communist sympathies.
The couple adopted their only child, the 4-year-old daughter of a friend, after the girl's father died in an accident. They divorced 13 years ago, after 20 years. Ms. Abnoudi now lives with her daughter, an actress, in an apartment in a newer Cairo suburb. They share it with seven cats.
Her early work helping her husband travel from village to village collecting myths and music found its way into her films. Local musicians often provide the soundtrack, including that of her latest film, completed this month, called "The Nubian Train."
It is the story of a special 15-car second-class train that departs from Alexandria every year, carrying Nubians back to their villages for the biggest Islamic holiday. She almost had to abandon the project. The train departed last February, a day after a disaster on another train in which hundreds of passengers were incinerated. 
The fire was started by a gas stove, and the police were taking no more chances. They confiscated lights and generators. But she decided to shoot anyway, frantically calling rental companies to deliver battery-powered lights when the train stopped in Cairo. 
The movie shows images of the passing countryside and the Nile. The Nubian songs are bluesy. The first, which plays as the train leaves Alexandria, captures the edge of melancholy on any long voyage. 
MS. ABNOUDI dresses like many of the peasants whose lives she portrays. She favors the reddish henna they use to color their hair. Her frocks, decorated with beading and embroidery, are made by a village woman who lives near the Pyramids.
Outside film, Ms. Abnoudi does not fear taking on difficult causes. She devotes much of her time to a nascent organization that seeks to get more Egyptians involved in solving the country's myriad ills. 
"I am a good citizen," she said, then added with a smile, "I wear my seat belt."

HEADLINE: One More Rally, Late in the Game, to Win Over Critics of a Newark Arena 

BYLINE:  By RONALD SMOTHERS

DATELINE: NEWARK, June 21 

 BODY:
After failing this week, in the waning days of the legislative session, to advance a measure to build a sports arena here, the owners of the New Jersey Nets and Devils are planning one final push this weekend: an advertising blitz aimed at the districts of key Republican lawmakers who are opposed to the plan or on the fence.
 The advertising campaign will test yet another of the seeming nine lives of the arena proposal, a five-year-old notion that has been unsuccessfully pressed by the administrations of three governors. 
 The newspaper advertisements will feature a long list of supporters of the proposed $355 million arena from corporate, political and civic circles, detail some of its economic benefits, and describe it as a necessity to keep the two sports franchises in the state.
The advertisements will also highlight the financial reasons the arena must open by 2005, and why legislative action is required by June 30 in order to meet that deadline. They will stress that the project will be financed by sales and income tax revenues generated by the arena and not directly by state taxpayers. 
James McQueeny, a spokesman for Newark Sports and Entertainment, the subsidiary of the YankeeNets that owns the two New Jersey teams, said the advertisements would bring together facts that had often been lost in news coverage of "the supercharged politics" surrounding the plan. 
The proposal, which would move the teams from the Continental Airlines Arena in the Meadowlands, has split Democrats and Republicans, North and South Jersey, as well as suburban and urban interests.
The advertisements will cap a flurry of activity over the last three days by the YankeeNets, Gov. James E. McGreevey and two former Republican governors to persuade lawmakers to tack the Newark arena proposal and a hockey arena in Pennsauken, in South Jersey, onto a bill authorizing a Harrison soccer arena. The bill has already passed the Assembly. Under Senate rules, the amendment requires the approval of both the Democratic and Republican leaders of the evenly split house, but John O. Bennett, the Republican leader in the Senate, refused to give his approval. The goal now, supporters said, is to build backing in key areas to prompt Republican lawmakers to pressure him to relent.
A spokesman for Mr. Bennett said the senator would not comment.
The 18,500-seat arena would be financed by a $120 million investment by the YankeeNets; $165 million in bonds issued by the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority that would be repaid from sales and income taxes generated by the arena and adjacent development; $50 million in Essex County and Newark money; and a $20 million loan from the YankeeNets and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. 
The sense of urgency is coming from the YankeeNets about a month after it seemed to accept the governor's looser timetable. That timetable called for the governor to begin planning for a replacement development in the Meadowlands -- which might build support for the Newark plan among Bergen County's residents -- before approaching lawmakers in September or October to authorize the Newark proposal.
But when the YankeeNets fretted recently that this would prevent it from opening the arena by 2005, Mr. McGreevey pressed quietly for immediate legislative action. 
One immediate result was cries from Bergen County lawmakers, who said that the governor was attempting an end run around them. Assemblywoman Loretta Weinberg, a Bergen Democrat, said that he was reneging on his promise to address their concerns about the future of the Meadowlands first.
The governor's effort was also ridiculed by a group of Republican senators who said in a statement that it was "ludicrous" to press for three arenas when aid was being cut to schools and towns.
Paul Aronsohn, a spokesman for Mr. McGreevey, did not respond to the accusations. But he said that the governor was determined to move forward on the Newark arena, the Meadowlands redevelopment and the Pennsauken and Harrison arenas. 
Supporters of the Newark arena, like the Rev. Reginald Jackson, head of the Black Ministers Council of New Jersey, said Mr. Bennett and other Republicans were exploiting the divergent interests arrayed around the arena issue to advance the party. Mr. Jackson and others also said that conservative Republicans were using the project to embarrass and intimidate moderates who might support it.
Bret D. Schundler, the former Jersey City mayor and a conservative who ran unsuccessfully for governor against Mr. McGreevey last fall, has indeed been a vocal opponent of the arena plan, insisting that it would involve state money and should go to voters in a statewide referendum.

HEADLINE: Jousting Over Drug Coverage 

 BODY:
Voters coming out of the last presidential election had good reason to believe that no matter who won, there would be federal prescription drug coverage for older Americans in the near future. Now, both the Senate and the House appear to be moving toward votes on a Medicare drug plan. The two proposals are very different, and we feel the Senate version is by far the better version. 
 There is no doubt that a drug benefit is needed. Prescription drug costs are rising faster than hospital or doctor bills. Yet a third of the elderly have no drug coverage at all, and many of the rest are poorly covered. But many Democrats and Republicans seem less interested in compromise than in a campaign issue this fall, and both versions could easily die in a Congressional stalemate. 
 The differences between the two bills relate to cost and philosophical approach. The Senate Democrats' plan comes with a price tag of more than $425 billion over seven years, roughly twice as much as the Republican House version. That is causing sticker shock among senators concerned about budget deficits and the financial difficulties of Medicare. The Senate Democrats would also have the Medicare program itself cover prescription drugs for any elderly people who want it.
House Republicans, who regard traditional Medicare as antiquated, would provide money to private insurance companies -- a big source of G.O.P. campaign donations -- to offer prescription drug policies. The idea of relying on private companies seems more ideological than practical. The pool of elderly Americans who will want the insurance is likely to consist of those who have the most need for expensive medicine. Even with federal subsidies, it's unclear that enough insurance companies would be willing to participate and provide the economies that come from competition. 
The Senate Democrats' plan is clearly more generous to beneficiaries, particularly those who buy generic drugs. There would be no deductible, and out-of-pocket expenditures would be capped at $4,000 per year. Under the House Republican guidelines, which could be modified by private insurers, the elderly would pay 20 percent to 50 percent of the first $2,000 in prescription bills. Above that, they would have to pay the full cost themselves until they had reached a cap of $3,700 or $3,800. Both plans would subsidize the elderly who have low incomes.
The House Republicans are expected to pass their bill next week, while the Senate Democratic leadership is going to have trouble overcoming all the chamber's procedural obstacles. Opponents will rail about the cost and budget deficits. That would be much less of a problem if Congress canceled some of the future tax breaks it has scheduled. This page has pointed out repeatedly that if the public were given a choice between a good prescription drug plan for the elderly and less taxes for the country's richest citizens, there's little doubt which they would choose. But the upcoming debate is time for another reminder.

HEADLINE: Filing Raises Concerns About Merck Unit 

BYLINE:  By MILT FREUDENHEIM

 BODY:
As Merck & Company prepares the initial public offering of its unit that manages pharmacy benefits next week, a regulatory filing has raised concerns about the subsidiary's future profitability.
 Although by some counts the unit, Medco Health Solutions, is the nation's largest drug plan manager, it said in a filing to the Securities and Exchange Commission that its gross operating profits had been slim and were becoming slimmer. 
 The filings, which were amended last week and spiced with new information, presumably at the S.E.C.'s request, also show that Medco's profits have been heavily dependent on rebates on products made by Merck and other drug manufacturers. The rebates are tied to assuring market share for those products. 
Medco, formerly called Merck-Medco Managed Care, has been accused in lawsuits of unduly favoring expensive Merck drugs like Zocor, a cholesterol-lowering treatment, over similar products, like Lipitor from Pfizer, that the plaintiffs say are more cost-effective.
Medco and its main competitors, AdvancePCS, Express Scripts and Caremark, use the buying power of millions of drug plan cardholders to extract discounts and rebates from drug manufacturers. They arrange lower prices to promote prescriptions of favored drugs, including lower-cost generics, and they collect small transaction fees for processing hundreds of millions of payments 
Medco has pledged to push Merck drugs for the next five years, a move that Wall Street analysts said could be risky. If sales of Merck drugs falter, they said, the rebates would shrink, sharply cutting Medco's profits. "Some customers might object," said Andrew Speller, a health care analyst at A. G. Edwards.
Contracts with some of Medco's biggest customers are up for renewal, including those of the Defense Department and the California Public Employees' Retirement System, which this week approved a staff recommendation to switch to Caremark from Medco. However, General Motors and Verizon recently decided to renew with Medco.
The initial public offering is expected late next week at a price that would value Medco at $6 billion to $6.5 billion. Merck bought Medco in 1993 for $6.6 billion, or about $8.2 billion, adjusted for inflation.
The price, about $22 to $24 a share, is roughly half the early estimates of $12 billion by most Wall Street analysts when Merck first announced the divestiture plan in January. Medco said it hoped to sell about 20 percent of the company now. Merck would like to spin off the rest to shareholders within 12 months.
Lawrence Marsh, an analyst at Lehman Brothers, said the lower valuation reflected a dip in Medco's first-quarter operating profits, and a slide in the stocks of other drug plan managers "based mainly on concerns about government investigations and various subpoenas."
Last month, Express Scripts, Caremark and the drug plan units of Cigna and WellPoint Health Networks said they received subpoenas in connection with a Justice Department investigation of drug marketing. They all said they were not the targets of the investigation.
Medco said it had been notified in 1999 that it was being looked at in another Justice Department inquiry. The company has also reported an investigation of its business by the State of Tennessee.
It said in the S.E.C. filing that its operating margins had declined to 3.2 percent in the first quarter, down from 4 percent the year before. A contributing factor, Mr. Marsh said, is that health plans and employers are demanding more and more of the rebate money that drug plan managers receive from manufacturers.
"As these rebates are more closely scrutinized, the economics of this sector could be devastated," said Larry Feinberg, a partner at Oracle Partners, a health care hedge fund that has sold shares of some of the drug plan companies' stock short. "The rebates are going to go away, and it becomes a less profitable, even a nonprofitable industry," he said.
Under a new contract with West Virginia and several other states, Express Scripts will have to surrender any rebates to those customers.
Merck, which has been struggling with weakening earnings after patents have expired and costs have risen, brushed aside a report in The Wall Street Journal yesterday that raised concerns about Medco's practice of booking patients' co-payments on drugs as revenue.
"Neither our external auditors nor the S.E.C. has ever raised an issue with our accounting," said Greg Reeves, the spokesman. He added that the revenue had "no impact on our net incomes or earnings per share." But investors drove down Merck shares by $2.22, or 4 percent, yesterday, to $49.98, a four-year low. 
Mr. Feinberg also dismissed the co-payments issue as "a nonevent" because it does not affect earnings.
As for Merck, securities analysts said its profit picture would brighten enormously once Medco's low-margin business was gone. Mr. Marsh of Lehman said, "There will be a collective cheer from Merck analysts and investors when this is finalized."

HEADLINE: Russian House Supports Bill On Farm Sales 

BYLINE:  By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, June 21 

 BODY:
Russia's lower house of Parliament today approved a bill to create a legal system for the purchase and sale of farmland for the first time since the Bolshevik Revolution in 1917. But the measure, which requires one more vote before it goes to the upper house, passed only after the government agreed to a late amendment prohibiting foreigners to own agricultural property. 
 Earlier this week, President Vladimir V. Putin played down fears that foreign companies would buy up Russian land. But his legislative allies agreed to the ban on foreign ownership on the eve of today's votes in what appeared to be an effort to mollify fears. 
 Parliament voted overwhelmingly for the ban on foreign ownership. The vote establishing a framework for buying and selling farmland was far closer, however. 
As protesters opposed to any sale of Russia's farms rallied outside Parliament, the debate inside underscored the depth of passions that still exist over Russia's slow move to a market economy, especially when it comes to its farmlands. 
The Communist leader, Gennady A. Zyuganov, called the legislation "a shameful spectacle" and warned that it would ignite civil conflict. 
On the other hand, the deputy chief of the liberal Yabloko Party, Sergei V. Ivanenko, contended that the ban on foreign ownership would worsen the investment climate and show the world that Russia was still not ready to embrace economic reforms. 
The majority of Russia's farmlands remain under the control of collective farms, whose members now own shares in the enterprise. Many shareholders lease their part of the collective back to the collective itself or to private farmers or corporations.
Michael Whitty, chief operations officer of an American company that is building a dairy farm on leased land north of Moscow, said the prohibition on foreigners could stifle investment and complicate efforts to raise capital for Russian enterprises. "If they want to establish enterprises here in Russia, with Russian partners, then it wouldn't be such big deal," he said. "If they want to establish their own freestanding property and ship the profits elsewhere, then it could have a very big effect." 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Another Tumble Gives Stocks Their Fifth Week of Losses

BYLINE:  By ALEX BERENSON 

 BODY:
Stocks skidded for a third consecutive day yesterday as investors grew increasingly gloomy about the possibility of more terrorist attacks, slowing economic growth and corporate accounting scandals.
 The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 1.7 percent, closing below 1,000 for the first time since Sept. 21, when markets bottomed out after the Sept. 11 attacks. The index now stands just 3 percent above its September low. Other indexes, including the Dow Jones industrial average and the Nasdaq composite index, also dropped sharply. 
 The decline capped another losing week on Wall Street. The S.& P. 500 has dropped five weeks in a row, eight weeks out of nine, and 14 weeks out of 16. Since mid-March, it has given up about 15 percent of its value. This week, stocks gained strongly on Monday, but the rally rapidly lost steam.
Investors have become negative, and the S.& P. 500 will probably fall to its September low before it has any hope of recovering, said Tobias Levkovich, equity strategist at Salomon Smith Barney.
"I haven't met a bull in five months," said Mr. Levkovich, who remains bullish and said he thought investors' concerns about higher inflation and economic weakness were overblown. "We have this downward momentum that is overwhelming any kind of rational behavior."
With questions about accounting practices hanging over many big companies, including Computer Associates, Tyco International and General Electric, investors are no longer willing to accept optimistic forecasts from managers or Wall Street analysts at face value, Mr. Levkovich said. Instead, they want to see rising profits and cash flow before they buy.
"Given the sense of corporate rot out there, managements not working for shareholders, there's such a sense of 'show me,' " Mr. Levkovich said.
At a news conference yesterday, President Bush acknowledged that concerns about management honesty were weighing on the stock market. "The business world must clean up its act," Mr. Bush said. "People have got to have confidence as to whether or not the assets and liabilities are good numbers. They've got to have confidence that the leadership has got the shareholder and employee in mind when they make decisions."
The Bush administration has not taken a public position on legislation in the Senate that would toughen the oversight of accountants.
Losses yesterday were broad and deep. The S.& P. 500 fell 17.15 points, to 989.14. The Dow Jones industrial average skidded 177.98 points, or 1.9 percent, to 9,253.79, and the Nasdaq composite index fell 23.79 points, or 1.6 percent, to 1,440.96.
Frank Holmes, the chief investment officer of U.S. Global Funds, which manages $1.3 billion, said he thought stocks would continue to fall. Even though the S.& P. 500 has lost a third of its value in the last two years, and the shares of many technology companies have fallen 80 percent or more, most stocks are still expensive, he said.
Companies continue to cut back on capital spending, and corporate investment in information technology remains dismal, Mr. Holmes said. Yet the average Nasdaq stock is still trading at 80 times earnings, far higher than the historical norm, he said.
Mr. Holmes said he was looking for companies that would benefit from a falling dollar. With the federal budget now in deficit and short-term Treasury bills paying less than the inflation rate, the dollar will probably decline, he said. If that happens, American consumer companies, like McDonald's, could benefit, he said.
Morton Cohen, general partner of Clarion Partners, which manages $180 million, said he thought many small technology stocks had fallen to bargain levels. Some companies are trading for less than the value of cash on their books, he said.
But Mr. Cohen said he thought the outlook for the broader market was bleak. Growth is anemic, and the risk of inflation is increasing as the budget and trade deficits rise and the dollar falls, he said.
"The overall market still looks like it's going lower," Mr. Cohen said.
Flight-to-safety buying raised the price of Treasury securities yesterday, as hefty declines in the stock market prompted buying. Also, a warning from the Federal Bureau of Investigation that terrorists may try to use fuel tanker trucks as weapons in the United States or abroad took bond prices higher.
The price of the benchmark 10-year Treasury note rose 5/32, to 100 26/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 4.77 percent, from 4.79 percent on Thursday. The 30-year bond rose 12/32, to 99 20/32, with its yield falling to 5.40 percent, from 5.43 percent.

HEADLINE: All in the Family 

BYLINE:  By Richard H. Brodhead; Richard H. Brodhead teaches American literature at Yale University, where he is A. Bartlett Giamatti Professor of English and dean of Yale College.

 BODY:
 HERMAN MELVILLE
A Biography.
PUB-DATE: UNKNOWN 2, 1851-1891.
By Hershel Parker.
Illustrated. 997 pp. Baltimore:
The Johns Hopkins University Press. $45.
 American lives have no second acts, F. Scott Fitzgerald famously said, but some do receive second volumes. Many years ago Hershel Parker set out to write the biography to end all biographies of Herman Melville, a book in which everything that could be known about the writer would be pieced out and put on record. Having pursued this quarry with a single-mindedness worthy of a Melville hero, Parker has brought this project to its conclusion with a second 900-plus-page volume to match the one he published in 1996.
Parker's first volume told the story of an exhilarating rise. The descendant of Revolutionary War heroes on both sides, Melville was born in 1819 to a status and prosperity that abruptly vanished when his father failed in business. Allan Melville died insane, leaving his wife to raise eight children on the scant funds wealthy relatives would spare. Herman, the second son and third child, was put to work at an early age, making his way aimlessly from clerking through school teaching to another job that required no economic outlay, the life of a common sailor. Having sailed on a number of vessels, Melville came ashore in his mid-20's and, hanging around his mother's house, wrote up the adventures he had after jumping ship in Polynesia. By happy luck his brother found a publisher, "Typee" (1846) became a success, and Melville found himself a writer. 
He repeated this success and consolidated his fame. But as he continued, the work he had mastered with little effort or forethought became a far more absorbing activity. In the late 1840's Melville rediscovered writing as the means by which to unfold his emerging powers of mind, a pleasure he found virtually addictive. From this point Melville began to write obsessively, in ever bolder departures from the popular forms of his first successes and with ever grander visions of his artistic gifts. "So far as I am individually concerned, & independent of my pocket, it is my earnest desire to write those sort of books which are said to 'fail,' " this proud new Melville wrote in 1849. Two years later, having just turned 32, he completed "Moby-Dick" -- the book whose publication closes Volume One.
But the same willfulness that produced this masterpiece had other consequences as well. In the middle of writing "Moby-Dick," Melville impulsively decided to move his family to the Berkshires, buying a farm and taking out two separate mortgages on the property (the second of which he long kept secret). Parker's first volume ends with Melville relishing the fruit of his impetuousness; the second shows him learning its price. 
For "Moby-Dick" was badly reviewed and helped to harden Melville's reputation for having swerved from his real talent into some strange, incomprehensible new line. The novel's lack of success led publishers to slash Melville's advances, so his earnings fell just as his family grew. His family shared the public's literary tastes far more than they did Melville's own, and he found himself surrounded by people who saw his ambitions in an increasingly dim light. Having missed the annual payments on the second mortgage, he saw his economic position became a source of growing stress and shame.
Melville did some of his best work under these painful conditions ("Bartleby the Scrivener" and "Benito Cereno" are from this time), but his early exuberance did not survive. Already by his late 30's, a man who had once been a picture of robust health was often ill, with his family only too happy to have him travel for his health. By the age of 40, having virtually given up writing for publication and then having failed in a career as a lecturer, Melville stopped even pretending to work for a living, becoming a dependent of his wealthy father-in-law. 
After 1866 Melville worked for nearly 20 years at a low-end job as a customs inspector, avoiding threatened layoffs but suffering a pay cut from $4 to $3.60 a day. When he gave in to literary ambition once more and wrote the long poem "Clarel," the strain was more devastating than ever, and the result was no new success. His publishers made him sign an agreement to pulp the remaining copies after this book sank like a stone.
Parker tells this story with a thoroughness that is scarcely to be believed. Nothing is summarized in this biography, nothing foreshortened; this demon researcher treats every phase of Melville's life as equally significant and tracks down (and writes up) every last fact. He is helped by the fact that masses of correspondence turn out to have survived from Melville's publishers and the many members of his extended family -- a trove so rich that virtually each week of Melville's life can be chronicled, often in multiple accounts.
Parker's work with these materials produces a picture of Melville's life that is extremely detailed in some dimensions but curiously thin in others. Scholars will be grateful for Parker's skill in filling in obscure chapters in Melville's writing life. One tour de force is his reconstruction of the composition of "Pierre; or, The Ambiguities," the successor to "Moby-Dick." Having worked out the timing of the rapid deterioration of Melville's literary position in 1851-52, Parker shows how Melville interpolated his resulting rage into the new manuscript, with predictably disastrous results. 
Equally interesting are Parker's surmises about works Melville never published that did not survive. He makes the case that in 1852-53 Melville wrote a novel based on materials he shared with Hawthorne about a sailor who deserted his wife. If this is true, then the theory that Melville renounced writing after "Pierre" is just wrong, and the mysterious leap from "Pierre" to the work he published after a silence, the very different "Bartleby the Scrivener," can be explained in a new way. Parker is also convinced that Melville prepared a volume of poems in 1860 that failed to be published. If this is so, a stretch that had seemed empty of literary strivings was instead a time of new effort and new failure -- a black hole Parker alone has the instruments to detect.
Parker's other achievement is his reconstruction of Melville's family life. Melville lived in continuing close contact with his mother, all his brothers and sisters, and many Melville and Gansevoort aunts, uncles and cousins -- a huge extended family that was further amplified when he added his wife's family to his own and when his siblings married and had children. Many of these figures are lovingly particularized in the book, which is really a biography of the Melville clan as much as of its now famous member. Parker's fascination with the ephemera of supporting actors' lives will exceed that of many readers (many a paragraph begins with a sentence like "Both Kate and Allan had serious dental work that year"), but the day-in, day-out chronicle of family doings has a cumulative effect. Parker reminds us that Melville's life was never only his writing life. He did that work amid the fulfillments, irritations and sheer chronic busyness of a larger life shared with others.
Parker's love of this family and its abundant records does mean, however, that matters not treated in those records tend to vanish from his view. Space is always available for another visit with Tom Melville, the lovable youngest brother, who became governor of the Sailors' Snug Harbor on Staten Island, but Parker has little time for history beyond family history. The 1850's crisis over the extension of slavery receives little more than a nod, the election of 1860 -- precipitant of the South's secession and the Civil War -- is barely mentioned, and the agony of Reconstruction receives perfunctory acknowledgment in a sentence that turns to the Melville women and the hard time they had finding servants. Parker suggests that Melville "was unwilling to respond to any present national crisis directly." But whether he was truly unengaged by the dramas of his time or whether (as seems more likely) that story is just uninteresting to Parker, the absence makes a strange gap.
The bustle of family doings tends to blot out dimensions of Melville's inner life as well. Parker does an admirable job of reconstructing Melville's reading, always a crucial part of his intellectual life. But what was so absorbing to Melville himself -- the will to understanding that he felt working itself out in him in rapid, self-revising leaps -- is harder to document and gets less play. No reader of Melville's fiction will have failed to feel the force of his religious curiosity, that driven, skeptical yet strangely resourceful intelligence with which he attacked questions like the nature of the world's creator or the value of Christian charity. Melville's few intellectual intimates knew the obsessional power of this side of him. After renewing their acquaintance in 1856, Hawthorne wrote: "Melville, as he always does, began to reason of Providence and futurity, and of everything that lies beyond human ken, and informed me that he had 'pretty much made up his mind to be annihilated' " -- that is, that there is no afterlife -- but still he does not seem to rest in that anticipation. . . . He can neither believe, nor be comfortable in his disbelief; and he is too honest and courageous not to try to do one or the other." But this part of Melville's character left little record outside his novels and a few reported conversations, so it plays little role in Parker's account. In Parker's story, Melville's religious life is largely a matter of his mother's efforts to make him go to church. 
Readers will need to turn to other sources to find these missing dimensions, but for all that, Parker's book has much to teach. In addition to the many episodes that he fills in or sets straight, he reminds us just how problematic writing was for Melville, how shrouded it was in personal risk and cost -- and how stubbornly he kept at this work, even late in life, when he did it almost wholly in private. (The manuscript of "Billy Budd" was found in his desk when he died.)
 Parker also deserves credit for filling in the darker half of Melville's life without making it a melodrama of misunderstood genius. The temptations to caricature are large in this volume, but Parker's doggedness defeats them. On one memorable page, tired at last (after a thousand pages!) of Mrs. Melville's chatty cliches and obtuseness to her husband's woes, Parker hauls off and rips into her for her failures to recognize and support his genius. But he knows that Melville was far from faultless as a husband, and, following them through their daily rounds and endless family visits, he builds the recognition that there was something between them, however imperfectly they met each other's needs. In his telling, Melville was certainly also a self-absorbed parent; for Christmas this man once gave his children bound volumes of a periodical he wished to own. But Parker refuses to let him harden into a caricature of egotistical tyranny, and he reports the sorrows these parents endured -- the suicide of their eldest son, the second son's emergence as a ne'er-do-well, the disabling rheumatism of their daughter Bessie -- without blame or exoneration.
What we cannot know, but the main thing this book makes us wonder, is what different life Melville might have led and what different work he might have done if his talents had met with a different reception. The first glimmers of the fame he would enjoy in the next century began to reach him in his last years, and when Melville reached his late 60's his wife even inherited a fortune. But by then the rising talent of 1851 was too old to get much good from this long-withheld support. Melville died in 1891 at the age of 72.
