HEADLINE: In Following a Dream, A Bit of Reality Helps 

BYLINE:  By JULIA LAWLOR 

 BODY:
THE success stories are enticing: Lawyer chucks it all to become a circus clown. Investment banker moves to Tuscany to grow olives, get a life. Hard-driving high-tech manager opens an ostrich farm, lives happily ever after.
 It never hurts to dream, especially when you're in a rut at work. With jobs scarce, the temptation for the resume to stray in other directions is great. Moreover, close to half of all baby boomers are now in their 50's, many itching to fulfill a youthful ambition before it is too late. Why not pursue that hankering to become a singer in a mariachi band, or a ski instructor in Switzerland? 
 Not so fast, says John Challenger, chief executive of Challenger, Gray & Christmas, a Chicago outplacement firm. "In most cases, we try to convince people not to make a radical change. Most go after it for the wrong reason, and they don't understand the ramifications in terms of money and position of authority." 
Sometimes, they are just sick of doing the same old thing and yearn to try something new. Sometimes, they have been laid off and can't find jobs in their fields, and so shop around in unfamiliar terrain. And sometimes, especially since Sept. 11, they want to do something more meaningful.
But unless they have done a lot of research, their experiment can backfire. "Often, people who choose a whole new career have to go back to entry level," Mr. Challenger said. "The result is that after a few years, they wish they hadn't done it."
Or maybe after a few days. Joe Bierman, 42, vice president for marketing in Manhattan for Sephora, the cosmetics retailer, did not have to take a cut in pay or position when he switched from a marketing career at Avon to a sales position at Fairchild Publications in 1999. He had just received his M.B.A., and after 10 years in the cosmetics business, wanted something new. 
But he realized right away that he did not like sales. "It is just enormously focused on a single thing -- closing that sale," Mr. Bierman said. "Publishing could have been more lucrative, but marketing used my creative skills more. I'd wake up in the morning with the feeling of not being challenged." Less than a year later, he was back in marketing, and happy again.
For many people, of course, switching careers can be liberating. Although the government does not track how often Americans do it, it calculates that they change jobs at least eight times on average by the time they are 55, so they do have some practice in starting over again.
And a study released in April by DBM, a human resources consulting and outplacement firm in New York, found that 72 percent of unemployed professionals changed industries (but not necessarily professions) in 2001, up from 52 in 1999, while 16 percent went into business for themselves, up from 7 percent three years ago.
Beth Burdick, managing consultant for DBM, has noticed an increase in the number of laid-off executives considering career changes lately. "Losing a job allows people time and space to reflect on their life," she said. "I'm hearing many people say things like, 'I had a really good career as a software engineer, but I want to do something different with my life.' "
But, she warns, they shouldn't make such a move lightly. "If you're thinking of doing something completely different, you have to go out and collect data," Ms. Burdick said. "If you want to run a bed and breakfast, spend time with people who do this. It's more than just serving tea and cookies, smiling and handing someone a map. Be there when there's a guest who's not happy, no matter what you do."
Sometimes a person will have the bright idea of making a business out of a hobby, she says, only to find that it loses its charm when it becomes a money-making proposition. "I knew a senior-level program manager in high tech who liked gardening, so she took a job with a landscaper," she said. "But she found that although she liked gardening, she didn't want to do it eight hours a day."
Some people mistake their dislike of an unpleasant aspect of their job, like a surly boss or a grinding corporate culture, for an aversion to the job itself. Change the setting, and they're fine, Ms. Burdick says.
Other people learn that a steep drop in income that they initially accepted as a trade-off for a job they love "is too much of a sacrifice," she said. "They may end up getting pressure from their family. If you have to worry every time you go to Starbucks whether you can afford it or not, is it worth it?"
In some cases, making the round trip from one career to another and then back again can take decades. Rena Thorsen, 50, of Basking Ridge, N.J., left a 60-hour-a-week job that she loved as a merchandising manager for Bamberger's department store 25 years ago for a 9-to-5 job giving training courses for corporations so that she could spend more time with her four children. "I switched to the corporate world so I could have regular hours, weekends and holidays off," she said. "But it was never the love of my life. I did it because I had to." 
Last year, the online education company Ms. Thorsen worked for closed and she began looking for another job in the same field. Then Sept. 11 happened. "Why aren't I doing what I love to do?" she asked herself. With her children grown, Ms. Thorsen decided it was time to return to her roots. In February, she and some partners opened iforstyle.com, which enables women entrepreneurs to sell jewelry, cosmetics and other goods online.
It was also a search for a saner existence that led Fernando Urroz, 51, of San Jose, Calif., to make the switch in 1988 from the world of high technology to the restaurant business. Mr. Urroz was a senior business consultant for Hewlett-Packard, traveling often and commuting more than an hour each way. 
"My wife and I had one child then, and we said there has to be a better life than this," he recalled. Since Mr. Urroz had worked as a chef before getting his computer science degree, the couple decided to buy a restaurant in Healdsburg, a small town north of the city, in Sonoma County.
The restaurant was so successful that their dream of a laid-back life quickly faded. Mr. Urroz spent seven days a week there, barely able to see his three children. The pressure was almost worse than it had been in the field that he had fled. "We were featured in Gourmet magazine once, and I remember a woman walking in with a photo of a particular dish from the magazine, saying, 'I want this,' " he said. When he arrived in Healdsburg, he bought a mahogany-hulled speedboat so he could go fishing on Sonoma Lake. It stayed in the garage. By the time the recession hit in the early 1990's and business fell off, the couple was almost relieved.
In 1995, Mr. Urroz sold the restaurant and then spent a year consulting, studying up on all the technology he had missed while he was a chef. Finally, he landed a job with Hewlett- Packard again as a regional sales and marketing manager.
"We joke that we had to slow our lives down by going back into high tech," he said. "I was back to 10-to-12-hour days; I had weekends and evenings off; I could take vacations. It was great."
In 2000, he left Hewlett to take a job with LSI Logic Storage Systems, but was laid off early this year. He has been approached about going back to the restaurant business, but one detour on the road to happiness was enough for Mr. Urroz. "I wouldn't go back to doing that," he said. "I love my family too much."

HEADLINE: ART/ARCHITECTURE; 
If the Chair Fits (or Challenges), Settle In and Listen

BYLINE:  By WENDY PERRON; Wendy Perron is a senior fellow at the Vera List Center for Art and Politics at the New School University.

 BODY:
ON a weekday afternoon last month, three 10-year-old girls were hanging out at the Langston Hughes Community Library and Cultural Center in Corona,, Queens, talking about capital punishment. They had just spent an hour with the installation "A Chair Is a Throne Is a Freedom Fighter's Camp Stool," moving from seat to seat and listening on headsets to stories on CD's. Chair No. 17 represents an electric chair, and the sound track tells of a young man who, in 1946, simply would not die from electrocution. Spurred by this bit of history, the girls debated the execution of the Oklahoma City bomber, Timothy McVeigh, last year. 
 "They should throw him in jail and starve him to death," Johanna Sanchez said. 
 But Michelle Franco argued: "It doesn't really matter if you kill him. The people he blew up aren't going to come back to life." 
Jerri Allyn, the artist and educator who created the installation, called Chair No. 17 "the darkest chair." Of the 21 chairs in the show, which is now in the Port Richmond Library in Staten Island until Thursday and then travels to Brooklyn, the Bronx and Manhattan, describe people who have solved conflicts peacefully. (Ms. Allyn calls them "portraits.") Words silk-screened on the seats inform viewers of alternatives to violence: from the therapeutic power of art to a "Bikes Not Bombs" program for teenagers; from Gandhi's civil disobedience to Nelson Mandela's restorative justice.
The chairs are made of walnut, birch, mahogany and other woods. Some are cube shaped like Donald Judd's furniture, with right angles, pleasing proportions and hard seats. Others have scooped out seats in the African tradition, while still others resemble triangular Mexican stools. As the seat -- or site -- of an idea, each chair and audio portrait allows the viewer, in Ms. Allyn's words, "to sink into another person's world." (The sound design is by Helene Rosenbluth.)
Once you sit on one of these chairs and put on the earphones, you want to close your eyes and absorb Ms. Allyn's narrative. Her voice -- urgent, plaintive, lilting into awe or wonder -- carries you from a terrain of violence into a terrain of hope. Sitting in Chair No. 2, a half-moon poplar stool, one hears about a South African tribe's custom of encircling a ne'er-do-well and showering him with compliments. Then Ms. Allyn relates her own effort to apply this ritual in a classroom, which ends with the class bully beaming happily.
As a ceramics major at the San Francisco Art Institute in the 70's, Ms. Allyn never bought the myth of the artist as a lone genius; she hungered for a connection to the outside world. 
"I was a really good art student," she recalled. "I went to all the exhibits the teachers told us to go to. Who I saw there were other artists, instructors and students. I didn't see the public. I wasn't interested in being isolated or ghettoized within the art world."
She was attracted to minimalism for its meditative qualities but felt it was limited. "I remember at the institute we were all taken up to the roof, where somebody had put up a neon piece that said, 'Art Is.' There's an aspect of the art world that is art about art. In my early days I just hated it." 
In the mid-70's, the Feminist Studio Workshop, housed in the Woman's Building in Los Angeles, generated a surge of activity in performance art and new media. The founding artists rejected the male-oriented hierarchy of the art world and championed collaboration and accessibility. Suzanne Lacy, a magnet in that milieu who later became known for large-scale urban performances, crossed disciplines to highlight issues like violence against women. 
"The Feminist Studio Workshop taught that art doesn't just pop from nowhere, that it develops within a political and economic context," said Ms. Allyn, who assisted Ms. Lacy in many projects. "The questions were, 'What are you trying to say, and who do you want to say it to?' That shifted everything for me." She found a freedom to experiment with different media and to draw thematic material from life experience. The feminist credo "The personal is political" was a driving force. 
Teaming up with other women, Ms. Allyn formed a performance-art group called the Waitresses, making use of the metaphor of women as servers. Since all of the women had waited on tables, the art-and-life connection was strong. 
The art historian Arlene Raven, a founder of the workshop, recalled: "They made amazing performances in restaurants, where you didn't see art performed. It was startling, new and very fresh. Jerri was the conceptual power behind some of that activity. She has a strong social consciousness that she was able to translate into her art." Ms. Raven also praised the originality of Ms. Allyn's voice -- her "Jerriness."
Ms. Lacy recalled a 1979 event: "My favorite image is the Waitresses All City Marching Band. It was hysterical -- 40 women in white waitress uniforms with red aprons!" (This band, in which Ms. Raven played kazoo, was in the DooDah Parade, an alternative to the Rose Bowl Parade.)
As a member of Sisters of Survival, a performance-art group with an antinuclear message, Ms. Allyn wore a nun's habit and danced the twist. From there it was a short skip to work for Lily Tomlin in the 80's, helping her with research on a book project. Ms. Allyn admired what she called Ms. Tomlin's "vision of promoting eccentric individuals."
Groups like the Waitresses and Sisters of Survival were inspired by the workshop, but they also trace their artistic lineage to avant-garde artists like Allan Kaprow, who helped invent the "happenings" of the 1960's. 
Choosing libraries as sites for her work reflects Ms. Allyn's desire to bring art into people's daily lives. She has staged performances in her bed (for seven days), in a dairy restaurant, at the Los Angeles City Hall and in outdoor plazas. Each performance is at least partly shaped by the participants. "A Chair" is still evolving, with five seats left undesignated, awaiting material that Ms. Allyn is gathering from the audience in each borough about a local peacemaker.
As an artist who uses words, Ms. Allyn feels an affinity for Jenny Holzer and Barbara Kruger, especially when their subject is abuse of power. But whereas the messages of those two artists can be ambiguous or cryptic, Ms. Allyn aims to lead the viewer to action. "I'm almost obsessed with letting people know that there are a lot of resources out there," she said, "things we can learn, from personal strategies all the way up to international diplomatic solutions." 
Ms. Allyn, who trains New York City public school teachers in integrating the arts into the curriculum, says she wants "A Chair" to extend eventually beyond the five boroughs, perhaps even to the Middle East. "I am such a small fry that it seems completely insane," she said. "Why do I think this can really effect any change?" 
Answering her own question, she points to herself as an example of transformation through art. "I was born into trouble," said Ms. Allyn, who is 50 and whose parents divorced when she was 7. "I moved 21 times by the time I was 21. In the 10th grade I was running away on weekends, sleeping on the floor of the Port Authority. I was an unwed mother at 18 and placed my son with an adoptive family because I could barely take care of myself." 
But the impulse to create was instilled at an early age. Her mother, an interior designer, and her father, a woodworker, engaged her in art projects at every opportunity. Another plus, she says, was being brought up as a Quaker. "The Quaker community was the one place that was stable in my life," she said. "They taught me a profound sense of social consciousness."
Ms. Allyn identifies with children who are considered "at risk" and reaches out to them in "A Chair" with workshops and discussions. (A full schedule can be found on www.interactionarts.org.) The installation, which is sponsored by the Lower Manhattan Cultural Council, a nonprofit group, will visit libraries in all five boroughs by September.
Ms. Allyn knows the challenge of finding one's way to nonviolence. Being able "to talk something through, rather than blast someone with my anger" has taken her years to learn. "If I can figure this out, anyone can," she said. 
In words chanted during the narrative of Chair No. 4, she credits art with being a catalyst for change: "Art never leaves you where it found you."

A Chair Is a Throne Is a Freedom Fighter's Camp Stool
New York Public Library,
Port Richmond, Staten Island.
Through Thursday.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Jerri Allyn, above, with her chair installation at the Port Richmond library in Staten Island. At right, from left, Debra Wanner, Ben McVey, Margot Lowery and Joseph Lowery listen to the piece's narratives. (Photographs by John Patrick Naughton for The New York Times)

PERSON: PERRON, WENDY; ALLYN JERRI 

GEOGRAPHIC: NEW YORK, NY, USA (88%); OKLAHOMA CITY, OK, USA (79%) NEW YORK, USA (88%); OKLAHOMA, USA (79%) UNITED STATES (88%)

HEADLINE: MUSIC; 
New Operas Are Booming, But the Bold Aren't Heard

BYLINE:  By ANTHONY TOMMASINI 

 BODY:
AMERICAN orchestras may be grappling with dwindling audiences and the indifference of the young, but opera companies are doing quite well. Attendance, overall, is up. It's not that the general directors of opera companies have been boldly reinventing what they do. The public just seems more interested in opera.
 One reason, certainly, is the adoption of supertitles or other text projection systems by virtually every American opera house. The technology has demystified the genre. All of a sudden, even neophytes get it: "Ah, opera is theater! I can just sit back and take in the show." 
 What's more, titles may be fostering the most important trend in opera today: a notable increase in the commissioning and presentation of new works. This assertion may seem a stretch, since most new works reaching American houses have English librettos. Yet as younger, eager audiences have been enticed into the opera house by supertitles, the natural curiosity for the new that exists among fans of theater, dance and film has affected operagoers as well. 
More new works are being developed and produced at America's opera houses than at any time since the post-World War II period, when a contemporary-opera boomlet was fostered by general economic prosperity and a serious commitment to the performing arts among corporations, private foundations and even television networks (until the rocking 60's declared high culture elitist). Savvy administrators have noticed the growing openness to new works and responded in their programming. And that's great.
What's not so great, however, is the timidity of their choices, which has resulted in a lot of earnest but forgettable works. General managers gravitate to composers who hew to what are deemed accessible musical styles: lush neo-Romanticism, folksy Americana, a halfhearted Minimalism that rejects the truly radical repetitiveness of the early, and best, operas by Philip Glass. Commissions tend to go not to bold composers but to marketable projects.
There are "Masterpiece Theater" operas, like Stephen Paulus's musically staid "Summer," introduced by the Berkshire Opera in 1999 and revived this month by the Center for Contemporary Opera in New York. There are operatic spinoffs from plays and films, like Andre Previn's "Streetcar Named Desire," which was unveiled at the San Francisco Opera in 1998. Though Mr. Previn's score, true to form, was harmonically rich, lyrically opulent and tellingly orchestrated, the music did not begin to match the impact and poetry of the Tennessee Williams play or its classic film version, directed by Elia Kazan.
But at least Mr. Previn was a veteran composer. The San Francisco Opera knew what it was getting and gave him lots of leeway. These days it's more typical for a company, worried about alienating its audience, to seek out a less experienced composer willing to be an obliging member of a large production team.
Stewart Robertson, the music director and principal conductor of the Glimmerglass Opera in Cooperstown, N.Y., and of the Florida Grand Opera in Miami, concedes that companies have been too wary. "A lot of what is being commissioned and performed is, frankly, very conservative," he said recently. Company administrators have been a bit myopic, he added. "They tend to think of the operatic world only, and not what else is being done in music in orchestras and chamber ensembles."
Still, the status quo is changing, he said. The Florida Grand Opera will open its new house in 2004 with the premiere of a work based on Tolstoy's "Anna Karenina" by David Carlson, a California composer Mr. Robertson believes in.
Two new American operas are enjoying widespread success. Mark Adamo's "Little Women," based on the Louisa May Alcott novel, was introduced by the Houston Grand Opera in 1998. Jake Heggie's "Dead Man Walking," based on Sister Helen Prejean's book about a Louisiana execution (though the devastating film directed by Tim Robbins was the real impetus), had its debut at the San Francisco Opera in 2000. So far, 16 companies have picked up one or the other of these works. "Little Women" arrives at the Glimmerglass Opera in Cooperstown, N.Y., on July 6; "Dead Man Walking" opens at the Cincinnati Opera on July 11. Both come to the New York City Opera next season.
It's remarkable to see two new American operas on such a roll. Yet, musically, I want more from new operas than these scores provide. Mr. Adamo understands the voice and has an instinctive sense of dramatic pacing. But, musically, he takes a self-conscious tack in adapting the novel. In the scenes of daily domesticity, his music is beguilingly lyrical. In reflective monologues and scenes driven by plot, he spikes his language with 12-tone elements to give the music some gnarly anxiety, to reveal the angst and erotic stirrings within the restless sisters. But the atonal passages sound heavy-handed. Less is more in this score. The simpler, sweetly tonal music is the most satisfying.
I did not see the San Francisco production of "Dead Man Walking," which, by all reports, was boldly theatrical. My impressions of Mr. Heggie's ambitious score come from the live recording on the Erato label. Before this work, Mr. Heggie was known for songs that artfully flatter the human voice. Here he shows a gift for melodic writing and laces his tonal language with shards of dissonance and jazzy riffs. His polyglot style, beholden to Bernstein, incorporates vernacular song and dance.
But the polemics and horror that permeate this story would daunt a greater composer than he. The massed crowd scenes just sound congested. As Bernard Holland, who reviewed the premiere for The New York Times, put it, when the big ensembles "do take on a certain power" in the last scenes, "credit more the raw, visceral drama surrounding the music, less the music itself."
Opera companies, like major orchestras, forever say that it's their risk-averse audiences who balk at challenging contemporary fare. But what happened when the New York City Opera celebrated its 50th anniversary in 1993 with three premieres on three consecutive nights? The hit of the series was not Ezra Laderman's stylistically muddled "Marilyn" (about the last years of Marilyn Monroe's life) or Lukas Foss's charming but slight children's opera, "Griffelkin." It was Hugo Weisgall's biblical opera "Esther."
Weisgall's score was craggy, dense, saturated with dissonance -- and completely riveting. Here was an uncompromising, impassioned musical voice. The audience sat rapt, then cheered Weisgall, 81 at the time, ecstatically. Why has the City Opera not brought the work back?
Opera is drama, yes, but drama driven by music, which is why innumerable works in the repertory move and thrill us despite having pronounced dramatic flaws. Like Verdi's "Simon Boccanegra," with its Bermuda Triangle of an opera plot: sail in, and you may never find your way out. Yet Verdi's gravely beautiful music somehow ennobles the opera's ill-defined characters.
EUROPEAN companies have been far more willing to commission formidable composers. The Finnish-born Kaija Saariaho had a major success at the Salzburg Festival in 2000 with "L'Amour de Loin," which receives its American premiere next month at the Santa Fe Opera. Ms. Saariaho provided a mystical, richly hued and intriguingly complex score to a fascinating French libretto by Amin Maalouf about a young prince in 12th-century Aquitaine. Sick at heart from his pampered life, he falls into idealized love with a countess in Tripoli whose virtue and beauty he has only heard about. Coming 10 months after Sept. 11, the opera's exploration of the cultural gulf between West and East should be newly meaningful.
Also in 2000, the Royal Danish Opera presented the premiere of Poul Ruders's opera based on Margaret Atwood's futuristic novel, "The Handmaid's Tale," in which Christian evangelicals have taken control of a large swath of the wanton, environmentally wasted United States and established a male-controlled totalitarian regime. Though the opera is somewhat convoluted, Mr. Ruders, an audaciously inventive composer, has written a wildly compelling score. The work receives its American premiere at the Minnesota Opera next year.
Music is paramount in the operas of the British composer Judith Weir, like her brilliant 1987 work, "A Night at the Chinese Opera," a play within a play about a group of Chinese actors forced into labor during the reign of Kublai Khan. Even if it were not so theatrically imaginative, Ms. Weir's music would captivate you. Listen to the first 30 seconds of the 1999 recording on the MMC label, and you start thinking: "What are those weird, slashing, wondrous orchestral chords? How did she do that?"
I'm not suggesting that only thorny musical languages have value. John Harbison, the composer of "The Great Gatsby," introduced by the Metropolitan Opera in 1999 and revived this spring, is essentially a pungently chromatic tonal composer. But he is a masterly technician and erudite musician whose voice is completely authentic, deftly drawing on the atonal rigor of his teacher Roger Sessions, on his own deep experience with sacred music and on an abiding love of early jazz.
Two projects on the horizon offer hope that American opera companies are ready to put more trust in strong composers. In 2004, the Glimmerglass Opera will give the premiere of Stephen Hartke's adaptation of a Guy de Maupassant story, "Boule de Suif," with a libretto by Philip Littell. The opera ("The Refugees" is its working title) concerns a sundry group of French people as they flee an enemy advance during the Franco-Prussian War. Mr. Hartke, 49, who teaches at the University of Southern California, has won acclaim for orchestral and chamber works that meld an astringent harmonic voice with fidgety rhythmic vitality and what could be called lucid complexity.
It surely helped in bringing about the commission that Mr. Hartke arrived at the bargaining table with part of his own commissioning fee: an award from the Institute for American Music, financed by the Howard Hanson estate and administered by the Eastman School of Music in Rochester. More critical was the presence at that table of Mr. Robertson, of Glimmerglass, a great admirer of Mr. Hartke's music. "Stephen's work," Mr. Robertson said, "while not wildly modern, has real compositional muscle to it."
Though this will be his first opera, Mr. Hartke has an ambitious agenda. "My opera will have no flashbacks, no outside narrator," he said in a recent interview, "none of those devices that smack of embarrassment with the medium of opera, of being unable to live with the unreality of the form." He is determined to avoid the "forced lyricism" that, he said, mars many operas of recent years.
In another heartening commission, the San Francisco Opera has asked Lewis Spratlan for a one-act work as part of its Aspects of Faust series, conceived by Pamela Rosenberg, the company's adventurous general director. Titled "Earthwise," with a libretto by Constance Congdon, a colleague of Mr. Spratlan's on the faculty of Amherst College, the opera tells of a scientist retiring from a research post who decides to select a successor from among three clones of herself.
Mr. Spratlan, 61, came to Ms. Rosenberg's attention through his opera "Life Is a Dream," based on the Spanish play by Pedro Calderon de la Barca. Inexplicably, the opera has never been produced despite snagging the Pulitzer Prize for music in 2000. It was commissioned by the New Haven Opera Theater, but by the time Mr. Spratlan completed it in 1978, the company had folded. For years he sought a production and was repeatedly turned down, no doubt, as he suggested in a recent conversation, because of the score's gritty atonal style.
"Opera company directors have made up their minds, wrongly I think, that the public is not interested in what might be called modernist music," Mr. Spratlan said. "The whole nature of our musical culture today is that we've passed by that ugly time of difficult works into a period of tunefulness and accessibility."
In 2000, the opera's second act was performed in a concert version, first at Amherst and then at Harvard. When it won the Pulitzer, Mr. Spratlan was elated, he said, thinking that "the sheer panache" of the prize would compel some company finally to produce the thing.
No such luck. It has apparently still proved too thorny for fearful general directors: a shame, for Mr. Spratlan's score is impressive. That the work is eminently performable despite its challenges was proved last month when the City Opera presented Act II as part of its Showcasing American Composers series, in which excerpts from new works and operas in progress are performed in open readings. With just one rehearsal under the conductor George Manahan, the singers and the City Opera orchestra gave a confident account of Mr. Spratlan's glittering score.
The City Opera would be a logical company to produce this honored work. It deserves credit for at least giving the piece some exposure. In just four years, the Showcasing American Composers series, now under the artistic guidance of Mr. Adamo, the company's current composer in residence, has become invaluable. Administrators, conductors and the operatically curious public can attend free readings and sample a roster of new works.
The venture has already produced success stories. Two years ago it presented excerpts from Scott Wheeler's "Democracy: An American Comedy," with a libretto by Romulus Linney based on novels by Henry Adams. In attendance were representatives of Placido Domingo and the Washington Opera, which Mr. Domingo runs. This exposure led to the unfinished work's being commissioned for the company's young artists program, which began operations in March.
Mr. Spratlan, though consoled by the San Francisco Opera commission, is "in calm despair" over the languishing fate of "Life Is a Dream," he said. Companies wary of music like his, he added, "should put more trust in audiences."
First they have to put more trust in composers. That overdue process may have begun.

HEADLINE: ART/ARCHITECTURE; 
Art Becomes an Instrument to Unearth Buried History

BYLINE:  By KAY LARSON 

DATELINE: CHARLESTON, S.C. 

 BODY:
AT night on a heaving sea off the shore here, the Morris Island lighthouse seems to walk on water. Its sand spit is sinking and so is the post-Civil War lighthouse. At high tide the island disappears, and a needle of brick appears to float upright in a foaming blackness.
 The searchlight was dismantled 40 years ago, but in Kim Sooja's installation, "A Lighthouse Woman," for the Spoleto Festival USA the lighthouse itself glowed in colors from a bank of lights at its top. Starting with luminous cherry red and moving through spectral grape and the whole rainbow between, plus white, one color slowly faded into another, at a pace like breathing. 
 From a boat, with the lights of Charleston cut off by the curvature of the earth, the lighthouse seemed to join the parade of ghosts that inhabit this former slave port. No longer focused toward the ships it used to guide, the lighthouse now seemed to regard itself in the not-unpleasant glow of self-reflection. 
The meditative mood has infected the whole Spoleto art program, "Evoking History," which is on view through Aug. 4. (The music, theater and lighthouse phases of the festival ended on June 9.) The curator, Mary Jane Jacob, a white woman, has devised a three-year series of installations and community discussions, which is generating an impassioned conversation about art's potential for catalytic social activism. Some works from the initial series last year -- David Hammons's six-foot wide, two-story house, a project about gentrification, for example -- can still be seen in neighborhoods around town. Ms. Kim's lighthouse, and the other projects this year, have taken oblique aim at slavery and its complex legacy. 
The past is not hard to find in Charleston. Morris Island was the site of the 54th Massachusetts regiment's suicidal charge against a Confederate fort, memorialized in the movie "Glory." But hauntings these days are more often disembodied -- the parking lot that once held the auction block where slaves were sold, or the crumbling building where slaves were professionally whipped for a fee to shield the sensibilities of slave owners -- and buried in memory.
To excavate and heal, artists and curators have forged unusually intense bonds with local people, including two black sisters, Rebecca Campbell and Catherine Braxton, who grew up in a pair of decrepit houses that are the focus of a snowballing community oral-history movement. The community was Ansonborough, called the Borough, the poorest of the poor of Charleston, but a place of fierce loyalties and mutual aid. 
The Borough was nearly wiped off the map during recent urban renewal. What's left is a barren expanse of grass and the two empty houses, starkly picturesque with their red roofs, black shutters and peeling white clapboards: Edward Hopper meets Porgy and Bess. (DuBose Heyward set his 1927 novel, "Porgy," in a tenement on Cabbage Row off Church Street, morphed now into a tony boutique.)
An inheritance delivered the houses to Ms. Campbell, Ms. Braxton and a cousin. Last summer they were considering renovating, but something told them to wait, Ms. Campbell said. A month later, they got a call from Ms. Jacob and her co-curator, Tumelo Mosaka, a black South African bearing his own family history of displacement, who was moved to tears by the sisters' stories of their childhood. 
Nosing around, Ms. Jacob and Mr. Mosaka discovered a whole neighborhood, now vanished, existing only in the memories of its former inhabitants. Mr. Mosaka, who is living in town for the three years of the art program, began interviewing. "These people's sense of history is not what the city of Charleston is interested in," he said. "Somebody needs to break that silence."
As the oral-history project blossomed, Suzanne Lacy, a white California artist and practitioner of socially engaged art arrived in town to create an installation for Spoleto. She asked instead to turn one of the sisters' houses into a youth center and Borough history interviewing site, as a way of bearing aesthetic witness to the everyday life of ordinary people. 
The other house is temporarily home to "Cottage Industry," a textile and sewing project by J. Morgan Puett -- a white woman from Atlanta, now living in Pennsylvania. Ms. Puett has an archivist's passion for clothes and an improvisatory eye for their construction. She joked that she has compressed 300 years of fashion history into one set of garments, manufactured by seamstresses at the house. 
The clothes she presented in a wryly funky fashion show on a platform in front of the house did have the plantation persona -- not the Hollywood Tara look, but the cobbled-together air of the handmade and hard-pressed. Her models -- two young women, one black, one white -- were dressed in public by four others, provoking reflections of what it means to be unable to put on your own clothes.
The houses and the lighthouse serve as two points in the triangle of exhibitions called "The Memory of Water." The third point is the Drayton plantation, up river. The sisters' family is buried in the old slave graveyard at Drayton, which is now a historic-trust site. Ms. Kim -- a South Korean-born New York resident -- prepared a set of four carpets for the floor of the Drayton mansion. The carpets are black -- jarring within the 1742 mansion's faded pastels -- and in white are names of people from the Drayton inventories: Boat Jack, Dumplin, Poor G, Fatima, lad, girl, boy, African. Those with last names lived after the Civil War.
The carpets' simplicity has a bite. People step on them seemingly without seeing them. Your breath catches in your throat, as it does when the tour guide explains the history of the mansion and the graveyard without once uttering the word slave.
Does courtesy shade into denial? "Where is the history of African-Americans in Charleston?" Ms. Campbell said. "I want the truth." 
The barren ground that was the Borough appealed to two black artists: the Jamaica-born Nari Ward and the Martinique-born Marc Latamie, both now residents of Manhattan. Mr. Ward attempts a complicated metaphor involving a palmetto tree cast in a mixture of concrete and iron filings, enclosed by glass walls inscribed with fragments of interviews with Borough residents. The palmetto is shown at several stages of its life cycle. This palmetto "nursery," visibly rusting, refers perhaps too abstrusely to simultaneous growth and decay, but the sight of a 26-foot-tall iron tree in a hot field has its own startling appeal.
Growing up in Martinique, Mr. Latamie had a chance to muse on the global shipping routes that created both the slave trade and the current itinerant lifestyle of artists like himself, who ply their installations all over the world. In the Borough lot, he built a shack resembling his favorite corner store in Martinique and stocked it with the foods he grew up on -- all, except rum, manufactured in France for export.
Food for Mr. Latamie is a kind of ammunition in the global cultural and economic wars, speaking of nurture and of the will of those in power to withhold nurturing. So for his second work, a one-shot, he imported the Martinique master chef Jean-Charles Bredas and his assistant, Richardson Skinner, to Middleton Place, a plantation next door to Drayton. They served a fine island meal of spiced pork tenderloin, baked plantains and eggplant to the several dozen people -- local and not -- who had been talking all morning about art and education. The slave cabin outside the windows did not visibly curb any appetites.
The flow of outsiders may yet bring healing energies into Charleston -- perhaps altering the karma created by the first outsiders. The sisters may hail from the Borough, but they worked in New York for decades. As a social activist, Ms. Campbell said she is most proudof helping to establish the League of Women Voters in Harlem. The sisters had never paid attention to the arts, but now they are so involved they took Mr. Latamie shopping to stock his store. 
"I didn't know about installation," said Ms. Campbell, the more talkative of the sisters. "I'm learning all the technology. It's beautiful." 
Charleston resists its past, said Edward Ball, a local white resident and winner of a National Book Award for "Slaves in the Family," a candid account of the Ball plantations. "There is a culture of intentional forgetting, purposeful forgetting, which is observed by both black people and white people," he said. "For black people, it's a traumatic memory that has to be controlled. They are reminded of it on a daily basis."
White southerners, he said, are convinced that their loss in the Civil War was as great as the suffering of black people in slavery. "Our sense of self and memory," he continued, "has to be asserted over every competing memory of the past, because it was so traumatic and painful."
Mr. Ball himself seems infected with an intelligent and observant sadness -- perhaps caused in part by his family's vehement response to his book. Some welcomed it, but most saw it as dangerous. A cousin warned Mr. Ball that if any harm came to his two young daughters as a result of the book, he would hold its author personally responsible.
Ms. Campbell and Ms. Braxton are energized rather than cowed. They have vowed to continue the oral-history project and to memorialize the houses and the hidden life of black Charleston. 
"Believe me, Rebecca Campbell knows what she's doing," Ms. Campbell said of herself. "I've been in bigger projects than this." 
Retired now, with money, time and skills honed outside, these two insiders may yet turn Charleston inside out.

The seamstresses, from left, are Mary Larimore, Jerushia Graham, Sarah Sophia Turner and Ursula Arsenalt. HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living In/Stony Brook; 
A Hamlet Where History Stays Alive

BYLINE:  By JOHN RATHER 

 BODY:
STONY BROOK, a culturally and historically endowed residential hamlet of moderately priced to expensive houses in Suffolk County's town of Brookhaven, owes much to Ward Melville, the visionary philanthropist who strove in 1940 to reconstruct the village with a blend of housing, business and culture in a New England-like setting. 
 Mr. Melville's vision remains intact 62 years later in the crescent-shaped village center, regarded as the first planned shopping district in the country and the core of one of Long Island's outstanding public spaces. 
 The center, with more than 40 shops, restaurants and service businesses, looks down over a two-acre village green toward Stony Brook Harbor. At mid-crescent, a Federalist-style post office is topped by a mechanical eagle that flaps its wings on the hour from 8 a.m. to 8 p.m. Mr. Melville, who headed the Melville Corporation, a major national footwear, apparel and drug retailer. insured the water view by buying up property and moving houses out of the way, relocating historic ones and razing others. 
In a stream of philanthropy over three decades, Mr. Melville also bought and renovated historic structures, including the Three Village Inn and a grist mill built about 1751; purchased 88 acres of wetlands where a marina was threatened; and, with his wife, Dorothy, established a museum. 
Most of the properties were bequeathed to the Ward Melville Heritage Organization, which remains the steward. A board of volunteer trustees and a paid president are in charge. The organization runs education programs, organizes seasonal family events and acts as landlord of the village center, which includes separate shopping areas called the Inner Court and Market Square. 
"There is very little you can do here or talk about that doesn't have something to do with Ward Melville," said Joyce Miraglia, the organization's community relations manager. The organization is also building a new educational and cultural center behind the Inner Court.
With the neighboring areas Setauket and Old Field, Stony Brook it is part of what is known as the Three Village area although Old Field is the only one that is actually a village. Stony Brook itself has two distinctly different sections. 
Lush, densely foliated and secluded, the residential areas along the winding and hilly roads in the hamlet's northern section are comforting to the eye. Older colonials and storybook cottages exude charm. Houses in the Southern sections, generally west of the Stony Brook campus of the State University and south of Route 25A, are newer, and the look is more typically suburban. 
The entire hamlet is within the Three Village Central School District, a highly regarded system that is a prime attraction for home buyers with children. Census figures show that more than 30 percent of residents moved in between 1995 and 2000.
The school district is also a common bond in the Three Villages area. "The schools are the unifying force; they tie everyone together," said Mitchell H. Pally, a school board member, vice president of governmental affairs for the Long Island Association and a Stony Brook resident for 16 years. 
As in many communities on Long Island, prices have been rising in the tight Stony Brook housing market despite the weakened national economy. "The mortgage rates are down, and there are a lot of buyers out there," said Andrea Kozlowsky, an associate broker at L. Ross Realty in Setauket. "There's just not that much inventory."
The $500,000 that Melville spent to reconstruct the village center would not be enough today to buy an older colonial near the water in the hamlet's northern part, where prices range from about $400,000 for cottages to well over $1 million for prime colonials. Newer homes in Forsythe Meadows, developed about 15 years ago, sell in the low $700,000's.
In the more affordable area of the hamlet south of Route 25A, Capes, ranches and colonials built by William Levitt beginning in the mid-1960's sold in the low $200,000's five years ago but now sell in the low to mid-$300,000's. The hamlet's median house price of just under $200,000 10 years ago is now only a memory. Rental houses go for $2,000 a month and up for three-bedrooms. 
There are no rental apartment complexes or co-ops. The Knolls at Stony Brook, a 180-unit condominium that opened in 1983, rarely has vacancies. "As soon as they go up, they sell like anything," said Sidney Reich, a board member of the owners' association. Mr. Reich said two-bedroom units were about $230,000 to $250,000. Six and eight-unit clusters make up the one-level complex, which has a pool and a recreation center.
Strathmore Gate, an older condominium complex for people 55 and older, is also in the hamlet. Prices are about the same as at the Knolls and vacancies are infrequent.
THE Three Village School District, a sprawling system joining Stony Brook, Old Field and Setauket, has five elementary schools for kindergarten through Grade 6 (there are no prekindergarten programs), two junior highs for Grades 7 through 9 and Ward Melville High School for Grades 10 through 12.
District enrollment, currently about 7,600, has grown from 6,870 10 years ago but still lags far below the district's peak of more than 10,000 students in the early 1970's.
Last year about 95 percent of the 466 graduates of highly regarded Ward Melville went on to higher education; 73 percent enrolled in four-year colleges or universities. About 78 percent of the graduates earned Regents diplomas. Average scores on the College Board were 559 in verbal and 564 in math. Both scores are more than 50 points above the statewide averages. Test scores in other grades are also above state averages.
The district is noted for a strong music program, the high numbers of students competing in state and national academic competitions, programs for students with special needs and a science research program for top achievers. "There are very high expectations for all the students," said John Sonedecker, the superintendent.
But despite its stature in the community, the district is not without problems. In May, voters rejected a $113 million school budget that would have increased the school tax rate by almost 13.9 percent. A vote on a revised budget is scheduled for Tuesday.
A lack of commercial and industrial properties leaves homeowners to pick up the school bill.
The Stony Brook School, which describes itself as a Christian college preparatory school, enrolls 375 students in Grades 7 through 12. Many take advanced placement courses and nearly all go on to higher education. Students are from Long Island and beyond. Fees range from $9,500 for day students in seventh grade to $25,150 for seven-day boarding students.
The State University of New York at Stony Brook, built in 1962 on land donated by Melville and since expanded, bears the hamlet's name but has a separate ZIP code and a limited town-and-gown connection with residential Stony Brook. Few students live in the hamlet. 
But Stony Brook is home for some of the university's administrators and 1,682 faculty members and also for employees of the Brookhaven National Laboratory, an Energy Department research laboratory in nearby Upton, and of the Stony Brook University Hospital and the adjacent Health Sciences Center.
The Stony Brook campus, which has nearly 1,200 acres, had an enrollment this spring of 13,646 undergraduates and 7,209 graduate students. It is the site of the Staller Center for the Arts, where a seventh annual film festival showing independent feature and short films, many making their United States or East Coast premieres, runs from July 17 to 27. Passes to more than 40 films cost $40.
A Melville legacy, the Long Island Museum of American Art, History and Carriages, is situated on nine acres near the Stony Brook village center. Admission to exhibits in its three separate museums is $5 for adults, $4 for students and free for museum members and children under age 6. 
A Brookhaven town beach open to all town residents is adjacent to the West Meadows Wetlands Preserve, the 88-acre parcel preserved by Mr. Melville. Naturalist-led wetlands cruises offered by the Ward Melville Heritage Organization aboard a 35-passenger boat, the Discovery, run from May to October. Tickets are $15 for adults and $9 for children under 12. 
A town boat ramp is located near the village center, as is the Stony Brook Yacht Club, a private club founded in 1913. Club membership is for Brookhaven residents only.
AN entrance to Avalon, a private garden established by the Paul Simons Foundation, is near the village center across from the grist mill. It is open to the public. A wooden boardwalk running along the west side of the Mill Pond leads to walking trails. 
Near the hamlet's southern rim is the Smith Haven Mall, with nearly 1.4 million square feet of retail space and more than 160 stores. Other commercial areas are along Route 25A and Route 347. Nicolls Road, which passes through the Stony Brook campus, eases access to major east-to-west arteries including the Long Island Expressway. Some rail commuters bypass the Long Island Rail Road station in Stony Brook for the railroad's more heavily serviced Ronkonkoma station, about a 20-minute ride away.
The Setalcott Indians inhabited the Three Village area when English settlers arrived in Stony Brook in the mid-1600's. By the early 1800's the hamlet was shipping cordwood to New York and developing as a significant port. 
A sea captain, Jonas Smith, purchased a homestead on the harbor in the mid-1800's; it survives as the Three Village Inn, a popular restaurant and hotel. By early in the 20th century the hamlet had become a resort. But it was fading by the 1940's, when Ward Melville stepped in.

HEADLINE: Supermarkets Square Off In Glen Cove 

BYLINE:  By STACY ALBIN 

DATELINE: GLEN COVE 

 BODY:
FREDERICK GAHAGAN said the spotty parsnips and the rotten eggplant annoyed him but he had no choice. Mr. Gahagan, a retired marketing executive from Lattingtown who now spends his afternoons cooking lavish meals for his wife, Dolly, was talking about the vegetables at the only supermarket in Glen Cove, the Super Stop & Shop on Forest Avenue.
 Stop & Shop came to Glen Cove about 18 months ago, after its Dutch parent company, Royal Ahold, changed the name of the Edwards supermarkets, which it also owned. Since then, Stop & Shop has bought out Farmers Bazaar, an independent local supermarket, and moved into the 45,000-square-foot Farmers Bazaar store on Forest Avenue. 
 But Mr. Gahagan, a twice-a-week shopper, isn't sold. "The quality stinks, and the variety stinks," he said. "All the staples went up 20 percent. If you do the shopping, you notice it very clearly."
A Stop & Shop spokesman, Gary Lewi of Howard J. Rubenstein Associates in Manhattan, said that he was not aware of customer complaints on quality or variety. He said that senior company officials inspect all stores on unannounced visits, using strict guidelines. "It is frankly a far tougher criterion than I suspect I would go out with, with a shopping list for my spouse," he said.
But since his tastes run to cheese souffles and zucchini-yogurt soup, Mr. Gahagan said he was pleased to learn that a second supermarket is opening in Glen Cove. "I think competition always makes a difference, especially in vegetables," he said.
The new store, the Farmer's Market of Glen Cove, will also be on Forest Avenue, about a block away from the Super Stop & Shop. Its owner, Cove Associates, is renovating a 30,000-square-foot brick building in an almost-vacant shopping center. Jay Adoni, the president of Cove Associates, said that he expected the Farmer's Market to open in September or October.
There have been a few snags along the way. In December, Stop & Shop filed a civil lawsuit in Supreme Court in Garden City, accusing the Glen Cove Planning Board of violating zoning ordinances in approving the Farmer's Market site plan. Stop & Shop's lawyer, William F. Bonesso, argued that the new market would likely attract vermin because its loading area was inadequate and that it would congest the parking lot with delivery trucks. He also accused the planning board of pandering to "a few vocal residents" in approving the Farmer's Market plans.
Last fall at a public hearing on the Farmer's Market's renovation plans, Mr. Bonesso, an associate at the Mineola law firm Forchelli, Curto, Schwartz, Mineo, Carlino & Cohn, said that Stop & Shop had an economic interest in the neighboring strip mall where the Farmer's Market planned to locate because it held the lease on the former Edwards store there. And as a leaseholder, it contended that having the Farmer's Market as a neighbor would reduce its chances of renting the space. 
But the Farmer's Market lawyer, Nicholas A. Sordi Jr. of Sordi & Sordi in Glen Cove, told the planning board that its employees would be assigned to clean up the grounds and that the loading area would be renovated. The board approved the store's plans in November.
Anthony J. Maurino, the city's director of building and code enforcement, said earlier this month that there was no legal reason to deny the application. The store's plans for the loading area, he said, were not a problem. 
But Stop & Shop was not swayed, and in December, Mr. Bonesso filed the lawsuit.
Mayor Mary Ann Holzkamp said that at least 50 residents had complained to her about the rising costs of groceries in Glen Cove. Some wrote to the local weekly newspaper, The Glen Cove Record Pilot, voicing their concerns. In April, the paper published a letter from Mayor Holzkamp that chided Stop & Shop. 
"Our sense of community tells us that what's good for Glen Cove is competition in the marketplace," the mayor wrote. "If Stop & Shop thinks we will settle for anything less, they are mistaken. When Stop & Shop came to Glen Cove it was welcomed as a member of our business family. It's time for them to act accordingly. Stop & Shop should stop the litigation, stop the appeals, and stop the delay, and let another supermarket come to Forest Avenue."
For their part, city officials say a resolution may be at hand. Mr. Maurino said he had received a call in early June from the T. J. Maxx chain, which was considering leasing the old Edwards store. No deal has been reached, city and Stop & Shop officials said. "The irony of it is it looks like we're going to have to a major national retailer there," Mr. Maurino said

HEADLINE: Towels, Sun Block And, Oh Yeah, Checkbook 

BYLINE:  By CHRISTINE WOODSIDE 

 BODY:
AS soon as beach season started, I set out on an odyssey to test the Connecticut Supreme Court ruling that municipal beaches must be open to the public, not just to residents. In the family van, my two daughters and I sought out beaches from Greenwich to Madison. Our plan was just to ask if we could use the beach and see what happened.
 What we found was a system that was both restrictive and human. As the Supreme Court ordered last year, towns have indeed made their beaches public, but the prices are so high and the rules about buying passes so awkward that much of the Connecticut coast remains as out of reach as ever. 
 In Greenwich, for example, it cost $50 for my girls and me to use the beach and would have cost $60 if my husband, Nat, had come along. That's outrageous by any standard. And economics is just the first hurdle. Many towns restrict parking around the beaches. And, finally, some don't sell nonresident beach passes at the beach. They must be bought at town offices, which are sometimes closed on weekends. So even when I was willing to pay the price to get in, I still faced being turned away. 
But we got in everywhere we tried, even when we weren't supposed to, and that was because of the people charged with enforcing the beach policies. These gatekeepers seemed embarrassed by the rules, often apologized for them, and sometimes tried to help us work around them.
In Madison, for example, the man checking cars told me that I had to buy our $40 worth of passes at the town offices, but that they were closed. He let us in anyway to "look around." In Stamford, the gatekeeper waved me in when I said we didn't want to stay that long. He saved us $20 and a trip to the Government Center, which, like Madison's office, is only open on weekdays.
In Greenwich, where I arrived at the beach on a cloudy Sunday of Memorial Day weekend, three different town workers warned us we would have to pay $50, as if to give us a chance to back out. The young man at the guard shack at Greenwich Point, which was at the center of the Supreme Court case, apologized when he told us the fee. "I know that's outrageous, but I didn't make the rules," he said, directing me to a town civic center about a mile away where the passes were sold. As I arrived there, a man sitting outside warned me about how much money I was about to spend and the man inside who sold me the passes said the same thing. It seemed everybody was trying to change my mind.
Back at the beach, the young man at the guard shack obviously felt bad that I had paid so much money to go to the beach on a cloudy day. So he told me he wouldn't stamp the passes so I could use them on a better day.
My trip around the state's beaches was full of such moments.

First Stop, Greenwich
 The Supreme Court ruling seemed to be made for people like me. I live in Deep River, which is along the Connecticut River and away from the great beaches on Long Island Sound. Before the ruling, I had very few choices if I wanted to swim in the Sound. The beautiful beaches at Greenwich were closed to me, as was Madison and those of several other communities. The court ruling was supposed to fix that.
I am the former environmental reporter for The Day, the newspaper in New London, and have written about the state's beaches, including the issue of public access, for almost 10 years. So I made the first stop on my trip Greenwich Point, which was the subject of the Supreme Court case. By forcing Greenwich to open its beaches to nonresidents, the ruling also forced other communities to do the same thing.
The Greenwich beach, of course, was beautiful. It was low tide. Annie, my 11-year-old, initiated a race to the rock wall. Elizabeth, who is 13, discovered pairs of horseshoe crabs, who had made circular patterns in the sand before mating.
It was one of those great moments of camaraderie for mother and child, and it happened at Greenwich Point. I wondered if you could put a price on watching horseshoe crabs with your children.
Annie said, "This is really nice. It's worth $10."
The girls dug a deep hole by the water. I had a cup of gourmet decaf from the snack bar. Annie and I hiked around the point past the blooming wild roses while Elizabeth napped on the sand. We watched a heron stretch out its neck, and then fold it up. A rabbit hid in a patch of wildflowers.
Annie said, "Maybe it's worth $15."

Candlewood Lake, New Fairfield
My stop after Greenwich was to Candlewood Lake in New Fairfield on Monday, Memorial Day. The sign there said, "All nonresidents will be towed." Annie spotted the sign and asked: "Are we going to be arrested?"
We were going to find out. It was mid-morning and the sun was out. I turned into an angled parking space near the bathhouse, just steps from the beach. We heard the drone of Jet Skis and motorboats. The water rippled beyond a row of trees and picnic tables. It was very inviting.
New Fairfield's town beach is adjacent to Squantz Pond State Park, where the parking lot tends to fill up on a hot day, sending overflow visitors looking for a place to park. I suspect that explains the no parking sign, so I warned my daughters that we might have to leave.
We got out of the van and walked up to the young woman and man guarding the beach entrance, which is through the bathhouse. "Hi. We don't live here, but we wondered if we could go to the beach."
"Yes," the woman said. "It's $10 to park and $6 for each of you. You have to park across the street, and pay for the parking there, then come back." The spot I had parked in right near the entrance to the beach, it turns out, was just for residents, who pay from $35 to $65 for a season pass. The lot for nonresidents was across a busy road, but at least it wasn't that far away.
After I reparked, we gathered up our paraphernalia, darted across the street, and went back. I paid the additional $18, for a total of $28 for our day there. No one tried to talk me out of it.
We swam for a bit in the chilly water and had the swimming float to ourselves. We lay down in the sun for a while before moving on, this time to Rowayton.

Bayley Beach, Rowayton
Bayley Beach in Rowayton, a village in Norwalk, used to be one of the more restrictive parks. Not only was it closed to nonresidents, but also to the rest of Norwalk. Only people from Rowayton could use the beach. So I wasn't sure what I was going to find when I tried to get in.
A woman was manning a card table at the entrance to the parking lot. I rolled down the van window and told her we wanted to use the beach..
She said it would cost $20 to park for the rest of the day.
"That's pretty steep," I said.
"They're charging more in Greenwich," she said. That was true, of course, especially since we were not charged to also use the beach. And the parking lot was the same for both residents and nonresidents.
The snack bar was open, and we could see a few dozen people walking down by the water or sitting in chairs on the sand. I bought Annie a hot dog and Elizabeth an Italian ice. They ate at the picnic tables, and then we set up our towels. I watched the girls collect shells and dig another hole, which the beach attendant soon enough refilled with his rake.
It was peaceful. I dug my toes into the sand and collected two or three tiny shells. I would have loved to stay longer, but the girls and I had another beach to hit.

The Surf Club, Madison
It was getting near the end of the afternoon on Memorial Day when we pulled up to the entry shack at the Surf Club, where Madison has strictly monitored residents' entries for many years. I knew that Madison had a policy similar to Greenwich's -- to sell passes at another location. But unlike Greenwich, Madison's offices are closed on weekends. I didn't know what they did when nonresidents showed up to enjoy the late afternoon sun on a national holiday, which is what I wanted to do.
"Hi. I don't live in town. Can we go to the beach?"
The young man was friendly. "You are supposed to go to the Town Campus to buy passes," he said. "It's $10 for the car, and $10 for each person. But Town Campus is closed."
I asked him what I should do.
"You can go the day before to get passes," he said with a straight face.
"I can't get passes now?"
"No."
But then his humanity took over. He looked at me and the girls, sitting there in our bathing suits, then said: "I'll let you go in and look around now because it's late in the day." I figured "look around" was his way of saying, "This is ridiculous. Just go on in."
We drove in and parked. There were about 100 people, all told, at the park. Most of them were sitting in the wooded section behind the beach, having picnics, or playing at the playground. A few were walking along the sand, wading, or just sitting and watching the way the sun makes shadows at that time of the day. I have always thought this is the most beautiful time of day at a beach. I'm glad the guard was nice enough to let me enjoy it.

Cummings Park, Stamford
A week and a half later, on a cloudy, warm Thursday, Elizabeth and I arrived at the little guard shack halfway down the long driveway of Cummings Park in Stamford. This is the home of Brenden Leydon, the Stamford lawyer who sued Greenwich over its beach policy in 1994. Stamford officials had told me in recent years that they are proud that the city has always allowed outsiders onto its beaches.
"Hi. I don't live here. Can we go to the beach?"
The friendly older man in the baseball cap said, "It'll cost you $50 because you'll get a parking ticket."
"Can I pay to park?"
"Where do you live?"
"Deep River." There was a pause. Then I said, "We're just passing through and we thought it would be nice to go to the beach. Can I pay to park?"
"I don't take money," he said. "How often do you come here?"
"Not often."
"For $125 you can get a pass for the year, or $20 for the day."
"Can I get it here?"
"No. At the Government Center," he said. "How long are you going to stay?"
"Not very long."
"Just go in," he said, "but watch out for the cop."
I proceeded to the empty parking spaces in front of the beach. The moody clouds and warm breeze lured us outside to a bench along the sand, but I was too fearful to move far away from the car because I didn't want to get a parking ticket.
Good thing. In 15 minutes, a Stamford patrol car floated into the nearly empty lot. We jumped up and leapt into the van. The Stamford beach would have to wait for another day.

Compo Beach, Westport
The next stop was in Westport, at Compo Beach, where rocks and sand form a wide peninsula near a peaceful residential neighborhood. Compo Beach has long been open to outsiders and I could tell that by how smoothly I was admitted. Here, three town employees walked up to our van as we edged into the narrow entrance. As usual, I told them I didn't live in town, but would like to go to the beach.
"O.K., it's $15 for the day," one of the trio, a man, said. "It would be $30 on a weekend." And, surprise, surprise, I could actually buy the pass there.
"Could you pull up here to the left so we can fill out the pass?" another of the group, a woman, asked me. I pulled over and two more cars, obviously with town passes, went around me to go into the park.
As she handed me the orange ticket, she said, "Put that on the dashboard. It's good for the day. You can come and go as you please."
So we got our feet into the sand and water of one more town. 

Forget Spontaneity
While the Supreme Court ruling has opened up once-restricted beaches, it's not as if the gates are wide open. My trip showed that anyone wanting to use these beaches can't be spontaneous. Want to go on a romantic sunset walk along the beach? You better plan your romance ahead of time since you may have to buy your beach pass at a town office, which may not be open when the mood strikes you. Then, you may have to be willing to spend what by any measure is a lot of money.
Leaders of many towns have been saying for years that residents maintain beaches with their taxes, and that it's only fair for nonresidents to pay their share. But Mr. Leydon said he was disturbed by the beach fees. He said that while he had expected Greenwich to impose high fees and then make it difficult to buy the passes, he was surprised that other towns did the same thing.
"That, I'm not happy about, and I do think the fees should be significantly lower," he said. "The State Legislature ought to take a look at it. If the Legislature established beach fees, it would save the courts from another lawsuit," which he said he is prepared to file next year.
Mr. Leydon said he thought the beach guards' willingness to bend the rules proved that municipal beaches aren't overcrowded.
"The people who are actually there are the ones to know if there is a problem, and obviously, there isn't," he said. "I think that really shows that all of this is a Chicken Little reaction."
I'm with the beach gatekeepers: I'm embarrassed for my state, where the coast is treated a little like a private club for those with the right credentials. I'm embarrassed for my own town of Deep River, where our beach at an abandoned quarry is free, but outsiders pay $10 to launch a boat on the river.
The beach gate guards we met never asked why we didn't just go swimming in our own town, why we didn't just go to the state parks (which were next-door to three of the beaches), or, outside of Greenwich, the most pressing question, one that I asked myself repeatedly during my trip, why would anyone pay these outrageous prices?
