HEADLINE: One Show In the Park And a Drama For the Board 

BYLINE:  By ROBIN POGREBIN 

 BODY:
Joseph Papp founded the New York Shakespeare Festival in 1954 to bring plays like "Much Ado About Nothing" and "The Tempest" to people without charge. He started in a Lower East Side amphitheater, then moved to a truck that toured the five boroughs and ultimately built the Delacorte Theater in Central Park. At first, the Public offered three plays a summer, then two so each would run longer and more people could see them. 
 The park productions have always been a serious drain on the theater's finances. Except for 1980, when Papp eliminated "A Midsummer Night's Dream" and did only "The Pirates of Penzance" to protest the city's budget cuts, the festival delivered at least two shows each season. 
 But this summer, the Public will present only one production in the park, "Twelfth Night," to run for seven weeks rather than the usual four. George C. Wolfe, the Public's producer, and Kenneth B. Lerer, its chairman, said that the combined financial hit of a weak economy, the effects of Sept. 11 and the city's cultural budget cuts proved too great for the theater. Each production costs the Public about $1 million. 
"Like every other cultural institution in the city, we're dealing with the realities," Mr. Wolfe said. "Instead of two shows it's one show, but it can run longer and more people can see it."
In addition, the Public is about to announce the appointment of a new executive director to handle the business side of the theater. The board's choice is Mara Manus, 42, a program officer of economic development at the Ford Foundation who was previously a senior vice president at Universal Studios.
These two developments, along with several other moves, are part of an aggressive effort by the Public over the last year to get its house in order, even if that means making some unpopular decisions.
Artistically, the Public is coming off a strong season, with two shows that moved to Broadway: Suzan-Lori Parks's "Topdog/ Underdog," which won this year's Pulitzer Prize, and the one-woman show "Elaine Stritch at Liberty," which won this year's Tony Award for special theatrical event. Its December production of "Othello," with Keith David and Liev Schreiber, exceeded box office projections by 10 percent, said a spokeswoman for the Public. 
"The institution is in better shape today," Mr. Lerer said. "We have righted the ship. I like where we are."
The Public lost a combined $14 million on its ill-fated Broadway musicals "On the Town" and "The Wild Party," which left the theater projecting a shortfall of nearly $700,000 and deficits until fiscal year 2004. In anticipation of the city's budget cuts, the theater laid off about 20 percent of its staff in November and cut back on activities like community outreach. 
Even though two of the Public's biggest benefactors -- Larry Condon of the LuEsther T. Mertz Charitable Trust and Dorothy Cullman -- quit the board to protest what they called mismanagement last fall and have not returned, their donations are intact, and Mr. Lerer said Mr. Condon has been personally supportive. 
The Public has brought on six new members: Andre Balazs, who owns the Mercer Hotel; Alec Baldwin, the actor; Susan Lyne, the president of ABC Entertainment; Myer Berlow, an AOL Time Warner executive; Frederick W. Hill, an executive at J. P. Morgan Chase; and David Rockwell, the architect.
The board appointed a new finance director, Ellen C. Moran, formerly director of finance and chief financial officer for the Lincoln Center Development Project, executive director of the Tucker Music Foundation and general manager of Pennsylvania Ballet.
Rather than bring "Topdog" and " Stritch' to Broadway, the Public licensed them to other producers, incurring no financial risk but retaining shares in the royalties and a small percentage of profits. (Mr. Lerer estimated that the Public has made a total of $250,000 from the two works.) "We were gun-shy," said Ken Auletta, who writes for The New Yorker and sits on the Public's board. "We had two Broadway shows that didn't make it and lost us some money. In the teeth of that and this economy and 9/11, are we going to dip into the endowment to produce two Broadway shows?"
The theater plans to return to two shows in the park next summer, finances permitting. "It's a wonderful venue that puts great economic stress on the institution and has since day one," Mr. Lerer said. 
However financially necessary, the decision is symbolically potent. For as long as anyone can remember there have been people lining up in Central Park for free tickets to two shows a summer like "Julius Caesar" and "The Taming of the Shrew." Some of those shows have been so well received -- like "Two Gentlemen of Verona" and "The Mystery of Edwin Drood" -- they moved to Broadway.
Of the decision to mount a single production, Rosemarie Tichler, who recently retired as artistic producer after about 30 years, said: "I hope it doesn't happen again. George is trying to be fiscally responsible."
Merle Debuskey, who worked as Papp's publicist for years, said: "I don't think it's a violation of any moral principle. I think the principle is to stay alive and to do plays and to do them free and what you have to do to accommodate it, you have to do."
Papp modeled the festival after institutions like the New York Public Library. In discussing the origins of the festival in her biography "Joe Papp: An American Life," Helen Epstein said Papp wrote: "There's a reason it's called show business. A business must stay out of the red to exist. I had a different idea. I wanted to reach audiences who might never have seen a play before and who were unable or unwilling to pay. I wanted my theater to be free."
Public board members warn not to make too much of the decision to produce only one play this summer. There was no internal debate. It seemed to everyone like the right thing to do. "There was not a climactic discussion," Mr. Auletta said. "There was not a moment when we said, 'This sabotages everything we believe in.' "
Even Papp's widow, Gail Papp, who sits on the board, said the call was not particularly significant, merely prudent. "We don't like it, believe me," she said. "But to be financially responsible we had to cut back, not only in the park but to start to economize in a responsible way."
By choosing the crowd-pleasing comedy "Twelfth Night" and casting stars like Julia Stiles, Jimmy Smits and Oliver Platt, the Public is hoping to replicate the success of its "Seagull" production in the park last summer, which had people camping out overnight for tickets to see Meryl Streep and Kevin Kline directed by Mike Nichols.
"We decided to do one production with big star names," Mr. Lerer said. "We picked a comedy rather than one of the dark ones." The play opens tomorrow and runs through Aug. 11.
Perhaps most crucially, the theater is trying yet again to find someone to handle the business side of the Public.
While several have failed in this role before -- most recently, Fran Reiter -- a number of board members said Ms. Manus was bound to work because she must. They said it was Mr. Wolfe's last chance to show that he could share power.
Even as the theater has been adjusting its financial side, its board continues to support Mr. Wolfe, in large part because he is coming off one of his strongest artistic seasons, having directed both "Topdog" and "Stritch." Mr. Wolfe also wrote and directed the show "Harlem Song," a pastiche of songs and skits about Harlem that starts performances at the Apollo Theater on July 6, although it is not a Public production. 
"We feel very good about George," said Mr. Auletta. "Look at what he does as a showman, as a director as a spotter of talent." He cited Mr. Wolfe's support of Ms. Parks's work as an example. "He's been nurturing that talent," Mr. Auletta said. "That is one of the things he does and does brilliantly."

HEADLINE: Money From Kin Abroad Helps Bengalis Get By 

BYLINE:  By SOMINI SENGUPTA 

DATELINE: BARIKHALA, Bangladesh 

 BODY:
The 5,000 residents of this village share one telephone. So when a call comes in to the village shop, a child must sprint down the meandering lanes, past the jackfruit hanging from the trees and the painted tin houses and the women pounding grain in their courtyards to fetch the lucky recipient.
 It could be a call from a brother building high-rises in Singapore, a husband trimming lawns in Dubai, a son calling from Italy, where he is said to be selling flowers in a city whose name no one knows. 
 Globalization meets the dirt road in villages like this one. Virtually every family here depends on at least one able-bodied man and sometimes a woman working overseas. 
They go abroad on temporary work contracts, mostly to Southeast Asia or the Middle East. Some make it back with money enough to make a living at home. Some come back empty-handed, and they wrap their checkered loongis around their waists and go back to working the fields. Many simply wait until they can scrape together enough cash to head out again.
As it has in developing countries worldwide, overseas migrant work has transformed villages and towns across Bangladesh. Remittances from abroad reached a record of nearly $2 billion last year, and that was just what came in through official channels. 
If unofficial transfers were counted, Finance Minister Saifur Rahman has said, they would substantially reduce the country's reliance on foreign aid -- about $1.4 billion a year. Remittances are the country's second-largest source of foreign revenue, after garment exports.
The government has a huge labor export program of its own. Today three million Bangladeshi migrant workers are overseas on government-sponsored contracts, the largest number in Saudi Arabia, according to government figures. 
That does not count those who go from villages like this one, sponsored by private employers in labor-needy countries from South Korea to the United Arab Emirates. Nor does it count all of those who go abroad illegally, paying through the nose for the chance to wash dishes in Tokyo or hawk fruit in Manhattan.
Migrant workers' success stories are abundant. Thanks to money made across the oceans, roads are widened, rooms added, minivans bought. A color television comes from Singapore, a fluffy fleece blanket from Malaysia.
But there are other stories as well. A woman comes back and sees that her husband has taken a new wife. A son comes back still unable to repay a family debt. Local land prices skyrocket as cash flows in from overseas workers. A man who goes abroad is likely to attract a wife from higher up on the social ladder. A woman may taste a freedom from familial duties that she never imagined. She may also taste abuse as never before.
One who has fared nicely from the arrangement is Harun Rashid, a garrulous, enterprising native son of Barikhala. 
Armed with a cellphone and a counterpart in Singapore, Mr. Rashid finds the right men for the right jobs. He fixes their work papers, fetches airline tickets. If his clients want to send money home, he arranges that too; there is no bank nearby.
The price of opportunity, as Mr. Rashid acknowledges, is not cheap. Fees for passage range from 150,000 takas -- roughly $2,700 -- for a relatively undesirable Persian Gulf country to nearly double for Singapore. In the last few years he has sent 52 of his kinfolk abroad.
A cash economy has come to Barikhala. But it is all but impossible to make any cash without leaving.
"There's not much to do here," the recently returned Bashir Ahmed, 31, said bluntly. Electricity came to his village in the five years he was away on a construction site in Singapore. Now idle at home, he is considering his next move and how to raise the money to get there.
For Saidur Rahman, the chance to go abroad came soon after he turned 18, though he had little choice in the matter. His mother, a mechanic's widow, could hardly afford to send her boy to college. So when a cousin called from Singapore offering to bring him over, a deal was struck. The family sold a tract of land to pay for his passage.
"We're in a poor country, so we get this idea," Mr. Rahman explained. "One older brother goes. Then, one after another, we all go."
Mr. Rahman, a twig of a man just over 5 feet tall, worked in a factory for a couple of years. He returned exhausted, and what he brought back was not even enough to buy back the land his mother had sold. Shame hovers over him like rain clouds. Going abroad, he said, is like playing craps: sometimes you win, sometimes you don't.
"The only thing we think of here is when do we go to Singapore," he said. "I didn't realize how hard it would be."
The drama of the laborers' journey plays out virtually every day at Dhaka International Airport. 
The foreign-returned pour into the arrivals wing, wheeling television sets and refrigerators. The foreign-bound linger at the departures terminal, sometimes wearing identical overalls, each with an identification number pinned to the chest.
Anwara Begum, a Barikhala-born woman married off to a man in a nearby village, did not tell anyone at first about her plans. No woman from her clan had ever worked outside the home. 
Shame aside, she said, what choice did she have? Her husband, a retired military man, could hardly make ends meet. Debt piled up on her back. After a few years working as a seamstress in Dhaka, the capital, she set her mind on going away. 
An ad in a Bengali newspaper informed her that Malaysia needed seamstresses. With roughly 20 other Bengali women, many of whom, like her, had left their children at home, she stepped onto an airplane for the first time, headed for the Malaysian island of Penang. "What a father does, I thought I would do as a mother," she said.
The hours were long: from 8 in the morning until after 10 at night. But gone was the tedium of her one-room house. No one to cook for. No one to wash for. No one minding what she did with her free time.
It was a freedom, she said, that not everyone handled well. A breadwinning wife, calling long distance, sometimes talked back to her husband. A woman sometimes found someone new to love. Occasionally someone returned to find that a new wife had taken her place.
Anwara Begum, it seems, was always aware of such things, which is why she never asked what her husband did with the money she sent every month, nearly half of her earnings. "If I questioned my husband," she explained, "there would be more trouble."
In any case, by the time she returned after five years away there was nothing left, only new debt. She has since borrowed some more money and bought chickens. Her chicken coop sits on top of bamboo stilts in a swamp across the road from her house.
Now around 36, Anwara Begum can still break into rapid Malay, the lingua franca of her co-workers in the sweatshop. They were women from all over South and Southeast Asia -- Sri Lankans, Indonesians, Indians -- and their concerns, as she recalled, were identical: the welfare of parents, husbands and children back home. 
"You're not the only one in need," they told her.
Memories of Penang are still with her. In a photo album she keeps inside a glass-doored cabinet are the smiling faces of her girlfriends. They are standing at an airport, clutching crates of gifts. They are sitting in their best dresses at a banquet hall. They are strolling on a day off.
Anwara Begum kept a journal all the years she worked away from home. But one of her friends took it away. "If you had it to look at it every day," she told Anwara Begum, "it would drive you mad."

PERSON: Dr. Frank X. Ogasawara 

HEADLINE: Frank Ogasawara, 88, Professor Who Helped Turkey to the Table 

BYLINE:  By ERIC NAGOURNEY

 BODY:
Dr. Frank X. Ogasawara, a poultry expert whose advances in artificial insemination helped keep the fat and happy farm-raised turkey from going the way of the dodo, died on June 8 at a hospital in Davis, Calif. He was 88. 
 Dr. Ogasawara, a longtime professor of avian and animal sciences at the University of California at Davis, was considered a pioneer in developing methods to impregnate turkeys artificially. 
 Artificial insemination is now used almost exclusively to produce the more than 250 million turkeys raised each year in the United States. But when Dr. Ogasawara began his research in the 1950's, the birds were left largely to their own devices when it came to mating -- and the results were none too good.
The domesticated turkey had become an ungainly creature, thanks in part to selective breeding by turkey producers. The male's swollen chest and meaty body made him a hit in the kitchen. In the bedroom, it was another story. It was not just the ability to fly that the birds lacked.
"The toms were getting heavier and heavier, and so it was very difficult for them to mount a hen and not really squash her," said Dr. F. Howard Kratzer, a professor emeritus of animal science at Davis and a friend of Dr. Ogasawara's. "It just wasn't possible for them to mate naturally."
Enter Dr. Ogasawara and his colleagues, who drew on earlier artificial insemination work to help the turkey industry avoid a serious economic blow.
The researchers figured out how to massage the male turkey's abdomen to coax the release of semen. Then it was simply a matter of getting the semen into the females. (Imagine the turkey-baster method, but with a genuine turkey.)
Dr. Ogasawara also made an important discovery about why female turkeys remain fertile for weeks after a single mating, finding that they have special "sperm nests" for storage in their oviducts. 
In 1972 he established the California Raptor Center at Davis, which cared for birds injured in the wild. He was also an expert in the long-tailed fowl, a Japanese bird whose feathers can reach 30 feet in length.
But he was best known for his work with breeding turkeys. He taught the technique to poultry experts around the world. In 1966, he received the National Turkey Federation's Outstanding Research Award. In 1982 he was named a Fellow of the Poultry Science Foundation.
Dr. Ogasawara, who took emeritus status in 1983, was born in San Diego on Nov. 10, 1913, and was raised mostly in Nevada. He received his bachelor's degree from the University of California at Berkeley and his doctorate from Davis. He is survived by his wife of 57 years, Kay Ogasawara of Davis; two daughters, Pam Ogasawara of Urbana, Md., and Patty Sunui of Sacramento; a son, Paul, of Sebastopol, Calif.; and five grandchildren.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Frank X. Ogasawara (University of California at Davis)

HEADLINE: Syracuse Dreams Of a Mall to Rival A Magic Kingdom 

BYLINE:  By DAN BARRY 

DATELINE: SYRACUSE 

 BODY:
Something momentous is happening here, they say, something that will transform upstate New York like nothing since the glaciers, or at least the Erie Canal. It will do more than simply enrich the region, they say; it will change the very way that people think -- about their environment, about themselves.
 It is not a new religion. It is a mall. 
 But even "mall" does not do justice to this project, its promoters say, because it is so much more. It is DestiNY USA, a behemoth of a shopping, tourism and entertainment complex that will take up more square footage than two Empire State Buildings. It will be even bigger, they promise, than Minnesota's Mall of America -- which is really, really big. 
The plans call for 400 stores, 4,000 hotel rooms, and more than 30 cafes and restaurants, including many without plastic trays. But that's not all, the promoters say. A massive saltwater aquarium. Rock- and ice-climbing mountains five stories high. A 65-acre park under a Biosphere-like dome. A 20-screen movie complex, a 15,000-seat concert hall and not one but two Broadway-style theaters. 
Oh, and a miniature Erie Canal, like the real one a few miles away.
That the financing for the $2.2 billion project still has to be secured does not bother its extremely wealthy developer, Robert J. Congel. He is so certain that his development firm will get the needed investment from Wall Street -- "We should have it shortly," he said -- that groundbreaking is tentatively scheduled for July.
Meanwhile, the plans for DestiNY USA continue to grow, mutating in size and expense like some space-eating organism made of glass and steel. In recent months, its estimated cost has risen about $400 million, as Mr. Congel keeps adding more flourishes, including a plan to make the entire project "green," or environmentally friendly. Even the poured concrete will be dyed green.
"It is time to give back," said Mr. Congel, who acknowledges that "cuddly" has not been among the terms applied to him as his company, Pyramid Management Group, has decorated the Northeast with malls and shopping centers. Hard-nosed, even ruthless, yes; warm and fuzzy, no.
But this native son's tough reputation may be why many here have come to share his bold assumption: that millions of people will flock to the cold belt of New York to visit a mall-that-is-not-a-mall, where a stop at the International Tourism/Exposition Center will move them to see the actual Erie Canal, the actual Adirondack Mountains and other actual upstate attractions. 
Mr. Congel's charmingly relentless style, along with upstate's glaring need for economic jumper cables, has persuaded virtually every level of government to give him extensive tax breaks. All this even though a few central matters, like the names of the anchor stores, remain a mystery.
Mayor Matthew J. Driscoll jokes that he often begins his frequent conversations with Mr. Congel by asking, "What is it you're building, and when is it?" But like so many others here, the mayor remains an enthusiastic supporter of the project, in Syracuse's old Oil City section at the southern end of Onondaga Lake. After all, where else in upstate New York -- or in the rest of the country -- is anyone investing $2.2 billion?
Figures developed by Economics Research Associates, a consulting firm hired by Mr. Congel, long ago became regional gospel. DestiNY USA will generate up to $12.5 billion in annual economic activity, the firm estimated, and will create as many as 122,000 jobs with an average annual wage of about $31,000. The firm predicts that the project will attract 35 million "visits" a year -- more than San Francisco, New Orleans or even Disneyland.
Mayor Driscoll acknowledged that the numbers sounded incredible; comparisons between Syracuse and San Francisco have never before seemed necessary. But the city has double-checked the soundness of the consulting firm's projections, he said. "And if half of what they estimate comes true, it's a home run."
For Syracuse, a simple double would be nice. This city of 150,000 remains proud of its museums, colleges and ethnic neighborhoods, and a 20-minute car ride from downtown leads to dairy farms and lakes dotting a lush countryside. But it suffers the classic upstate urban plight: the department stores have fled from downtown, there is a projected $28 million deficit in the school and city budgets, and high-tech industries are not exactly clamoring for office space. Once known as the Salt City, it now calls itself "A City for All Seasons" to make the most of those long winters encased in snow.
Along came Mr. Congel, a resident of a Syracuse suburb who has an estimated worth of $700 million that, according to Forbes magazine, puts him in a tie for the country's 364th wealthiest person. His company says its shopping centers serve one of every four households in the Northeast. Those developments often faced intense opposition, which Mr. Congel dismissed as the handiwork of competitors.
He plays hardball. In the mid-1980's, Pyramid spent big-city money -- $770,000 -- to influence the outcome of a small-town election in Poughkeepsie because one of its mall proposals hung in the balance. The mall was built, a state ethics panel expressed dismay but found no criminal wrongdoing, and Mr. Congel was left with what he calls a "bad taste," though not bad enough to end his days as a prodigious campaign contributor. State records show, for example, that in January he made a $25,000 donation to Gov. George E. Pataki's re-election campaign.
But when it comes to Syracuse, Mr. Congel says that he opens his heart and wallet. When he replaced an ugly stretch of oil tanks with the Carousel Center mall, he said, his company spent $173 million to clean up the pollution -- an expense he considers to be a contribution to the city that granted him the substantial property-tax concessions needed to build the project.
That was in 1990; things have changed. Mr. Congel is 66 years old now, with 17 grandchildren, all under the age of 9. His professed desire to keep those grandchildren from fleeing Syracuse one day has become part of the DestiNY USA legend.
Two years ago, Pyramid announced plans to expand the Carousel Center to create what in the tourism trade is known as a destination. More than a year of intense haggling over tax breaks followed; at one point, Pyramid adopted a take-it-or-leave-it stance, and prepared to build DestiNY USA in Massachusetts or Pennsylvania, which, among other complications, would have required a name change.
"Suppose you went to a guy and said, 'I'll give you $100,' and he said, 'No, I want $110,' " Mr. Congel said. "You can't negotiate forever."
In the end, he got what he needed to seek Wall Street financing, from a 30-year property-tax exemption to inclusion in the state Empire Zone and the federal Empowerment Zone, providing even more tax incentives. The state also agreed to spend some of the sales tax generated at DestiNY USA -- an estimated $30 million a year -- on promoting upstate tourism and perhaps operating the mall's tourism center, as long as Pyramid builds a substantial portion of the project -- 3.2 million square feet -- by July 2004.
Pyramid has striven to create excitement and mystery about the project, dispatching executives to drop the DestiNY USA name with travel agencies and chambers of commerce. Its promotional video, available on the Internet, alternates images of the proposed project with those of the American flag, while the same phrase is repeated: "Nothing like it in the world." 
All the while, Mr. Congel summons people -- public officials, environmentalists, hotel managers -- to spend the day and perhaps the night at his secluded country lodge, about an hour's drive from Syracuse. There, before elaborate meals of game hunted on the property -- deer, elk, Russian boar, -- the New York wine is uncorked and ideas are discussed and sometimes incorporated into the ever-changing proposal. Before long, another frill is dangled before the public, the latest being: How about a golf course?
The project's name is now firmly lodged in the regional consciousness. Entrepreneurs are incorporating businesses with names like "DestinyUSA Golf" and "Destiny USA City Tours," while critics are often accused of exacerbating Syracuse's latent inferiority complex. 
Still, some people manage to steel themselves against the constant Pyramid message that Mr. Congel is a visionary long enough to ask a few questions.
"Is there as much detail about the project as I would like? No," said Steven DeRegis, a city councilman. "People in my opinion were scared to stand up to the developer. The position they fell back on was that he would walk away from the project, but I believed that he had too much invested down there to walk away."
Mr. DeRegis said that he supported the project after Mr. Congel made certain financial assurances to protect the city's interests. Still, he said, he worries that DestiNY USA will become an Atlantic City -- "a castle with a moat around it" -- and he is fighting for assurances that the entire city will be integrated into the overall tourism plan.
Robert Haley, an architect and co-director of the Urban Design Center, a nonprofit urban-planning organization, expressed similar concerns. "They're trying to create all of the experiences of New York State within the mall: the canal, the Adirondacks, Native America," he said. "It's about having all the excitement right next to the cash register. And it's not dealing with the downtown context at all."
Amanda Nicholson, who teaches retail management and consumer studies at Syracuse University, said that DestiNY USA may represent the next generation in the evolution of malls. She also said that building it in Syracuse makes sense: the city has interstate highway access, a central upstate location, and long winters that will make indoor entertainment seem even more attractive.
As for the virtual elements of the plan -- the imitation canal, the faux rock climbing -- Ms. Nicholson said that "virtual stuff seems to be very popular with the American psyche."
"It's getting in touch with reality," she added. "But not really."
The other day, Mr. Congel settled back into a chair at his sprawling country lodge and once again discussed his DestiNY USA vision. He dismissed the idea that visitors will see virtual representations of some of upstate New York's attractions and then venture no farther than the upscale food court. He said that his project would improve the economy of upstate, with the high-tech tourism center perhaps arranging trips to Cooperstown, Niagara Falls and, yes, even downtown Syracuse.
He said that this would be his last development, and that he intended to recycle his profits back into the project. In fact, he said, he planned to be the unofficial mayor of DestiNY USA, making sure that the operation continues to meet his high standards.
The cooks were puttering in one of the kitchens. Downstairs, the grandchildren's bunk beds were all made. And in the conference room, another round of guests -- some hotel executives -- were being shown a promotional video about, well, what else.
Articles in this series are exploring upstate New York in the gubernatorial election year. Earlier articles are online at nytimes.com/metro.

HEADLINE: Report Shows Serious Crime Rose in 2001 

BYLINE:  By SARAH KERSHAW 

 BODY:
Serious crimes like homicide and robbery have risen in the United States for the first time in almost a decade, fueled by increases in many large cities but tempered by a sharp decline in New York City, according to statistics to be reported today by the Federal Bureau of Investigation. 
 Crime increased in the nation by 2 percent over all in 2001, according to the federal report, which was released yesterday by New York officials trumpeting an eight-year decline in the state in most major crimes tracked annually by the F.B.I. 
 The nationwide increase comes after steady inroads against crime during the 1990's, and when many local police departments are facing budgetary strains as they confront the new and complex demands of fighting terrorism along with routine crime. 
The F.B.I. data are to be officially released today with more detailed statistics. They also show that in many categories, like homicide (up 3.1 percent) and car theft (up 5.9 percent), the incidence climbed dramatically during the second half of 2001, after declining in the first half. 
While criminologists cautioned against drawing sweeping conclusions about the country's crime based on a one-year -- or, in some cases, a six-month -- change, there were substantial increases in all but a few of the seven crimes in the F.B.I. report.
The data, part of the Uniform Crime Reporting Program, are considered preliminary until the final statistics are issued in October and reflect the incidence of homicide, rape, robbery, aggravated assault, burglary, larceny and motor vehicle theft reported to police nationwide. 
With the exception of New York City, where violent crimes continued a sharp decline, almost 10 percent in 2001, homicides and other serious crimes surged last year in several cities. They included Boston, where homicides rose 67 percent last year, Houston, Atlanta, St. Louis and Phoenix, F.B.I. officials said yesterday. 
Data on crime in cities outside New York were first reported yesterday in The Washington Post. 
"Americans were getting along much better with each other during the 1990's," said Andrew Karmen, a professor of sociology at John Jay College of Criminal Justice in Manhattan. "Many of the cities that enjoyed big drops in the 1990's are now suffering from a rebound, with New York City being the big exception."
While the F.B.I. data showed that crime had risen by 2 percent over all, violent crime increased only slightly, by 0.3 percent. 
One kind of violent crime, aggravated assault, decreased in 2001, by 1.4 percent. In the other six categories, crime was up, and in most cases those increases reversed a downward trend from the previous six months. 
Professor Karmen, the author of "New York Murder Mystery," which discusses the plunge in crime in New York City during the 1990's, said that the factors contributing to a decline in crime were as varied and hard to figure as the factors contributing to an increase. 
But he suggested that the spike in crimes during the second six months of 2001 might have been fanned by anger over the Sept. 11 terrorist attack and the economic downturn that was gripping the country a year ago, at the start of the second half of 2001. 
Professor Karmen said that the two categories of crime experts considered most reliable were homicide and car theft, because incident reporting is more accurate and more thorough than for the other categories. 
While crime in those two categories rose substantially nationwide in 2001, New York City continued to show sharp decreases. Homicides, reflecting data reported earlier by New York City officials, decreased by 3.6 percent, while the incidence of car theft in the city was down by 16.3 percent, according to the federal data. 
The New York City and New York State statistics did not include the deaths and injuries that resulted from the attack on the World Trade Center.

HEADLINE: Soon Only Snakes Will Be Using Outhouses 

BYLINE:  By PETER T. KILBORN 

DATELINE: WARM SPRINGS, Va. 

 BODY:
Just three or four years before the 21st century, taking a bath at nearly one in five homes here in Bath County in the Allegheny Mountains meant hauling a galvanized tub into the kitchen and filling it with water heated on the stove. Children took turns, oldest first. 
 "You never felt like you were clean," said Peggy Stewart, 64, whose family repeated the ritual on Saturday nights for generations. 
 For the Stewarts of Bath County, population 5,048, those days are over. On a two-and-a-half acre lawn planted with dainty clusters of flowers made of cloth, Mrs. Stewart and her husband, Tommy, now have water enough for real plants they have begun to cultivate. They have removed the five-gallon buckets from their drain pipes. Copperhead snakes lurk in the outhouse, but nobody need go there any more. 
"We are in seven heavens," Mrs. Stewart said. 
The 2000 census recorded the demise of the outhouse, an artifact that for most Americans is old enough to be funny. Yet at the start of the 1990's, having tubs that drained and toilets that flushed remained an aspiration for around 3 million people living in 1.1 million houses, or 1.2 percent of all houses.
Now, the census shows, the number of houses without plumbing has dropped below one million for the first time, to 671,000, and below 1 percent, to 0.64 percent, for the first time, too. The decline has been precipitous but a long time coming, from nearly half the houses lacking plumbing in 1940, when the Census Bureau began keeping plumbing records, and 17 percent in 1960. 
"You're seeing the end game" of President Franklin D. Roosevelt's promise to bring rural residents the conveniences of cities, said Robert E. Lang, demographer and director of Virginia Tech's Metropolitan Institute in Alexandria. "Although the numbers look infinitesimal, at the county level you see a dramatic change."
The tiny fraction of houses that remain without plumbing are tucked away on terrain too arid, rocky or remote to accommodate plumbing, or their owners just will not have it.
"You never get to zero in one of these things," said John C. Weicher, assistant secretary for housing in the Department of Housing and Urban Development. "I think at this point we're down to such a small number, it's difficult to do anything about it." 
A department-sponsored survey three years ago found about 2 percent of all houses to be severely inadequate, Mr. Weicher said, but plumbing was just one of the criteria, with safety, wiring and heating.
Spurred by money from HUD, as well as state health departments and county treasuries fattened by the economic growth of the last decade, 48 counties in 19 states reduced the number of houses without plumbing by more than 90 percent, according to an analysis by Andrew Beveridge, a demographer at Queens College and a consultant to The New York Times.
Twelve years ago, 349 Bath County houses had little or no plumbing. By 2000, the number was down to 31, the sharpest decline of all Virginia counties. In Hamilton County, N.Y., in the Adirondacks, 854 of 2,362 occupied houses lacked plumbing 12 years ago. By 2000, the number had fallen to 20. In Mahnomen County, Minn., an Indian reservation, the number dropped to 4 from 181 and in Piscataquis County, Me., site of Moosehead Lake, to 130 from 2,332. 
Close to the West Virginia line, the corkscrew mountain roads of Bath County bind isolated homesteads, farms, villages and little subdivisions. In Hot Springs, the county's biggest town, stands the 2,948-acre Homestead Resort and its immense brick pile of a hotel, celebrated for its therapeutic mineral baths. 
The Homestead is the county's principal economic engine and its biggest employer. In addition to guests from big cities who spend $300 to $400 a day to stay there, the Homestead has attracted a growing population of affluent retirees to its nearby hills.
But the wealth of Bath County stops there. "We just have the extremes," Claire Collins, the county administrator, said. "The very wealthy and the poor." 
Well into the 1990's, many workers who cleaned the Homestead's bathrooms lived in houses without bathrooms. Some lived in West Warm Springs, once called Shakerag, a hilly, largely black subdivision of about 35 small, four- and five-room ranch houses a mile from the serene county seat, Warm Springs, population 980. 
West Warm Springs, along knolls overlooking the Alleghenies, was an unlikely candidate for the indoor plumbing that reached the county seat generations ago. Most of the community's terrain is too rocky to percolate, ruling out septic tanks, and the county resisted putting in water and sewer lines.
For decades people coped. Joan Williams, a cafeteria worker at Bath County High School, said she gave her four boys and two younger girls sponge baths each morning with water heated on the stove. For the Saturday bath, she put the boys in the tub, one by one, then changed the water and put in the girls. 
" 'If Thomas Jefferson and Woodrow Wilson did it, we can do it, too,' " Ms. Williams's daughter Sarah, 25, said her mother would say as she put her into the tub.
Once a week, the Williamses would toss a layer of lime into the pit of the outhouse. "When that hole filled up," Mrs. Williams said, "you dug another hole and moved it." She watered her flowers with spent dishwater. Twice a week, she drove to the nearest coin laundry, 25 miles away in Covington, to wash clothes. 
Her neighbor, Mrs. Stewart, recalled: "We'd put jugs in the car, 15-, 20-gallon jugs, 5-gallon cans, as much as you could haul, and go to the river. It might last a week." 
In the house, she said: "We had a little room that had a slop jar. In the morning, you'd take it to the outside toilet. We would wash it out with disinfectant." 
For years, she said, she and her neighbors pressed county officials for water and sewer services. 
"They didn't think we should have water," Mrs. Stewart said. "Like we didn't count." 
In the late 1980's, the county acquiesced and stretched water lines into the settlement. But they stopped at small hydrants -- three-foot-tall pipes with frost-free faucets -- on the residents' lawns. Lacking sewers and septic tanks for drainage, homeowners could not bring the lines indoors. 
Then in the early 1990's a new county Board of Supervisors took office, and Ms. Collins, 47, was hired as administrator. "One of the questions during my interview was, 'Would you be willing to work with people on improvements of their indoor plumbing?,' " Ms. Collins said.
With the change in command, Shirley Cardwell, 52, a bartender at the Homestead, organized a neighborhood campaign for plumbing. She learned of a federal program to rehabilitate rural housing in communities and another to fix up isolated houses that lay beyond villages and subdivisions. 
"I thought, 'Let's see if we can get some things done,' " Ms. Cardwell said. She said the supervisors asked if she wanted water or home renovation. " 'We'll go for both,' " she said she told them. "They were open to it."
At a maximum cost of $27,000 per household, contractors tore down the shakiest houses and built new ones, shored up foundations, replaced roofs, siding and floors, and installed kitchen sinks and bathrooms. 
Most outhouses were filled in and plowed over. 
Once drains and faucets were flowing, most of them by late 1996, Mrs. Stewart said, "I told all my neighbors, 'If you call I won't answer because I'm going to be in the bathtub all day.' " 
Gene Phillips, administrator of the Bath County Service Authority, said he had spent nearly $15 million in federal, state and county money to lay 80 miles of sewer and water lines since the mid-1980's. Homeowners pay $17 a month for sewer service and $15 a month for water, plus 3 cents a gallon for amounts of more than 4,200 gallons. 
Some traumas have come with plumbing. Margaret Bee, a 96-year-old widow, was moved to a motel while her house was renovated. Accustomed to water warmed on a stove, she turned on the motel's water to take a bath and died of a scalding. "She never got a chance to enjoy her new home," Ms. Cardwell said. 
A land rush has ensued, too. "I've had poachers," said Mrs. Stewart's husband, Tommy, 54, a bellman at the Homestead. Laying aside a single-barrel shotgun he was using to pick off copperheads, he said the poachers pretended forebears left them parts of his land. "They would paint the side of one of my trees and claim it was theirs," Mr. Stewart said.
Amy Crowder, the county planner, said land in West Warm Springs is now selling for $12,000 to $20,000 an acre. "Before it was 1,000 bucks an acre, if that," Ms. Crowder said. 
Elsewhere in Bath County, some houses have yet to see a flush toilet. A few years ago, Jim Smith, a retired electrician, and his wife, Carolyn, a registered nurse, bought an imposing three-story farmhouse in the hamlet of Burnsville from the estate of a widow who died there in her 80's. 
The woman had let the county fix the house up, installing electricity, insulation, storm windows and a water line from a spring into the kitchen. "But she refused a bathroom," Mrs. Smith said. The Smiths fixed up the two-hole outhouse, 100 feet beyond the back door, and wallpapered the inside. For a year they trudged through the mountain ice and rain to use it. 
But like their neighbors in West Warm Springs, the Smiths have been swept up by the tide of domestic technology. They have built a three-story addition and are packing it with pipes. "We have put in two bathrooms," Mrs. Smith said, "and we're going to have four."

HEADLINE: The Politics of Futbol 

BYLINE:  By WILLIAM SAFIRE; E-mail: safire@nytimes.com

DATELINE: HARPERS FERRY, W. Va. 

 BODY:
You isolationist moms may call it soccer, a word derived from the second syllable in "association football," but we pre-emptive interventionists call the game that has the world transfixed this week futbol. 
 Set aside the game itself; this is not the sports page. Consider instead the intelligence, geostrategic, cultural and diplomatic ramifications of futbol, with its World Cup played, as always, halfway between U.S. presidential elections. 
 On intelligence: The game of futbol first came to the attention of our satellite mapping analysts at the C.I.A. during the Kennedy administration. A playing field had been leveled -- obviously not a baseball diamond -- near some unexplained facilities in Cuba. That recreational facility could only be a soccer field, which strongly suggested the presence of Russian workers -- a deduction that led to the Cuban missile crisis. 
On strategic power: the Italian semiologist-novelist Umberto Eco wrote in 1978 about the impact of the World Cup on global crowd psychology. He noted that war and terrorism were destabilizing forces, but that the great countervailing power in the world was "in society's capacity for redistributing tension, immediately afterwards, on other poles, closer to the soul of the crowds." This stabilizing "other pole" was an international sports event like futbol's World Cup. 
On culture: The U.S. team, which had come in dead last in the last tournament in 1998, amazed 40 million viewers around the world by battling its way into the quarter-finals. The unthinkable thought was thunk: what if (gasp!) the U.S. team were to win the biggest global sports prize of all? 
The International Herald Tribune headlined a column by its astute political-cultural observer, John Vinocur, with a startling "God Bless America -- and Let U.S. Lose." 
"God save us from the United States winning the World Cup," he wrote, "not so much because it would bring on waves of anti-Americanism . . . but because the Americans don't play pretty soccer. Things are tough enough for the Beautiful Game." 
Vinocur noted in sadness that "winning ugly is on the rise all over the sport . . . the gorgeous, swooping attacks of a Brazil, once virtually a national obligation, are on the decline" as against "the willfulness and professionalism that have made Germany recurring world champions however consistently short on beauty." 
The columnist deplored the replacement of the past glories of brilliance and elegance with the secondary virtues of strength and robustness, "relentlessness snuffing out what's left of filigree." (On Friday, the robust Germans knocked the robust Americans out of the tournament on a disputable call and tomorrow will play the surprising South Koreans; the winner of that, on Hyperbowl Sunday, will play the title-rich Brazilians or the title-hungry Turks.) 
On diplomacy: U.S. foreign-policy makers, though patriots all, hoped fervently from the start that the U.S. team would make a respectable showing but not win. This lust to lose has nothing to do with Vinocur's sensitivity to the quality of the sport; on the contrary, it is based strictly on our national interest. 
If the invigorated U.S. team had come out of nowhere to defeat the best of all the nations of the world -- and not in our football, but in their futbol -- such a triumph, in this year, would have been a psychological bummer for the rest of the world and thus a diplomatic disaster for us. 
Here we are, the locomotive of the world economy, the unipolar bear, a hyperbolic hyperpower bestriding the earth like a Colossus -- do we have to win every hand, rake in every pot, block every competitor's goal? Let some other nation's screaming populace get a kick out of the kicking game. Because we lost honorably, doing better than expected, the U.S. won by losing. 
But nice guys finish last only once. We don't play to lose well; that would be the height of condescension. The purpose of the World Cup may be to redistribute global tension, but the object of each team is to win. In 2006, even our multilateralists will root for our players' victory, whether their play is elegant or robust.
In the meantime -- go Turks!

HEADLINE: The Immigrants And the Suburbs 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"A Suburb All Grown Up and Paved Over," by David Plotz (Op-Ed, June 19), was correct in noting that Fairfax County, Va., is the "very model of the benefits of immigration," but I disagree that the county is in a "crisis." In 2001, my agency helped 164 companies that said they would create more than 11,500 jobs here. 
Compare that with tech centers like San Jose, Calif., and Atlanta, which have been shedding jobs by the tens of thousands. 
 Also, Mr. Plotz says there is only enough "greenery left for a side salad." Funny line, but the county has more than 30,000 acres of dedicated parkland, including a national wildlife refuge established to protect bald eagles and one of the largest urban marshes on the east coast. 
 Yes, some homeowners have "asphalted" their lawns so they have a place to put cars. Putting a halt to this was a legitimate response to keep lawns beautiful for all our residents. There's nothing wrong with worrying about property values. 
Fairfax County has assimilated thousands of immigrants, built an economic powerhouse, lowered tax rates, added parkland and maintained a top-flight school system -- and what is the hot topic? Parking.

GERALD L. GORDON
President, Fairfax County
Economic Development Authority
Vienna, Va., June 20, 2002

HEADLINE: In the Role of Manhattan, Toronto; 
New York Crews Worry as Canada Lures Filmmakers

BYLINE:  By GLENN COLLINS

 BODY:
Blame Canada.
 That's the rallying cry these days among New York City's film workers as they listen anxiously for the giant sucking sound of movie jobs departing for Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver. They say Canadian government subsidies are luring so many feature films away from New York that the new phenomenon has inspired a phrase that sounds like an above-the-title credit: "runaway productions." 
 Filmmaking in New York City is a $5.1 billion business that employs more than 100,000 people and drives 5,000 production businesses, according to the Boston Consulting Group.
"New York is losing jobs to Canada," said Patricia Reed Scott, commissioner of the Mayor's Office of Film, Theater and Broadcasting. "And when you undercut the businesses that offer facilities here, you undermine the very infrastructure that makes us an international production center." 
In 1998, Canada enacted its production services tax credit, a rebate that gives payments to United States producers for 11 percent of labor costs. Ontario, Quebec, British Columbia and other provinces have offered additional subsidies that enable United States producers to save a total of 22 percent on wages in, say, Toronto. Added to the weak Canadian dollar, the subsidies are becoming a powerful lure.
"The subsidies are an ever-present concern for our members," said George DeTitta, president of Local 52 of the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employees, which represents 1,500 electricians, sound technicians and other craft workers in the New York metropolitan region.
The Canadian subsidies have cost the United States $4.1 billion in lost revenue, and an average of 25,000 jobs a year, according to Stephen Katz, director of the Center for Entertainment Industry Data and Research, a nonprofit association in California financed by movie-industry groups.
Feature-film expenditures in New York City decreased to $678 million in 2001 from $839 million in 1999, Ms. Scott said. Canada benefited from about $1.1 billion of spending from foreign productions in the year that ended on March 31, 2001, up 17 percent from the previous year, according to the Canadian Film and Television Production Association. Most of that spending came from United States filmmakers.
Nevertheless, some New York loyalists are resisting the call from the north. "There is no better backdrop than New York, and the look of our film is crucial to its authenticity," said Jane Rosenthal, a producer of "Analyze That," the sequel to "Analyze This." It has been shooting in the metropolitan area since April 3.
"New York's talent pool is extraordinary, not just for the first choice, but for the fourth choice," Ms. Rosenthal added.
On a recent afternoon, the film's stars, Robert De Niro and Billy Crystal, were facing the cameras in the film's final scene before the panoramic sweep of the Brooklyn Bridge. The crew of 150 at waterside was but a part of the 250 employees on the production payroll.
"We were asked about shooting 'Analyze That' in Canada," Ms. Rosenthal said, "and it was right after Sept. 11, and in view of our commitment to the city, we felt it had to be here."
Ms. Rosenthal would not reveal the production cost of her film, but it has been estimated at $50 million. She could have saved $5 million to $7.5 million across the border.
"It would be nice to save that kind of money," Ms. Rosenthal said. "It can sometimes be the difference between making your movie, or not."
But the incentives have made it increasingly common for films to do "splits," said Ms. Scott, where Hollywood studios "do the hard shot here in New York, then run up to Canada to do all the other work," like interiors. 
Canada, unsurprisingly, is less than thrilled about being blamed. "We don't see any divine right of the United States to have ownership of production," said Peter Lloyd, who heads political and economic relations at the Consulate General of Canada in New York. "It is a global industry, and we believe that every country has a right to compete for a share of the business." 
Elizabeth McDonald, president and chief executive of the Canadian Film and Television Production Association, a group of 400 producers, said, "It is not even clear that 'runaway production' actually exists."
"These productions may be shot in Canada, but the dollars don't necessarily stay in Canada," she said. "The copyright remains in United States hands, and profits remain in the United States." 
She also challenged some of Mr. Katz's findings, saying that the increase in foreign productions shot in Canada -- and the corresponding decrease in the United States -- could have been affected by production rescheduling in preparation for possible industry strikes last year.
Mr. Katz responded that "only Canadian subsidies could have caused the trend." 
But beyond this, the United States critics are "aggressively focused on Canada," Ms. McDonald said, when the issue "is also about Australia, the Czech Republic and other countries around the world."
In fact, many other nations have implemented tax incentives; Australia offers a 12.5 percent rebate. And Ms. Rosenthal said she knew of studios in the Czech Republic and Germany that are offering lavish incentives. 
"But the difference is that Canada is in the same time zones as New York and California," Ms. Scott said. 
The Canadian subsidies are especially damaging to New York because the city has mounted a longtime campaign to build its film infrastructure, the commissioner said. "New York City's economy currently has 47,000 full-time jobs in the industry, 78,000 freelance jobs and 5,000 production businesses," she said, "and now they are in jeopardy."
Many in the industry "are looking to remedies by our federal and state officials," said Mr. DeTitta of Local 52. 
Joseph A. Aredas, who heads the West Coast office of the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employees, which represents 28,000 film workers in California, agreed. "Everybody realizes that producers are going to travel to different places for artistic reasons or to get a certain look," he said, "but it shouldn't be money that makes them go."
Last month, the California State Assembly passed a proposal that would provide a 15 percent production tax credit on the first $25,000 of wages for film and television productions. The measure, which could help low-budget features, is headed for the State Senate. Similar legislation has been introduced in the United States Senate.
The Film and Television Action Committee, a Los Angeles advocacy group that says it represents 200,000 film workers and vendors, has announced plans to file a petition to get relief under the Trade Act of 1974. The group asserts that the subsidies provided by the Canadian federal and provincial governments are inconsistent with Canada's obligations under the World Trade Organization.
If the group's petition meets success, it could force Canada to eliminate the subsidies, or duties or import restrictions on Canadian goods could be imposed.
But Mr. Lloyd of the Canadian Consulate said, "There is nothing to indicate that these subsidies are not in conformity with international trading rules." And he pointed out that subsidies to moviemakers were already offered by states and locales, including New York.
Ms. Scott responded that "no incentive offered by either New York City or New York State rebates public funds to producers in New York."
Another option is to punish Canada for its subsidies by placing tariff barriers on the import of Canadian-made products "such as beer or hockey sticks," Mr. Katz said.
Meanwhile, even the most dedicated aficionados of Gotham cannot ignore the Canadian incentives. "I am loyal to staying home here, but you have to do what's smart for your project," Ms. Rosenthal said. "It could be the right business decision to shoot in Canada. The subsidies are a real threat that have to be considered."

HEADLINE: SCORCHED EARTH: THE OVERVIEW; 
Giant Wildfires Combine To Menace Arizona Town

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: SHOW LOW, Ariz., June 23 

 BODY:
Larry Humphrey, the incident commander, pointed to a map today and said: "We have our plans for attack. We have a strike team in place. We have our task forces. We're ready to triage."
 If it sounded as if he was at war, he was. 
 Two wildfires that have burned about 330,000 acres of northern Arizona in the last week merged today, becoming the biggest fire in the state's history. Officials said it could cover a million acres, about 1,500 square miles, before it goes out. 
It was bearing down tonight on Show Low, normally a town of 8,000 in the White Mountains that was eerily ghostlike today. Most of its residents fled on Saturday night, leaving squadrons of firefighters, fire officials and several hundred obstinate townspeople who defied the mandatory evacuation order.
The fire, one of the largest in the United States, is easily the most challenging of the young fire season. It surpasses even the forest fires that have beset Colorado in recent weeks.
Most of the 25,000 residents of the region have left their homes. With the fire's leading edge running for 50 miles at the north and the east, plumes of bruise-colored smoke are rising 15,000 feet and are visible halfway to Phoenix, 125 miles away.
On Monday, its first day, the larger of the two fires, Rodeo, grew to 48,000 acres from 700 acres in just six hours. In the next few days it blew mostly through wooded areas of the Apache-Sitgreaves National Forest. More recently, it has churned through small communities like Clay Springs, Pinedale and Linden before joining up with the Chediski.
But it is now threatening to hit its first real population center, Show Low, a town named for a style of poker. Fire officials said this afternoon that the blaze was moving ominously toward the west side of town.
"There are a lot of houses on the fringe of the forest, and there's nothing we can do to save them," Mr. Humphrey said, adding that the fire had already destroyed 115 houses, but "thousands of others have been saved." Seventy were destroyed by the smaller fire.
All the experts are saying the same thing: It is likely to get worse, perhaps much worse, before it gets better. That is especially bad news for Show Low, the economic engine of the area as a tourist and recreation destination for residents of Phoenix and Tucson. Fishing and hunting, gambling at the Apache casino, and the Fort Apache Timber Company keep the town vibrant.
Now, the forest that brings thousands to the area each summer is burned and closed to outsiders, the casino and timber mill are closed, and state officials are predicting that the fires will affect the economy of the area for years to come.
"I cannot tell you how serious this is," said Gov. Jane Dee Hull, who toured Show Low and a nearby evacuation site in Eagar today. "This is like a freight train coming at us."
Ms. Hull's trip served several purposes. She wanted to rally troops dog-tired after fighting the fire for almost a week. But she also wanted to send a political message to Washington that the fire-management policies now in place are not working.
Echoing the testimony of Dale N. Bosworth, the Forest Service chief who recently appeared before Congress and joined her today, Ms. Hull criticized the lawsuits and layers of administrative process that she said had prevented more aggressive efforts to clear the nation's forests of dense underbrush. The underbrush has been making fires so intense that firefighters cannot always get close enough to fight them.
"We've got to clean up these forests," said Ms. Hull, a Republican whose family has had a home in the area for three decades. "Mother Nature is telling us to do so. We've got to get this under control."
From here today, that sounded like a dream. Towering spirals of smoke over hot spots moved ever closer to town, casting a wide purple pall over the western horizon, a sharp contrast to the azure skies to the east. Officials said embers from the updrafts would soon begin falling like dirty snowflakes.
"The tactics we are going to be using is to let the flaming front go through, then go back and put out the fire," Mr. Humphrey said. "If it retreats, then we can go back in."
For Governor Hull, the tour was her first expanded look at fires that have led President Bush to promise her -- by telephone on Saturday -- he would declare on Monday that Arizona would receive federal disaster aid for the firefighting efforts.
With Mr. Bosworth and state officials, she flew into Show Low about 12 hours after all roads in were closed by the state police so evacuations could proceed at a more orderly pace.
Then, she spent 30 minutes aloft in and around the smoke plumes to get a close up view of the fires.
At the fire command center, she and Mr. Bosworth were briefed by officials who, essentially, gave them one small dose of good news, that firefighters working overnight have secured a four-mile fire break southeast of Show Low.
But the rest of the news was chilling. As John C. Bedell, forest supervisor for the Apache-Sitgreaves forests, said, if the fire outpaces efforts to extend the fire breaks, Show Low would be consumed by flames.
Additional caution came in the form of the weather forecast. It was hotter and drier than Saturday, perfect conditions for the fire to spread rapidly. Mr. Humphrey said that experts were considering asking for a fourth federal hot-shot team.
By today, firefighters on the lines, some from as far as Alaska, California and Illinois, were being aided by eight helicopters and seven tanker planes, dropping water and slurry on fires and homes. That was sufficient equipment, Mr. Humphrey said, because of hot spots so intense that firefighters can get only so close to them from the ground and air.
After the briefing, Ms. Hull joined state and local officials at a news conference at the command center, where Mayor Gene Kelley of Show Low was, perhaps, the most forlorn looking of the group. "We have no idea what we're going to do until we find out what the depth of damage is," he said softly. That damage, he added, could include his own home.
Mr. Bosworth used the opportunity of facing a dozen television crews to hammer home the point that federal fire management policies need to change. Forests like this one, he said, have grown 100 times more dense than they once were, a clean invitation for trouble.
"We need to take less time with analysis, paperwork and process," he said. "We need to do more work on the ground, and it's still going to take 10 years to make a difference."
Governor Hull then boarded her plane and flew 40 miles east to Eagar, which has the country's only high school with a domed football stadium. The facility is now the largest of three evacuation centers serving people driven out by the fires. On Saturday night 1,500 people slept on Army cots on its football field.
Dawn Huset, her two daughters, Samantha, 8, and Danielle, 2, and Ms. Huset's mother Deannna, were camped out on the 20-yard line. They had a few pillows, blankets, a few toys for the girls and not much more.
Ms. Huset said they moved to Lakeside, south of Show Low, two weeks ago from Moline, Ill. "Now, I don't know what to think," she said, an assertion heavy with meaning. She had no idea whether the house was still standing and, if it was not, what the family would do.
"I can't believe all this," she said.
Ms. Hull walked around the field, chatting with evacuees, encouraging them to stay hopeful. There were forced smiles all around.
The return flight to Phoenix took Ms. Hull past the soaring plumes once again, off in the purple distance. "Congress passes laws, and bureaucracies make regulations," she said, shaking her head. "Most of the time, neither one of them makes a lot of sense."

HEADLINE: Bush Facing Test in House As Economic Agenda Stalls 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 23 

 BODY:
The Republican-controlled House faces a politically painful decision in the coming week about whether to give in to increasingly urgent demands from the Bush administration for action to avert a government financial crisis, the latest example of the White House economic agenda's becoming trapped in partisan gridlock.
 The administration is likely to succeed in its efforts to persuade the House to support an increase in the legal limit on the national debt, because failure to do so would leave the government unable to borrow enough money to meet all its obligations starting at the end of the week. 
 "We will not let the federal government default on debt," J. Dennis Hastert, Republican of Illinois and the House speaker, said today on the CNN program "Hunt, Novak and Shields."
The reluctance of House Republicans to take up the issue, and the eagerness of Democrats in both chambers to emphasize it, is the newest skirmish in the fight over whether the tax cut pushed through Congress last year by President Bush has proved to be too expensive.
But the maneuvering over a step that both parties acknowledge must be taken to avert a catastrophic default is also evidence of how the two parties are at loggerheads over a range of economic issues. 
After a quick victory last year with passage of its tax cut, the administration has had little success advancing the rest of its economic agenda and faces questions on the strength of its economic team, analysts and members of both parties say.
Now that the government's priority has shifting to fighting terrorism, and with the White Houses political strategy complicated by last year's recession and the shift in control of the Senate to the Democrats, many Bush proposals have been slowed, watered down or undermined by the administration's own actions.
On trade, the budget, Social Security, energy, the fallout from the Enron scandal and efforts to make permanent the provisions of the 10-year tax cut, Mr. Bush has found himself on the defensive, forced into compromises or playing for time.
He paid little or no political price for the recession, because it was brief and mild and because of the focus on terrorism. But with the strength of the recovery in doubt, Wall Street jittery about corporate malfeasance and Democrats eager to emphasize pocketbook issues in this fall's Congressional elections, analysts say the Bush economic record is sure to be scrutinized more intently in coming months.
"The only thing the administration really accomplished that was set out in the original December 2000 game plan was the tax cut," said Kim Wallace, a political analyst in Washington for Lehman Brothers.
Mr. Bush came to office advocating an expansion of free trade deals. He asserted that the nation could afford a big tax cut and still pay down the debt. He called for creating personal investment accounts in the Social Security system. He sought more freedom for oil companies to drill, saying it would reduce reliance on foreign oil.
House Republican leaders have signaled that they will do what it takes to avert a financial default this week, despite wide opposition among them to any vote that would put them on record supporting an increase in the $5.95 trillion national debt, much of which is obligations to pay future Social Security benefits. The Senate has voted for a $450 billion increase in the debt ceiling, enough to get the government through to early next year.
Moreover, White House officials say they are forging ahead with the rest of their agenda, with no second thoughts about the wisdom of the tax cut. They say last year's tax cut for individuals and the corporate tax breaks Mr. Bush signed into law in March are lifting the economy. 
To the extent that other initiatives have been stalled or rewritten, they assert, the fault rests with the Democratic leadership of the Senate, which they cast as obstructionist.
With members of Congress from both parties facing pressure from voters to accomplish something, the logjam could break this summer, giving the president a series of victories, administration officials say.
"Things are progressing," said Lawrence B. Lindsey, Mr. Bush's chief economic policy adviser. 
Democrats say the current situation makes clear that Mr. Bush is not much interested in any domestic or economic policy beyond tax cuts.
"The Bush domestic agenda ended with the tax cut," said Bruce Reed, president of the Democratic Leadership Council. "Instead of coming up with new economic ideas, they've spent most of their time coming up with new rationales for old ideas."
Even important economic legislation that is progressing faces many hurdles. The House and the Senate have passed legislation increasing the president's authority to negotiate international trade deals. But it is unclear if the two very different versions can be reconciled. An effort to begin talks on a compromise faltered last week when the Republican leadership in the House lacked the votes to get past a procedural hurdle.
In other cases, circumstances have forced the administration to accept radical changes in its goals. With national security needs and a drop in tax revenue, Mr. Bush's push to limit spending growth has given way to the biggest expansion of government in decades and a swing from surpluses to deficits. With money tight, the president has failed to persuade Congress to make permanent the 10-year tax cut, including repeal of the estate tax.
Then there are Social Security and energy. On the first issue, vociferous Democratic opposition has led Mr. Bush to put his plans for an overhaul on the back burner; on the second, the Senate gutted central provisions of the president's proposal, including his call for drilling in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge.
The relatively limited regulatory changes Mr. Bush advocated after Enron's collapse have done little to restore investor confidence on Wall Street, where falling stock prices and concern about the integrity of corporate accounting threaten the recovery. On Tuesday, the Senate Banking Committee adopted a bill, with bipartisan support, that would go further in regulating accountants than Mr. Bush has called for.
On some issues, the administration has muddied its own message for the sake of scoring political points, members of both parties say. In a move widely seen as out of step with his free-trade philosophy, Mr. Bush imposed tariffs in March to protect domestic steel. Last month he signed a bipartisan farm-subsidy bill that conservatives considered bloated, undercutting his calls for limited government spending and more reliance on market forces.
"The Bush team has treated conservative economic principles at times like bargaining chips," said Kevin A. Hassett, an economist at the conservative American Enterprise Institute. 
Some analysts say Mr. Bush's economic team lacks the influence to prevail not just on Capitol Hill or in the public arena but also in debates with White House political advisers like Karl Rove.
Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill, a blunt, results-oriented pragmatist to his supporters, is dismissed as a quirky loose cannon by his critics, some of them Republican. Mr. Lindsey still has the president's ear but is viewed by people inside and outside the administration as disorganized and a weak manager. 
"They've got an imbalance in the sense that they have strong political advisers who know what they want," said I. M. Destler, director of the program on international security and economic policy at the University of Maryland. But they have no "comparably connected people with economic perspectives," he said. 
Mr. O'Neill "has been an idiosyncratic figure," in the view of Mr. Destler, who said of Mr. Lindsey, "The skepticism about him as a policy manager hasn't been rebutted."
After winning initial praise for their role in getting the president off to a fast start with the tax cut, nearly all the members of the economic team have taken some lumps. 
"There's no one in the inner sanctum who's a heavyweight on these issues," said Stephen Moore, president of the Club for Growth, a political action committee for supply-side conservatives. 
Administration officials say the economic team has the president's confidence, and the targets of the criticism, like Mr. O'Neill and Mr. Lindsey, have for the most part brushed it off. 
To be sure, the administration has had some successes since Mr. Bush signed the tax cut into law a year ago. It has pushed forward much of its deregulatory agenda, particularly on environmental rules, and is making plans for initiatives, including an overhaul of the tax code. But the lack of momentum on most high-profile economic issues has left parts of Mr. Bush's conservative base frustrated.
"The tax cut was the crown jewel of what they were trying to do in domestic policy," Mr. Moore said. "Having said that, from the start of this year Bush's economic agenda has been pretty much adrift."
